ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Prerequisites/Preconditions] This protocol [MS-ASCMD] assumes that authentication has been performed by the underlying protocols.
[In Transport] This protocol [MS-ASCMD] consists of a series of XML elements contained in request or response messages between a client and server.
[In Transport] The XML block containing the command and parameter elements is transmitted in [either] the request body of a request [, or in the response body of a response].
[In Transport] The XML block containing the command and parameter elements is transmitted in [either the request body of a request, or in ] the response body of a response.
[In Transport] The request body and request response are always preceded by the HTTP header, as specified in [MS-ASHTTP], except for the Autodiscover command <1>.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirements: MS-ASCMD_R7491, MS-ASCMD_R7573, MS-ASCMD_R7574, MS-ASCMD_R7569, MS-ASCMD_R7575, MS-ASCMD_R7576.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Transport] All command (except the Autodiscover command) messages are encoded as WBXML.
[In Transport] The Autodiscover command uses plain XML.
[In Transport] For more details about WBXML, see [MS-ASWBXML].
[In Autodiscover] The Autodiscover command facilitates the discovery of core account configuration information by using the user's Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP) address as the primary input.
[In Autodiscover] For information about the Autodiscover service, see [MSFT-AUTODISCOVER].
[In Autodiscover] For more details about the Autodiscover HTTP Service, see [MS-OXDSCLI].
[In Autodiscover] The Autodiscover command request and response messages are sent in XML format, not WBXML format.
[In Autodiscover] When sending an Autodiscover command request, the Content-Type header value MUST be set to text/xml.<2>
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirements: MS-ASCMD_R5123, MS-ASCMD_R5718.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Autodiscover] For more details about the Content-Type header, see [MS-ASHTTP] section 2.2.1.1.2.3.
[In Autodiscover] The client SHOULD use the Autodiscover command as an initial response to common HTTP errors.
[In Autodiscover] Common HTTP errors are specified in [MS-ASHTTP] section 2.2.2.1.1.

[In Autodiscover] Autodiscover has the ability to retrieve an updated URL when a mailbox has been moved, a user is trying to connect to a server that cannot access the user's mailbox [, or when there is a more efficient server to use to reach the user's mailbox].

[In Autodiscover] Autodiscover has the ability to retrieve an updated URL [when a mailbox has been moved, a user is trying to connect to a server that cannot access the user's mailbox, or ] when there is a more efficient server to use to reach the user's mailbox.
[In Autodiscover] After a successful Autodiscover command response, the client sends an HTTP Options command to the server identified in the Autodiscover command response.
[In Autodiscover] The HTTP Options command returns the newly supported protocol versions and commands if they changed due to the Autodiscover command.

[In Autodiscover] The http://schemas.microsoft.com/exchange/autodiscover/mobilesync/requestschema/2006 namespace is the primary namespace for the Autodiscover command and this section [2.2.2.1] of the specification [MS-ASCMD].

[In Find] The XML schema for the Find command request is described in section 6.7.
[In Find] The XML schema for the Find command response is described in section 6.8.
[In Find] The Accept-Language header in a Find command request is used to define the locale of the client so that the search is relevant.
[In Find] If the accept language is not specified, the search is conducted by using the server language.
[In Find] [Searching the Global Address List (GAL)] The Find command is used to find contacts and recipients in the GAL, and to retrieve information about them.
[In Find] [Searching the Global Address List (GAL)] When a search query matches more than one GAL entry, the Find command MUST return as many entries as requested.

[In Find] [Searching the Global Address List (GAL)] When a search query matches more than one GAL entry, [the Find command MUST return as many entries as requested,] up to a total of 100 entries by default.

[In Find] [Searching the Global Address List (GAL)] For each GAL entry that is found, the Find command returns all the non-empty properties that are indexed by the online ambiguous name resolution (ANR) in the global catalog server—for example, email alias, display name, first and last names, company name, and so on.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Partially verified by derived requirement: MS-ASCMD_R1002501.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Find] For each GAL entry that is found, the Find command returns email alias and display name.
[In Find] [Searching the Global Address List (GAL)] The client can optionally specify the maximum number of entries to retrieve in the Find command request by specifying the range.
[In Find] [Searching the Global Address List (GAL)] The server MUST return entries up to the number that is requested, and MUST also indicate the total number of entries that are found.
[In Find] [Searching the Global Address List (GAL)] The text query string that is provided to the Find command is used in a prefix-string match.

[In Find] [Searching the Global Address List (GAL)] For example, if the client performs a Find with a Query element value of "Michael A.", the command returns the entries that contain the search string in any text field, such as "Michael Alexander", "Michael Allen".

[In Find] [Searching the Global Address List (GAL)] [For example, if the client performs a Find with a Query element value of "Michael A.", the command returns the entries that contain the search string in any text field, such as "Michael Alexander", "Michael Allen".] Because the Find command matches the Query element value against all GAL text properties that are indexed by using ANR, the client can also search by email address, company name, and so on.
[In Find] [Searching the Global Address List (GAL)] The ANR system indexes the following properties: § Display name § Alias § FirstName § LastName § EmailAddress
[In Find] [Searching the Global Address List (GAL)] The Find command results are sorted by the server according to their ordering in the GAL (that is, by the display name property).
[In Find] [Searching the Global Address List (GAL)] Because of how the search results are sorted, the client could have to sort the results to display results in a relevant manner to users.
[In Find] [Searching the Global Address List (GAL)] For example, a search for "123" might return all GAL entries that have mailing addresses [or email addresses that begin with 123].
[In Find] [Searching the Global Address List (GAL)] For example, a search for "123" might return [all GAL entries that have mailing addresses or] email addresses that begin with 123.

[In Find] [Searching the Global Address List (GAL)] [if they know their users use email addresses more frequently than mailing addresses,] The client can choose to display matching email addresses before mailing addresses.

[In Find] [Searching the Global Address List (GAL)] [or if mailing addresses before email addresses if mailing addresses are used more frequently.] The client can choose to display matching email addresses before mailing addresses.

[In Find] [Searching Email Content] [Search using the Find command involves the following phases.] 1. The client issues a request to find specific emails that are returned by the server with preview text.
[In Find] [Searching Email Content] [Search using the Find command involves the following phases.] 2. The client uses subsequent requests to retrieve more results by incrementing the range.

[In Find] [Searching Email Content] [Search using the Find command involves the following phases.] 3. The client can use the ServerId element and CollectionId element to determine if an email item was previously synced.

[In Find] [Searching Email Content] [Search using the Find command involves the following phases.] 4. If an email item has not already been synced, the client can issue an ItemOperations command to fetch the item using the CollectionId and ServerId element.

[In Find] [Searching Email Content] [Search using the Find command involves the following phases.] 5. Any other actions on the search results are carried out by using other protocol commands, such SmartReply or SmartForward.

[In Find] Protocol version 14.1 does not supports this [Find] command.
[In Find] Protocol version 16.0 does not supports this [Find] command.
[In Find] Protocol version 16.1 does supports this [Find] command.
[In FolderCreate] The FolderCreate command creates a new folder as a child folder of the specified parent folder.
[In FolderCreate] A parent ID of 0 (zero) signifies the mailbox Root folder.
[In FolderCreate] The FolderCreate command cannot be used to create a recipient information cache [or a subfolder of a recipient information cache].
[In FolderCreate] The FolderCreate command cannot be used to create [a recipient information cache or] a subfolder of a recipient information cache.

[In FolderDelete] The FolderDelete command deletes a folder from the server.

[In FolderDelete] The ServerId (section 2.2.3.151.2) of the folder is passed to the server in the FolderDelete command request (section 2.2.2.3), which deletes the collection with the matching identifier.
[In FolderDelete] The server then sends a response indicating the status of the deletion.
[In FolderDelete] The FolderDelete command cannot be used to delete a recipient information cache.
[In FolderDelete] Attempting to delete a recipient information cache using this command results in a Status element (section 2.2.3.162.3) value of 3.
[In FolderDelete] The FolderHierarchy namespace is the primary namespace for this section [2.2.2.3].
[In FolderDelete] Elements referenced in this section [2.2.2.3] that are not defined in the FolderHierarchy namespace use the namespace prefixes defined in section 2.2.1.

[In FolderSync] The FolderSync command synchronizes the collection hierarchy.
[In FolderSync] But [FolderSync command] does not synchronize the items in the collections themselves.
[In FolderSync] This [FolderSync] command works similarly to the Sync command (section 2.2.2.19).

[In FolderSync] An initial FolderSync command with a SyncKey element (section 2.2.3.171.2) value of 0 (zero) is required in order to obtain the list of folders and the synchronization key associated with that list [list of folders].
[In FolderSync] The synchronization key is returned in the SyncKey element of the response if the FolderSync command succeeds.
[In FolderSync] This synchronization key is used in subsequent FolderSync commands to obtain folder hierarchy changes.
[In FolderSync] Unlike a Sync request, there is no GetChanges element (section 2.2.3.80) submitted in the FolderSync request (section 2.2.2.4) to get changes from the server.
[In FolderSync] All folders MUST be returned to the client when initial folder synchronization is done with a synchronization key of 0 (zero).
[In FolderSync] The FolderHierarchy namespace is the primary namespace for this section [2.2.2.4].
[In FolderSync] Elements referenced in this section [2.2.2.4] that are not defined in the FolderHierarchy namespace use the namespace prefixes defined in section 2.2.1.

[In FolderUpdate] The FolderUpdate command moves a folder from one location to another on the server.
[In FolderUpdate] The [FolderUpdate] command is also used to rename a folder.
[In FolderUpdate] The FolderUpdate command cannot be used to update a recipient information cache.
[In FolderUpdate] [The FolderUpdate command cannot be used] to move a folder under the recipient information cache.

[In GetAttachment] The GetAttachment command retrieves an email attachment from the server.
[In GetAttachment] Attachment data is not automatically included with email messages in a synchronization.
[In GetAttachment] Instead, an Attachment element ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.7) is included for each attachment.
[In GetAttachment] The Attachment element specifies the name of the attachment in the DisplayName element ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.11).
[In GetAttachment] Attachments are explicitly retrieved by attachment name by using the GetAttachment command.
[In GetAttachment] This command [GetAttachment] is issued within the HTTP POST command.
[In GetAttachment] [GetAttachment command] does not require any additional information in an XML body.
[In GetAttachment] The name of the attachment to be retrieved is specified in the AttachmentName command parameter.
[In GetAttachment] The content of the attachment is returned in the response body with the content type being specified in the Content-Type header of the response.
[In GetAttachment] When the Content-Type header is missing, this indicates that the default encoding of 7-bit ASCII has been used.
[In GetAttachment] If the GetAttachment command is used to retrieve an attachment that has been deleted on the server, a 500 status code is returned in the HTTP POST response.
[In GetAttachment] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [GetAttachment] command.
[In GetAttachment] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [GetAttachment] command.

[In GetHierarchy] The GetHierarchy command gets the list of email folders from the server.
[In GetHierarchy] Each folder's place within the folder hierarchy is indicated by its parent ID.
[In GetHierarchy] The list of folders returned by the GetHierarchy command includes only email folders.
[In GetHierarchy] For example, the Contacts folder and the Calendar folder are not included in the list.

[In GetHierarchy] Because the GetHierarchy command does not return a synchronization state for a folder hierarchy, the client uses the FolderSync command [either] to manipulate the folder hierarchy [or to retrieve the complete folder hierarchy].

[In GetHierarchy] Because the GetHierarchy command does not return a synchronization state for a folder hierarchy, the client uses the FolderSync command [either to manipulate the folder hierarchy or] to retrieve the complete folder hierarchy.
[In GetHierarchy] The client can use the GetHierarchy command to obtain the collection ID of a folder, such as Sent Items folder [or Deleted Items folder], that does not change.
[In GetHierarchy] The client can use the GetHierarchy command to obtain the collection ID of a folder, such as Sent Items folder [or Deleted Items folder], that cannot be deleted.
[In GetHierarchy] The client can use the GetHierarchy command to obtain the collection ID of a folder, such as [Sent Items folder or] Deleted Items folder, that does not change.
[In GetHierarchy] The client can use the GetHierarchy command to obtain the collection ID of a folder, such as [Sent Items folder or] Deleted Items folder, that cannot be deleted.
[In GetHierarchy] The collection ID is obtained from the ServerId element of a previous FolderSync [or FolderCreate] command.
[In GetHierarchy] The collection ID is obtained from the ServerId element of a previous [FolderSync or] FolderCreate command.
[In GetHierarchy] An HTTP status code of 500 is returned in the response if the GetHierarchy command request fails.
[In GetHierarchy] The FolderHierarchy namespace is the primary namespace for this section.
[In GetHierarchy] Elements referenced in this section that are not defined in the FolderHierarchy namespace use the namespace prefixes defined in section 2.2.1.

[In GetHierarchy] That is, there is no such top-level element called "GetHierarchy" that identifies the body of the HTTP POST as containing a GetHierarchy command.
[In GetHierarchy] Instead, the Folders element is the top-level element.

[In ItemOperations] The ItemOperations command acts as a container for the Fetch element (section 2.2.3.63.1), the EmptyFolderContents element (section 2.2.3.55), and the Move element (section 2.2.3.107.1) to provide batched online handling of these operations against the server.
[In ItemOperations] Operations that are contained within the ItemOperations element (section 2.2.3.89) MUST be executed by the server in the specified order.
[In ItemOperations] The server MUST report the status per operation to the client.
[In ItemOperations] Accordingly, the client correlates these responses to the initial operation and proceeds appropriately.
[In ItemOperations] The ItemOperations command cannot perform operations on items in the recipient information cache.
[In ItemOperations] The fetch operation is intended to be used on Microsoft Windows SharePoint Services technology, for Universal Naming Convention (UNC) access, or for user mailbox access.
[In ItemOperations] Document metadata, search results, and mailbox items and attachments can be retrieved.
[In ItemOperations] The EmptyFolderContents operation enables the client to empty a folder of all its items.
[In ItemOperations] Clients typically use the EmptyFolderContents operation to clear out all items in the Deleted Items folder if the user runs out of storage quota.
[In ItemOperations] The Move operation moves a conversation to a destination folder.
[In ItemOperations] The ItemOperations namespace is the primary namespace for this section [2.2.2.8].
[In ItemOperations] Elements referenced in this section [2.2.2.8] that are not defined in the ItemOperations namespace use the namespace prefixes defined in section 2.2.1.

[In Delivery of Content Requested by Fetch]Because the ItemOperations response (section 2.2.2.8) potentially contains large amounts of binary data, the client can choose a delivery method that is most efficient for its implementation by providing the following two methods for delivering the content that is requested by the Fetch element (section 2.2.3.63.1): Inline , Multipart
[In Delivery of Content Requested by Fetch] The inline method of delivering binary content is including data encoded with base64 encoding inside the WBXML.
[In Delivery of Content Requested by Fetch] The inline method generally requires the client to read the whole response into memory in order to parse it, thereby consuming a large amount of memory.
[In Delivery of Content Requested by Fetch] The inline method is the default method for ItemOperations responses.

[In Delivery of Content Requested by Fetch] The multipart method of delivering content is a multipart structure with the WBXML being the first part, and the requested data populating the subsequent parts.

[In Delivery of Content Requested by Fetch] This format [The multipart method of delivering content is a multipart structure with the WBXML being the first part, and the requested data populating the subsequent parts] enables a client to handle large files without consuming large amounts of memory, because a file is read in pieces, one piece at a time.

[In Delivery of Content Requested by Fetch] Clients request multipart responses by including the MS-ASAcceptMultiPart header (specified in [MS-ASHTTP] section 2.2.1.1.2.3) set to "T" (TRUE) in the request.
[In Delivery of Content Requested by Fetch] Multipart responses have a Content-Type header with the value "application/vnd.ms-sync.multipart".
[In Delivery of Content Requested by Fetch] The format of the body of the response is a MultiPartResponse structure, specified in section 2.2.2.9.1.1.
[In Delivery of Content Requested by Fetch] For an example of requesting and receiving a multipart response, see section 4.10.5.
[In MultiPartResponse] The MultiPartResponse structure represents the format of the body of a multipart ItemOperations command response.
[In MultiPartResponse] PartsCount (4 bytes): This field [PartsCount] is an integer that indicates the number of PartMetaData structures contained in the PartsMetaData field.
[In MultiPartResponse] It [PartsCount] also indicates the number of binary parts contained in the Parts field.
[In MultiPartResponse] PartsMetaData (variable): This field [PartsMetaData] is an array of PartMetaData structures, as specified in section 2.2.2.9.1.1.1.
[In MultiPartResponse] The length of the array is equal to the value of the PartsCount field.
[In MultiPartResponse] Parts (variable): This field [Parts] is an array of bytes that contains the data for the parts of the multipart response.
[In MultiPartResponse] The data in the Parts field is interpreted by using the offset and length information in the PartsMetaData field.
[In PartMetaData] The PartMetaData structure is used in the PartsMetaData field of the MultiPartReponse structure specified in section 2.2.2.8.1.1.
[In PartMetaData] It [PartMetaData] contains the offset and length of a single part of a multipart ItemOperations command response.
[In PartMetaData] Offset (4 bytes): This field [Offset] is an integer that contains the number of bytes from the beginning of the MultiPartResponse structure where a part's data is located.
[In PartMetaData] Length (4 bytes): This field [Length] is an integer that contains the number of bytes that comprise the part's data.
[In MeetingResponse] The MeetingResponse command is used to accept [, tentatively accept, or decline] a meeting request in the user's Inbox folder [or Calendar folder].<3>

[In MoveItems] The MoveItems command moves an item or items from one folder on the server to another [folder].
[In MoveItems] The item to be moved is identified by its server ID in the MoveItems command request (section 2.2.2.11).
[In MoveItems] The source and destination folders are also identified by their server IDs in the command request.
[In MoveItems] The MoveItems command response shows the status of the move, the message that was moved, and the new message ID.

[In MoveItems] When items are moved between folders on the server, the client receives Delete (section 2.2.3.42) and Add (section 2.2.3.7) operations the next time the client synchronizes the affected folders.
[In MoveItems] An item that has been successfully moved to a different folder can be assigned a new server ID by the server.
[In MoveItems] The Move namespace is the primary namespace for this section [2.2.2.10].
[In MoveItems] Elements referenced in this section [2.2.2.10] that are not defined in the Move namespace use the namespace prefixes defined in section 2.2.1.

[In Ping] The Ping command is used to request that the server monitor specified folders for changes that would require the client to resynchronize.
[In Ping] The body of the request contains a list of folders on the server about which the client is requesting notifications.
[In Ping] The body of the request contains an interval of time that specifies how long the server SHOULD wait before responding if no new items are added to the specified folders.

[In Search] The Accept-Language header in a Search command request is used to define the locale of the client so that the search is relevant.
[In Search] If the accept language is not specified, the search is conducted by using the server language.
[In Search] Searching the Global Address List (GAL)
[In Search] The Search command is used to find contacts and recipients in the GAL, and to retrieve information about them [contacts and recipients in the GAL].
[In Search] When a search query matches more than one GAL entry, the Search command MUST return as many entries as requested, up to a total of 100 entries by default.

[In Search] For each GAL entry that is found, the Search command returns all the non-empty properties that are indexed by the online ambiguous name resolution (ANR) in the global catalog server—for example, email alias, display name, first and last names, company name, and so on.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Partially verified by derived requirement: MS-ASCMD_R5711.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Search] For each GAL entry that is found, the Search command returns email alias and display name.
[In Search] The client can optionally specify the maximum number of entries to retrieve in the Search command request by specifying the range.
[In Search] The server MUST return entries up to the number that is requested.
[In Search] [The server] MUST also indicate the total number of entries that are found.
[In Search] The text query string that is provided to the Search command is used in a prefix-string match.

[In Search] For example, if the client performs a Search with a Query element value of "Michael A.", the command returns the entries that contain the search string in any text field, such as "Michael Alexander", "Michael Allen".

[In Search] Because the Search command matches the Query element value against all GAL text properties that are indexed by using ANR, the client can also search by email address, company name, and so on.
[In Search]The ANR system indexes the following properties: Display name, Alias, FirstName, LastName, EmailAddress.
[In Search] The Search command results are sorted by the server according to their ordering in the GAL (that is, by the display name property).
[In Search] Because of how the search results are sorted, the client could have to sort the results to display results in a relevant manner to users.
[In Search] For example, a search for "123" might return all GAL entries that have mailing addresses or email addresses that begin with 123.
[In Search] The client can choose to display matching email addresses before mailing addresses, if they know their users use email addresses more frequently than mailing addresses.
[In Search] [The client can choose to display matching] mailing addresses before email addresses if mailing addresses are used more frequently.
[In Search] The Range option is a zero-based index specifier in the form of "m-n".
[In Search] For more details about the meaning of the Range values, see section 2.2.3.130.2.
[In Search] Searching Outside the GAL
[In Search] Typical Usage
[In Search] Essentially, search involves the following three phases: 1. The client issues a request for specific search results.
[In Search] [Essentially, search involves the following three phases:] 2. The client uses subsequent requests to retrieve more results by incrementing the range.

[In Search] [Essentially, search involves the following three phases:] 3. Any actions on the search results are carried out by using other protocol commands, such as ItemOperations, SmartReply, or SmartForward.

[In Search] The following figure shows the typical usage of the Search command to retrieve successive result sets from the server and then perform some action based on those results (for example, retrieve the full message body (2) for an email search result).

[In SendMail] Clients SHOULD NOT save messages directly to the local Sent Items folder.

[In SendMail] [Clients SHOULD NOT save messages directly to the local Sent Items folder.] Instead, clients SHOULD use the SaveInSentItems element (section 2.2.3.144) to automatically save the messages on the server.
[In SendMail] It is not possible to reconcile the local Sent Items folder with the server's Sent Items folder by using the Sync command (section 2.2.2.19).
[In SendMail] Items in the server's Sent Items folder can be added to the client by using the Sync command, but it is not possible to add items that are in the local Sent Items folder to the server.
[In SendMail] Note that the From: MIME header in the outgoing message is set on the server to the primary email address of the authenticated user.

[In Settings] The Settings command supports get and set operations on global properties and Out of Office (OOF) settings for the user.

[In Settings] The Settings command also sends device information to the server, implements the device password/personal identification number (PIN) recovery, and retrieves a list of the user's email addresses.
[In Settings] The Get (section 2.2.3.75) and Set (section 2.2.3.152) operations act on named properties.
[In Settings] In the context of the Get and Set operations, each named property can contain a set of property-specific data nodes.
[In Settings] The Settings command can contain multiple Get and Set requests and responses in any order.
[In Settings] The implication of this batching mechanism is that commands are executed in the order in which they are received.
[In Settings] The implication of this batching mechanism is that the ordering of Get and Set responses will match the order of those commands in the request.

[In Settings] The following is the generic form of the Settings request, where "PropertyName" is a named property (that is, the actual name of the property). <Settings> <PropertyName> Data nodes </PropertyName> ... </Settings>

[In Settings] The Settings command can be used on the following named properties: OOF (section 2.2.3.104), DevicePassword 2.2.3.112), DevicePassword (section2.2.3.44), DeviceInformation 2.2.3.46), DeviceInformation (section2.2.3.43), UserInformation 2.2.3.45), UserInformation (section 2.2.3.165) 2.2.3.176), RightsManagementInformation (section 2.2.3.143).

[In Settings] Clients SHOULD send DeviceInformation parameters in a Set block to the server as soon as the client has been provisioned, and before the FolderSync command (section 2.2.2.4) so that the server can use this information to determine what the device has access to.<4>
[In Settings] The argument or data nodes are Get or Set, which can also have their own arguments.
[In Settings] It is up to the individual property handlers to parse and interpret them [individual property handlers] as necessary.
[In Settings] It is possible to have between 0 (zero) and 5 PropertyName elements in a Settings request (that is, each of the four named properties can appear zero or one time in a request).
[In Settings] Each property MUST be processed in order.
[In Settings] There can be cases in which one property call affects another property call .
[In Settings] The server will return responses in the same order [the order of elements in the Settings request] in which they [responses] were requested.

[In Settings] Each response message contains a Status element (section 2.2.3.167.14) value for the command, which addresses the success or failure of the Settings command, followed by Status values for each of the changes made to the Oof, DeviceInformation, DevicePassword or UserInformation elements.
[In Settings] The Status node MUST indicate success if the Settings response contains property responses.
[In Settings] If the command was not successful, the processing of the request cannot begin, no property responses are returned, and the Status node MUST indicate a protocol error.
[In Settings] Any error other than a protocol error is returned in the Status elements of the individual property responses.
[In Settings] All property responses, regardless of the property, MUST contain a Status element to indicate success or failure.
[In Settings] This Status node MUST be the first node in the property response.
[In Settings] The Settings namespace is the primary namespace for this section [2.2.2.16].
[In Settings] Elements referenced in this section [2.2.2.16] that are not defined in the Settings namespace use the namespace prefixes defined in section 2.2.1.

[In SmartForward] The SmartForward command is used by clients to forward messages without retrieving the full, original message from the server.
[In SmartForward] The body of the request depends on the protocol version that is being used.
[In SmartForward] See the details about protocol versions at the end of this section [2.2.2.18].

[In SmartForward] The SmartForward command is similar to the SendMail command (section 2.2.2.15), except that the outgoing message identifies the item being forwarded to and includes the text of the new message.
[In SmartForward] The full text of the original message is retrieved and sent by the server.
[In SmartForward] Using the server copy of the original message saves network bandwidth by not downloading the original message to the client and then uploading it again with the forward.
[In SmartForward] The SmartForward command lists the message recipients.
[In SmartForward] The ComposeMail namespace is the primary namespace for this section [2.2.2.17].
[In SmartForward] Elements referenced in this section [2.2.2.17] that are not defined in the ComposeMail namespace use the namespace prefixes defined in section 2.2.1.

[In SmartForward] Clients SHOULD NOT save messages directly to the local Sent Items folder.

[In SmartForward] [Clients SHOULD NOT save messages directly to the local Sent Items folder.] Instead, clients SHOULD use the SaveInSentItems element (section 2.2.3.144) to automatically save the messages on the server.
[In SmartForward] It is not possible to reconcile the local Sent Items folder with the server's Sent Items folder by using the Sync command (section 2.2.2.19).

[In SmartForward] Items in the server's Sent Items folder can be added to the client by using the Sync command, but it is not possible to add items that are in the local Sent Items folder to the server.
[In SmartForward] The SmartForward command can be applied to a meeting [or an appointment].
[In SmartForward] The SmartForward command can be applied to [a meeting or] an appointment.
[In SmartForward] When SmartForward is applied to a recurring meeting, the InstanceId element (section 2.2.3.87.2) specifies the ID of a particular occurrence in the recurring meeting.
[In SmartForward] If SmartForward is applied to a recurring meeting and the InstanceId element is absent, the server SHOULD forward the entire recurring meeting.

[In SmartReply] The SmartReply command is used by clients to reply to messages without retrieving the full, original message from the server.
[In SmartReply] The body of the request depends on the protocol version that is being used.
[In SmartReply] See the details about protocol versions at the end of this section [2.2.2.19].

[In SmartReply] The SmartReply command is similar to the SendMail command (section 2.2.2.15), except that the outgoing message identifies the item being replied to and includes the text of the new message.
[In SmartReply] The full text of the original message is retrieved and sent by the server.
[In SmartReply] Using the server copy of the original message saves network bandwidth by not downloading the original message to the client and then uploading it again with the reply.
[In SmartReply] The SmartReply command lists the message recipients, so it is used to implement both Reply and Reply-to-All functionality.
[In SmartReply] The ComposeMail namespace is the primary namespace for this section [2.2.2.18].
[In SmartReply] Elements referenced in this section [2.2.2.18] that are not defined in the ComposeMail namespace use the namespace prefixes defined in section 2.2.1.

[In SmartReply] It is not possible to reconcile the local Sent Items folder with the server's Sent Items folder by using the Sync command (section 2.2.2.19).

[In SmartReply] Items in the server's Sent Items folder can be added to the client by using the Sync command, but it is not possible to add items that are in the local Sent Items folder to the server.
[In SmartReply] The SmartReply command can be applied to a meeting.
[In SmartReply] When SmartReply is applied to a recurring meeting, the InstanceId element (section 2.2.3.83.2) specifies the ID of a particular occurrence in the recurring meeting.
[In SmartReply] If SmartReply is applied to a recurring meeting and the InstanceId element is absent, the server SHOULD reply for the entire recurring meeting.

[In Sync] Synchronization requires a priming of the system.
[In Sync] Therefore for each collection that the client wishes to synchronize, it [client] MUST issue an initial Sync request by sending a synchronization key of 0 (zero).
[In Sync] This [Sync] request establishes a synchronization relationship with the server and initializes the synchronization state there.
[In Sync] The server responds with an initial value of the synchronization key, which the client MUST then use to get the initial set of objects from the server.

[In Sync] (From this point [The server responds with an initial value of the synchronization key, which the client MUST then use to get the initial set of objects from the server] forward , client requests MUST always include the synchronization key that was received in the last response from the server.)
[In Sync] The client then sends a Sync command request to the server with the response synchronization key and includes any changes that were made on the client.
[In Sync] If the client device has not yet synchronized a folder, there SHOULD be no client-side changes.
[In Sync] The device MUST synchronize the full contents of a given folder, and then have its changes, additions, and deletions applied.
[In Sync] The response from the server indicates whether the client's changes were accepted, and includes any changes that were made on the server.
[In Sync] The server response also contains a synchronization key that is to be used for the next synchronization session for the folder.
[In Sync] This protocol [MS-ASCMD] has been optimized for the case in which there are no changes to any of the collections that are specified in the Sync request.
[In Sync] In such a case [there are no changes to any of the collections that are specified in the Sync request], the client can receive an empty response from the server.
[In Sync] After the client receives an empty response, the client can issue an empty Sync request.
[In Sync] The server then re-executes the previous request, which it [server] cached.
[In Sync] Certain ActiveSync classes support ghosted properties.
[In Sync] A ghosted property whose value has not changed from the last Sync response can be excluded from the request body.
[In Sync] Its [ghosted property's] value on the server will be preserved instead of being deleted.
[In Sync] A client uses the Supported element to specify to the server which properties are managed by the client and not ghosted by the server.
[In Sync] For more information, see section 2.2.3.164.
[In Sync] The following diagram shows request and response processing by the client.
[In Sync] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Sync] command.
[In Sync] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Sync] command.
[In Sync] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Sync] command.
[In Sync] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Sync] command.
[In Sync] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Sync] command.
[In Empty Sync Request] If the client sends a Sync request (section 2.2.2.20) with no client additions, changes, or deletes, the server caches the request.
[In Empty Sync Request] If no changes are detected on the server, the Sync response includes only HTTP headers, and no XML payload, and is referred to as an empty Sync response.

[In Empty Sync Request] When the client receives the empty Sync response, if there are no pending client changes, the client in turn can send only the HTTP headers, and no XML payload in the Sync request to save bandwidth.
[In Empty Sync Request] This [Empty Sync] request is referred to as an empty Sync request.
[In Empty Sync Request] If bandwidth is not a concern, the client can send a Sync request with an XML payload.
[In Empty Sync Request] When the server receives the empty Sync request, the server assumes the request is identical to the cached request, so it [server] retrieves the cached request and uses it.
[In Empty Sync Request] The cached request is discarded when the server receives a Sync request with an XML payload (a non-empty Sync request).
[In Empty Sync Request] This exchange of the empty Sync requests and responses continues until a change is detected on either the client or server.
[In Empty Sync Request] For an example empty Sync request and response, see section 4.5.10.
[In Empty Sync Response] The server sends a Sync response (section 2.2.2.20) with only HTTP headers, and no XML payload, if there are no pending server changes to report to the client.
[In Empty Sync Response] This Sync response[with only HTTP headers, and no XML payload] is referred to as an empty Sync response.
[In Empty Sync Response] The client can respond to the empty Sync response with an empty Sync request if there are no pending client changes and if the client is required to conserve bandwidth.
[In Empty Sync Response] Otherwise [if there are pending client changes and if the client is not required to conserve bandwidth], a Sync request with an XML payload can be sent.
[In Empty Sync Response] For more information about empty Sync requests, see section 2.2.2.19.1.
[In Empty Sync Response] For an example of an empty Sync request and response, see section 4.5.10.
[In ValidateCert] The ValidateCert command is used by the client to validate a certificate that has been received via an S/MIME mail.
[In ValidateCert] To validate a certificate, the server MUST verify that the certificate has not expired and has not been revoked.
[In ValidateCert] The server MUST walk up the certificate chain, verifying that each intermediate CA certificate has not expired.

[In ValidateCert] [The server MUST walk up the certificate chain, verifying that each intermediate CA certificate] has not been revoked and that the root certificate is a trusted certification authority (CA).
[In ValidateCert] Certificate validation is particularly important for verifying signatures (for example, on S/MIME signed mail).
[In ValidateCert] The ValidateCert namespace is the primary namespace for this section [2.2.2.20].
[In ValidateCert] Elements referenced in this section [2.2.2.20] that are not defined in the ValidateCert namespace use the namespace prefixes defined in section 2.2.1.

[In Common Status Codes] Command SmartForward (section 2.2.2.17), the status element specified in Section 2.2.3.162.15.
[In Common Status Codes] Command SmartReply (section 2.2.2.18), the status element specified in Section 2.2.3.162.15.
[In Common Status Codes] Command Sync (section 2.2.2.19), the status element specified in Section 2.2.3.162.16.
[In Common Status Codes] Command ValidateCert (section 2.2.2.20), the status element specified in Section 2.2.3.162.17.
[In Common Status Codes] Many of the status codes listed in the Status element sections have a scope assigned to them.
[In Common Status Codes] The following table defines the scope values [Global, Item, Policy].
[In Common Status Codes] Scope value Global means The status pertains to the overall client request.
[In Common Status Codes] Scope value Item means The status pertains to a particular item within the overall client request.
[In Common Status Codes] Scope value Policy means The status pertains to a particular policy within the Provision command.

[In Common Status Codes] In addition to the status values specified for individual commands in the Status element sections of this document [MS-ASCMD], the following table lists the Status element values that are common to all commands.
[In Common Status Codes] The protocol versions that support each value are specified in the "Protocol versions" column of the table.
[In Common Status Codes] When protocol version 2.5, 12.0, or 12.1 is used, an HTTP status code 4xx [or 5xx] instead of a Status element value 1xx is returned in the response.
[In Common Status Codes] When protocol version 2.5, 12.0, or 12.1 is used, an HTTP status code [4xx or] 5xx instead of a Status element value 1xx is returned in the response.
[In Common Status Codes] The specific HTTP status codes corresponding to some Status element values are specified in the table.

[In Common Status Codes] Note: The client indicates the protocol version being used by setting either the MS-ASProtocolVersion header, as specified in [MS-ASHTTP] section 2.2.1.1.2.4, or the Protocol version field, as specified in [MS-ASHTTP] section 2.2.1.1.1.1, in the request.
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element InvalidContent is 101.
[In Common Status Codes] When the protocol version is 14.0, 14.1 or 16.0, [The meaning of the status value 101 is] The body of the HTTP request sent by the client is invalid.

[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 101 is] The body of the HTTP request sent by the client is invalid, when protocol version 2.5, 12.0, or 12.1 is used, an HTTP 400 response is returned instead of this status value [101].

[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 101 is] Ensure the HTTP request is using the specified Content-Type and length, and that the request is not missing (when an empty body is not allowed).
[In Common Status Codes] Examples: Ping command (section 2.2.2.12) with a text/plain body, or SendMail command (section 2.2.2.16) with version 12.1 and a WBXML body.[Status 101 should be returned.]
[In Common Status Codes] When protocol version 2.5, 12.0, or 12.1 is used, an HTTP 400 response is returned instead of this status value [101].
[In Common Status Codes]The value of the element InvalidWBXML is 102.
[In Common Status Codes] When the protocol version is 14.0, 14.1 or 16.0, [The meaning of the status value 102 is] The request contains WBXML but it could not be decoded into XML.
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element InvalidXML is 103.
[In Common Status Codes] When the protocol version is 14.0, 14.1 or 16.0, [The meaning of the status value 103 is] The XML provided in the request does not follow the protocol requirements.
[In Common Status Codes] When protocol version 2.5, 12.0, or 12.1 is used, an HTTP 400 response is returned instead of this status value [103].
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element InvalidDateTime is 104.

[In Common Status Codes] When the protocol version is 14.0, 14.1 or 16.0, [The meaning of the status value 104 is] The request contains a timestamp that could not be parsed into a valid date and time.
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element InvalidCombinationOfIDs is 105.
[In Common Status Codes] When the protocol version is 14.0, 14.1 or 16.0, [The meaning of the status value 105 is] The request contains a combination of parameters that is invalid.
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element InvalidIDs is 106.
[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 106 is] The request contains one or more IDs that could not be parsed into valid values.

[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 106 is] That [The request contains one or more IDs that could not be parsed into valid values.] is different from specifying an ID in the proper format that does not resolve to an existing item.
[In Common Status Codes] When protocol version 2.5, 12.0, or 12.1 is used, an HTTP 400 response[, or an HTTP 500 response for the SendMail command,] is returned instead of this status value [106].
[In Common Status Codes] When protocol version 2.5, 12.0, or 12.1 is used, [an HTTP 400 response, or] an HTTP 500 response for the SendMail command, is returned instead of this status value [106].
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element InvalidMIME is 107.
[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 107 is ] The request contains MIME that could not be parsed.
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element DeviceIdMissingOrInvalid is 108.
[In Common Status Codes] When the protocol version is 14.0, 14.1 or 16.0, [The meaning of the status value 108 is] The device ID is either missing or has an invalid format.
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element DeviceTypeMissingOrInvalid is 109.
[In Common Status Codes] When the protocol version is 14.0, 14.1 or 16.0, [The meaning of the status value 109 is] The device type is either missing or has an invalid format.
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element ServerError is 110.
[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 110 is] The server encountered an unknown error, the device SHOULD NOT retry later.
[In Common Status Codes] When protocol version 2.5, 12.0, or 12.1 is used, an HTTP 500 response is returned instead of this status value [110].
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element ServerErrorRetryLater is 111.
[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 111 is] The server encountered an unknown error, the device SHOULD retry later.
[In Common Status Codes] When protocol version 2.5, 12.0, or 12.1 is used, an HTTP 503 response is returned instead of this status value [111].
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element ActiveDirectoryAccessDenied is 112.
[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 112 is] The server does not have access to read/write to an object in the directory service.
[In Common Status Codes] When protocol version 2.5, 12.0, or 12.1 is used, an HTTP 403 response is returned instead of this status value [112].
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element MailboxQuotaExceeded is 113.
[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 113 is] The mailbox has reached its size quota.
[In Common Status Codes] When protocol version 2.5, 12.0, or 12.1 is used, an HTTP 507 response is returned instead of this status value [113].
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element MailboxServerOffline is 114.
[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 114 is] The mailbox server is offline.
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element SendQuotaExceeded is 115.
[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 115 is] The request would exceed the send quota.
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element MessageRecipientUnresolved is 116.
[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 116 is] One of the recipients could not be resolved to an email address.
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element MessageReplyNotAllowed is 117.
[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 117 is] The mailbox server will not allow a reply of this message.
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element Message PreviouslySent is 118.

[In Common Status Codes] When the protocol version is 14.0, 14.1 or 16.0, [The meaning of the status value 118 is] The message was already sent in a previous request [or the request contains a message ID that was already used in a recent message].

[In Common Status Codes] When the protocol version is 14.0, 14.1 or 16.0, [The meaning of the status value 118 is] The [message was already sent in a previous request or the] request contains a message ID that was already used in a recent message.

[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 118 is] The server determined this [The message was already sent in a previous request or the request contains a message ID that was already used in a recent message.] by remembering the values of the ClientId (section 2.2.3.28) from the last few sent messages.
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element MessageHasNoRecipient is 119.
[In Common Status Codes] When the protocol version is 14.0, 14.1 or 16.0, [The meaning of the status value 119 is] The message being sent contains no recipient.

[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 120 is] The server failed to submit the message for delivery.
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element MessageReplyFailed is 121.
[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 121 is] The server failed to create a reply message.
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element AttachmentIsTooLarge is 122.
[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 122 is] The attachment is too large to be processed by this request.
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element UserHasNoMailbox is 123.
[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 123 is] A mailbox could not be found for the user.
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element UserCannotBeAnonymous is 124.
[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 124 is] The request was sent without credentials.
[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 124 is] Anonymous requests are not allowed.

[In Common Status Codes] When the protocol version is 14.0, 14.1 or 16.0, [The meaning of the status value 125 is] The user was not found in the directory service.

[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element UserOnNewMailboxCannotSync is 127.
[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 127 is] The server is configured to prevent users from syncing.

[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 128 is] The server is configured to prevent users on legacy servers from syncing.
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element DeviceIsBlockedForThisUser is 129.
[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 129 is] The user is configured to allow only some devices to sync.
[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 129 is] This device [devices to sync] is not the allowed device.
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element AccessDenied is 130.
[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 130 is] The user is not allowed to perform that request.
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element AccountDisabled is 131.
[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 131 is] The user's account is disabled.
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element SyncStateNotFound is 132.
[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 132 is ] The server’s data file that contains the state of the client was unexpectedly missing.
[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 132 is] It [server’s data file] might have disappeared while the request was in progress.
[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 132 is] The next request will likely answer a sync key error and the device will be forced to do full sync.
[In Common Status Codes] When protocol version 2.5, 12.0, or 12.1 is used, an HTTP 403 response[, or an HTTP 500 response for the Provision command,] is returned instead of this status value [132].
[In Common Status Codes] When protocol version 2.5, 12.0, or 12.1 is used, [an HTTP 403 response, or] an HTTP 500 response for the Provision command, is returned instead of this status value [132].
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element SyncStateLocked is 133.

[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 133 is] The server’s data file that contains the state of the client is locked, possibly because the mailbox is being moved or was recently moved.
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element SyncStateCorrupt is 134.
[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 134 is] The server’s data file that contains the state of the client appears to be corrupt.
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element SyncStateAlreadyExists is 135.

[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 135 is] This [The server’s data file that contains the state of the client already exists.] can happen with two initial syncs are executed concurrently.
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element SyncStateVersionInvalid is 136.
[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 136 is] The version of the server’s data file that contains the state of the client is invalid.

[In Common Status Codes] When protocol version 2.5, 12.0, or 12.1 is used, [an HTTP 400 response, or] an HTTP 505 response for version 1.0 devices, is returned instead of this status value [138].

[In Common Status Codes] For more details, see [MS-ASPROV] section 3.1.5.1.
[In Common Status Codes] When protocol version 2.5, 12.0, or 12.1 is used, an HTTP 403 response for no policy key header[, or an HTTP 449 response] is returned instead of this status value [140].
[In Common Status Codes] When protocol version 2.5, 12.0, or 12.1 is used, [an HTTP 403 response for no policy key header, or] an HTTP 449 response is returned instead of this status value.

[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element PolicyRefresh is 143.

[In Common Status Codes] When protocol version 2.5, 12.0, or 12.1 is used, an HTTP 449 response is returned instead of this status value [143].

[In Common Status Codes] When the protocol version is 14.0, 14.1 or 16.0, [The meaning of the status value 146 is] The request tried to forward an occurrence of a meeting that has no recurrence.

[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element InvalidStoredRequest is 149.

[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 149 is] When the device sent an empty request, the server tried to re-execute that previous request but it was found to be impossible.
[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 149 is] The device needs to send the full request again.
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element ItemNotFound is 150.

[In Common Status Codes] When the protocol version is 14.0, 14.1 or 16.0, [The meaning of the status value 150 is] The value of either the ItemId element (section 2.2.3.88) or the InstanceId element (section 2.2.3.87.2) specified in the SmartReply (section 2.2.2.19) or the SmartForward (section 2.2.2.18) command request could not be found in the mailbox.
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element TooManyFolders is 151.

[In Common Status Codes] When the protocol version is 14.1 or 16.0, The value of the element DeviceInformationRequired is 165.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Common Status Codes] The value of the element IRM_OperationNotPermitted is 172.
[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 172 is] Information Rights Management does not support the specified operation.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Common Status Codes] The value of the element NoPicture is 173.
[In Common Status Codes] When the protocol version is 14.1 or 16.0, [The meaning of the status value 173 is] The user does not have a contact photo.
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element PictureTooLarge is 174.
[In Common Status Codes] When the protocol version is 14.1 or 16.0, [The meaning of the status value 174 is] The contact photo exceeds the size limit set by the MaxSize element (section 2.2.3.99).

[In Common Status Codes] When the protocol version is 14.1 or 16.0, [The meaning of the status value 175 is] The number of contact photos returned exceeds the size limit set by the MaxPictures element (section 2.2.3.98).
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element BodyPart_ConversationTooLarge is 176.
[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 176 is] The conversation is too large to compute the body parts.
[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 176 is] Try requesting the body of the item again, without body parts.
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element MaximumDevicesReached is 177.
[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 177 is] The user's account has too many device partnerships.
[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 177 is] Delete partnerships on the server before proceeding.
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element InvalidMimeBodyCombination is 178.

[In Common Status Codes] When the protocol version is 16.0, [The meaning of the status value 178 is] The SmartForward command request included elements that are not allowed to be combined with [either] the Forwardees element (section 2.2.3.76) [or the airsyncbase:Body element ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.9)], as specified in section 2.2.3.159.

[In Common Status Codes] When the protocol version is 16.0, [The meaning of the status value 178 is] The SmartForward command request included elements that are not allowed to be combined with [either the Forwardees element (section 2.2.3.76) or] the airsyncbase:Body element ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.9), as specified in section 2.2.3.159.
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element InvalidSmartForwardParameters is 179.

[In Common Status Codes] When the protocol version is 16.0, [The meaning of the status value 179 is] The Forwardees element or the airsyncbase:Body element in the SmartForward command request could not be parsed.
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element InvalidRecipients is 183.

[In Common Status Codes] When the protocol version is 16.0, [The meaning of the status value 183 is] A draft email either has no recipients or has a recipient email address that is not in valid SMTP format.
[In Common Status Codes] The value of the element OneOrMoreExceptionsFailed is 184.

[In Common Status Codes] When the protocol version is 16.0, [The meaning of the status value 183 is] The server failed to successfully save all of the exceptions specified in a Sync command request (section 2.2.2.20) to add a calendar series with exceptions.

[In Common Status Codes] [The meaning of the status value 183 is] This code will be returned on the item level, and the client SHOULD check the status on each of the exceptions to see which ones failed and just resend those.

[In AcceptableResponseSchema] The AcceptableResponseSchema element is a required child element of the Request element in Autodiscover command requests that indicates the schema in which the server MUST send the response.
[In AcceptableResponseSchema] Element AcceptableResponseSchema in Autodiscover command request (section 2.2.2.1), the parent element is Request (section 2.2.3.141.1).
[In AcceptableResponseSchema] None [Element AcceptableResponseSchema in Autodiscover command request (section 2.2.2.1) has no child element.]
[In AcceptableResponseSchema] Element AcceptableResponseSchema in Autodiscover command request (section 2.2.2.1), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7).
[In AcceptableResponseSchema] Element AcceptableResponseSchema in Autodiscover command request (section 2.2.2.1), the number allowed is 1...1 (required).
[In AcceptableResponseSchema] The value of this [AcceptableResponseSchema] element MUST be "http://schemas.microsoft.com/exchange/autodiscover/mobilesync/responseschema/2006".
[In AcceptableResponseSchema] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [AcceptableResponseSchema] element.
[In AcceptableResponseSchema] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [AcceptableResponseSchema] element.
[In AcceptableResponseSchema] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [AcceptableResponseSchema] element.
[In AcceptableResponseSchema] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [AcceptableResponseSchema] element.
[In AcceptableResponseSchema] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [AcceptableResponseSchema] element.
[In Account] The Account element is a required child element of the Accounts element in Settings command responses that contains all account information associated with a single account.
[In Account] All elements [Accounts, AccountId, AccountName, UserDisplayName, SendDisabled, EmailAddresses] referenced in this section [2.2.3.2] are defined in the Settings namespace.
[In Account] Element Account in Settings command UserInformation response (section 2.2.2.17), the parent element is Accounts (section 2.2.3.5).

[In Account] The element Account in Settings command UserInformation response (section 2.2.2.17), the child elements are AccountId (section 2.2.3.3.2), AccountName (section 2.2.3.4), UserDisplayName (section 2.2.3.181), SendDisabled (section 2.2.3.151), EmailAddresses (section 2.2.3.54).
[In Account] Element Account in Settings command UserInformation response (section 2.2.2.17), the data type is container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2).
[In Account] Element Account in Settings command UserInformation response (section 2.2.2.17), the number allowed is 1…N (required).
[In Account] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [Account] element.
[In Account] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [Account] element.
[In Account] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Account] element.
[In Account] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Account] element.
[In Account] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Account] element.

[In AccountId] The AccountId element is used in the following command requests and responses: SendMail command requests (section 2.2.2.15), SmartForward command requests (section 2.2.2.17), SmartReply command requests (section 2.2.2.18), Settings command responses (section 2.2.2.16).
[In AccountId] The definition of the AccountId element differs according to the context in which it [AccountId element] is used.
[In AccountId] For more details, see section 2.2.3.3.1 and section 2.2.3.3.2.

[In AccountId(SendMail, SmartForward, SmartReply)] The AccountId element is an optional child element of the SendMail element in SendMail command requests, an optional child element of the SmartForward element in SmartForward command requests, and an optional child element of the SmartReply element in SmartReply command requests.
[In AccountId(SendMail, SmartForward, SmartReply)] In all contexts, it [AccountId element] identifies the account from which an email is sent.

[In AccountId(SendMail, SmartForward, SmartReply)] Elements [SendMail (section 2.2.3.148), SmartForward (section 2.2.3.154), SmartReply (section 2.2.3.155)] referenced in this section [2.2.3.3.1] are defined in the ComposeMail namespace, except where otherwise indicated by the presence of a namespace prefix (as defined in section 2.2.1).
[In AccountId(SendMail, SmartForward, SmartReply)] Element AccountId in SendMail command request (section 2.2.2.16), the parent element is SendMail (section 2.2.3.152).
[In AccountId(SendMail, SmartForward, SmartReply)] None [ Element AccountId in SendMail command request (section 2.2.2.16) has no child element.]
[In AccountId(SendMail, SmartForward, SmartReply)] Element AccountId in SendMail command request (section 2.2.2.16), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7).
[In AccountId(SendMail, SmartForward, SmartReply)] Element AccountId in SendMail command request (section 2.2.2.16), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In AccountId(SendMail, SmartForward, SmartReply)] Element AccountId in SmartForward command request (section 2.2.2.18), the parent element is SmartForward (section 2.2.3.159).
[In AccountId(SendMail, SmartForward, SmartReply)] None [ Element AccountId in SmartForward command request (section 2.2.2.18) has no child element.]
[In AccountId(SendMail, SmartForward, SmartReply)] Element AccountId in SmartForward command request (section 2.2.2.18), the data type is string.
[In AccountId(SendMail, SmartForward, SmartReply)] Element AccountId in SmartForward command request (section 2.2.2.18), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In AccountId(SendMail, SmartForward, SmartReply)] Element AccountId in SmartReply command request (section 2.2.2.19), the parent element is SmartReply (section 2.2.3.160).
[In AccountId(SendMail, SmartForward, SmartReply)] None [Element AccountId in SmartReply command request (section 2.2.2.19) has no child element.]
[In AccountId(SendMail, SmartForward, SmartReply)] Element AccountId in SmartReply command request (section 2.2.2.19), the data type is string.
[In AccountId(SendMail, SmartForward, SmartReply)] Element AccountId in SmartReply command request (section 2.2.2.19), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).

[In AccountId(SendMail, SmartForward, SmartReply)] If the AccountId element is not present in the request, the server sends the email using the account identified by the settings:PrimarySmtpAddress element (section 2.2.3.131) returned in the Settings command response (section 2.2.2.17).

[In AccountId(SendMail, SmartForward, SmartReply)] If AccountId is included in the request, the value MUST equal one of the settings:AccountId element values included in the Settings command response.
[In AccountId(SendMail, SmartForward, SmartReply)] The server MUST validate that the AccountId element value provided is valid for sending email.
[In AccountId(SendMail, SmartForward, SmartReply)] A Status element (section 2.2.3.167) value of 166 is returned if the AccountId element value is not valid.
[In AccountId(SendMail, SmartForward, SmartReply)] A Status element value of 167 is returned if the account does not support sending email.

[In AccountId(SendMail, SmartForward, SmartReply)] Note The server sends the email using the account specified by the AccountId element, and not the account specified by the From element ([MS-ASEMAIL] section 2.2.2.36).
[In AccountId(SendMail, SmartForward, SmartReply)] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [AccountId(SendMail, SmartForward, SmartReply)] element.
[In AccountId(SendMail, SmartForward, SmartReply)] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [AccountId(SendMail, SmartForward, SmartReply)] element.
[In AccountId(SendMail, SmartForward, SmartReply)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [AccountId(SendMail, SmartForward, SmartReply)] element.
[In AccountId(SendMail, SmartForward, SmartReply)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [AccountId(SendMail, SmartForward, SmartReply)] element.
[In AccountId(Settings)] The AccountId element is an optional child element of the Account element in Settings command responses (section 2.2.2.16).
[In AccountId(Settings)] The value of this element [AccountId] identifies an account.
[In AccountId(Settings)] The server MAY return this element [AccountId] in Settings command responses.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In AccountId(Settings)] All elements [Account] referenced in this section [2.2.3.3.2] are defined in the Settings namespace.

[In AccountId(Settings)]None[Element AccountId in Settings command response (section 2.2.2.17) has no child element.]
[In AccountId(Settings)] Element AccountId in Settings command response (section 2.2.2.17), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7).
[In AccountId(Settings)] Element AccountId in Settings command response (section 2.2.2.17), the number allowed is 0…1 (optional).

[In AccountId(Settings)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [AccountId(Settings)] element.
[In AccountId(Settings)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [AccountId(Settings)] element.
[In AccountId(Settings)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [AccountId(Settings)] element.
[In AccountName] The AccountName element is an optional child element of the Account element in Settings command responses (section 2.2.2.16).
[In AccountName] The value of this element [AccountName] specifies the friendly name for the given account.
[In AccountName] The server MAY return this element [AccountName] in Settings command responses.

[In AccountName] None [Element AccountName in Settings command UserInformation has no child element.]

[In AccountName] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [AccountName] element.
[In AccountName] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [AccountName] element.
[In AccountName] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [AccountName] element.
[In AccountName] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [AccountName] element.
[In Accounts] The Accounts element is an optional child element of the Get element in Settings command responses that contains all aggregate accounts that the user subscribes to.
[In Accounts] All elements [Get (section 2.2.3.79), Account (section 2.2.3.2)] referenced in this section [2.2.3.5] are defined in the Settings namespace.
[In Accounts] Element Accounts in Settings command UserInformation response (section 2.2.2.17), the parent element is Get (section 2.2.3.79).
[In Accounts] Element Accounts in Settings command UserInformation response (section 2.2.2.17), the child element is Account (section 2.2.3.2).
[In Accounts] Element Accounts in Settings command UserInformation response (section 2.2.2.17), the data type is container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2).
[In Accounts] Element Accounts in Settings command UserInformation response (section 2.2.2.17), the number allowed is 0…1 (optional).
[In Accounts] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [Accounts] element.
[In Accounts] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [Accounts] element.
