[In Accounts] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Accounts] element.
[In Accounts] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Accounts] element.
[In Action] The Action element is an optional child element of the Response element in Autodiscover command responses that encapsulates the server action type for the request.
[In Action] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.6] are defined in the http://schemas.microsoft.com/exchange/autodiscover/mobilesync/requestschema/2006 namespace.
[In Action] Element Action in Autodiscover command response (section 2.2.2.1), the parent element is Response (section 2.2.3.144.1).
[In Action] Element Action in Autodiscover command response (section 2.2.2.1), the child elements are Redirect (section 2.2.3.138), Settings (section 2.2.3.158.1), Error (section 2.2.3.60).
[In Action] Element Action in Autodiscover command response (section 2.2.2.1), the data type is container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2).
[In Action] Element Action in Autodiscover command response (section 2.2.2.1), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In Action] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Action] element.
[In Action] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Action] element.
[In Action] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Action] element.
[In Action] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Action] element.
[In Action] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Action] element.
[In Add] The Add element is used in the following command requests and responses: FolderSync command responses (section 2.2.2.4), Sync command requests and responses (section 2.2.2.19).
[In Add] The definition of the Add element differs according to the context in which it [Add element] is used.
[In Add] For more details, see section 2.2.3.7.1 and section 2.2.3.7.2.
[In Add(FolderSync)] The Add element is an optional child element of the Changes element in FolderSync command responses.
[In Add(FolderSync)] [The Add element] creates a new folder on the client.
[In Add(FolderSync)] Child elements of the Add element specify the server ID of the folder, the server ID of the parent folder, the display name of the folder, and the type of folder.

[In Add(FolderSync)] All elements [Changes (section 2.2.3.25), ServerId (section 2.2.3.156.3), ParentId (section 2.2.3.123.2), DisplayName (section 2.2.3.47.3) and Type (section 2.2.3.176.3)] referenced in this section [2.2.3.7.1] are defined in the FolderHierarchy namespace.
[In Add(FolderSync)] Element Add in FolderSync command response (section 2.2.2.4), the parent element is Changes (section 2.2.3.25).

[In Add(FolderSync)] Element Add in FolderSync command response (section 2.2.2.4), the child elements are ServerId (section 2.2.3.156.3), ParentId (section 2.2.3.123.2), DisplayName (section 2.2.3.47.3), Type (section 2.2.3.176.3).
[In Add(FolderSync)] Element Add in FolderSync command response (section 2.2.2.4), the data type is container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2).
[In Add(FolderSync)] Element Add in FolderSync command response (section 2.2.2.4), the number allowed is 0...N (optional).
[In Add(FolderSync)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Add(FolderSync)] element.
[In Add(FolderSync)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Add(FolderSync)] element.
[In Add(FolderSync)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Add(FolderSync)] element.
[In Add(FolderSync)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Add(FolderSync)] element.
[In Add(FolderSync)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Add(FolderSync)] element.

[In Add(Sync)] The Add element is an optional child element of the Commands element in Sync command requests and an optional child element of the Commands element and the Responses element in Sync command responses.
[In Add(Sync)] It [Add element] creates a new object in a collection on the client or on the server.

[In Add(Sync)] All elements [Commands (section 2.2.3.32), ClientId (section 2.2.3.28.2), ApplicationData (section 2.2.3.11), Class (section 2.2.3.27.5), ServerId (section 2.2.3.151.6), Responses (section 2.2.3.141) and Status (section 2.2.3.162.16)] referenced in this section [2.2.3.7.2] are defined in the AirSync namespace.
[In Add(Sync)] Element Add in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.20), the parent element is Commands (section 2.2.3.32).

[In Add(Sync)] Element Add in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.20), the child elements are ClientId (section 2.2.3.28.2), ApplicationData (section 2.2.3.11), Class (section 2.2.3.27.5), email2:Send ([MS-ASEMAIL] section 2.2.2.69).
[In Add(Sync)] Element Add in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.20), the data type is container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2).
[In Add(Sync)] Element Add in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.20), the number allowed is 0...N (optional).
[In Add(Sync)] Element Add in Sync command response, the parent element is Commands.
[In Add(Sync)] Element Add in Sync command response, the child elements are ServerId (section 2.2.3.156.7), ApplicationData (section 2.2.3.11).
[In Add(Sync)] Element Add in Sync command response, the data type is container.
[In Add(Sync)] Element Add in Sync command response, the number allowed is 0...N (optional).
[In Add(Sync)] Element Add in Sync command response, the parent element is Responses (section 2.2.3.145).
[In Add(Sync)] Element Add in Sync command response, the child elements are ServerId, ClientId, Class, Status (section 2.2.3.167.16).
[In Add(Sync)] Element Add in Sync command response, the data type is container.
[In Add(Sync)] Element Add in Sync command response, the number allowed is 0...N (optional).
[In Add(Sync)] When a new item is being sent from the client to the server, the ClientId element specifies a temporary ID for the item, which is unique on the client.
[In Add(Sync)] The ApplicationData element specifies the item data.

[In Add(Sync)] [When a new item is being sent from the client to the server] The server then responds with an Add element in a Responses element, which specifies the client ID and the server ID that was assigned to the new item.

[In Add(Sync)] When the client sends a Sync command request to the server and a new item has been added to the server collection since the last synchronization, the server responds with an Add element in a Commands element.
[In Add] This Add element specifies the server ID and data of the item to be added to the collection on the client.
[In Add(Sync)] One or more Add elements can appear as a child of the Commands and Responses elements for a particular collection.
[In Add(Sync)] The Add element cannot be used to add any email items from the client to the server, or to modify the contents of the recipient information cache.
[In Add(Sync)] If a client attempts to add emails to the server, a Status element with a value of 6 is returned as a child of the Add element.
[In Add(Sync)] If a client attempts to add an item to the recipient information cache, a Status element with a value of 4 is returned as a child of the Sync element.
[In Add(Sync)] If the server ID in an Add element from the server matches the server ID for an item on the client, the client treats the addition as a change to the client item.
[In Add(Sync)] The server is not required to send an individual response for every operation that is sent by the client.
[In Add(Sync)] The client only receives responses for successful additions, successful fetches, successful changes that include an attachment being added, and failed changes and deletions.
[In Add(Sync)] When the client does not receive a response, the client MUST assume that the operation succeeded unless informed otherwise.
[In Add(Sync)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Add(Sync)] element.
[In Add(Sync)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Add(Sync)] element.
[In Add(Sync)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Add(Sync)] element.
[In Add(Sync)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Add(Sync)] element.
[In Add(Sync)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Add(Sync)] element.

[In airsyncbase:FileReference] The airsyncbase:FileReference element is an optional child element of the Fetch element in ItemOperations command requests that specifies a unique identifier that is assigned by the server to each attachment to a given item.

[In airsyncbase:FileReference] Elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.8] are defined in the ItemOperations namespace, except where otherwise indicated by the presence of a namespace prefix (as defined in section 2.2.1).
[In airsyncbase:FileReference] Element airsyncbase:FileReference in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.9) fetch operation, the parent element is Fetch (section 2.2.3.63.1).
[In airsyncbase:FileReference] None [Element airsyncbase:FileReference in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.9) fetch operation has no child element.]
[In airsyncbase:FileReference] Element airsyncbase:FileReference in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.9) fetch operation, the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7).
[In airsyncbase:FileReference] Element airsyncbase:FileReference in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.9) fetch operation, the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In airsyncbase:FileReference] The client MUST store the file reference for any item that is retrieved by means of the Sync command (section 2.2.2.20) or Search command (section 2.2.2.15).
[In airsyncbase:FileReference] In an ItemOperations request, only one airsyncbase:FileReference identifier can exist per Fetch node.

[In airsyncbase:FileReference] Violation of this constraint [in an ItemOperations request, only one airsyncbase:FileReference identifier can exist per Fetch node] results in a Status element (section 2.2.3.167.7) value of 2 being returned from the server.
[In airsyncbase:FileReference] The client can, however, retrieve multiple attachments by using one Fetch node per attachment.

[In airsyncbase:FileReference] If the airsyncbase:FileReference element is present, then the Range element (section 2.2.3.134.1) is the only valid child element of the Options element (section 2.2.3.119.2).
[In airsyncbase:FileReference] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [airsyncbase:FileReference] element.
[In airsyncbase:FileReference] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [airsyncbase:FileReference] element.
[In airsyncbase:FileReference] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [airsyncbase:FileReference] element.
[In airsyncbase:FileReference] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [airsyncbase:FileReference] element.
[In airsyncbase:FileReference] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [airsyncbase:FileReference] element.
[In Alias] The Alias element is used in the following command responses: § Find command responses (section 2.2.1.2) § Search command responses (section 2.2.1.16)
[In Alias] The definition of the Alias element differs according to the context in which it[Alias element] is used.
[In Alias] For more details, see section 2.2.3.9.1 and section 2.2.3.9.2.
[In Alias (Find)] The Alias element in the GAL namespace is an optional child element of the find:Properties element in Find command responses.
[In Alias (Find)] The Alias element is only present in response to Find command requests that contain the GALSearchCriterion element as specified in section 2.2.3.82.
[In Alias (Find)] It[Alias element] contains the alias of a recipient in the GAL that matched the search criteria from the corresponding Find command request.
[In Alias (Find)] Element Alias in Find command response (section 2.2.1.2), the parent element is Properties (section 2.2.3.139.1).
[In Alias (Find)] None [Element Alias in Find command response (section 2.2.1.2) has no child element.]
[In Alias (Find)] Element Alias in Find command response (section 2.2.1.2), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7).
[In Alias (Find)] Element Alias in Find command response (section 2.2.1.2), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In Alias (Find)] Protocol version 12.1 does not supports this [Alias] element.
[In Alias (Find)] Protocol version 14.0 does not supports this [Alias] element.
[In Alias (Find)] Protocol version 14.1 does not supports this [Alias] element.
[In Alias (Find)] Protocol version 16.0 does not supports this [Alias] element.
[In Alias (Find)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Alias] element.
[In Alias (Search)] The Alias element in the GAL namespace is an optional child element of the search:Properties element in Search command responses.
[In Alias (Search)] The Alias element is only present in response to Search command requests that contain a search:Name element with a value of "GAL", as specified in section 2.2.3.114.2.
[In Alias (Search)] It [Alias element] contains the alias of a recipient in the GAL that matched the search criteria from the corresponding Search command request.
[In Alias (Search)] Element Alias in Search command response (section 2.2.2.15), the parent element is Properties (section 2.2.3.132.2).
[In Alias (Search)] None [Element Alias in Search command response (section 2.2.2.15) has no child element.]
[In Alias (Search)] Element Alias in Search command response (section 2.2.2.15), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7).
[In Alias (Search)] Element Alias in Search command response (section 2.2.2.15), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In Alias (Search)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Alias] element.
[In Alias (Search)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Alias] element.
[In Alias (Search)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Alias] element.
[In Alias (Search)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Alias] element.
[In Alias (Search)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Alias] element.
[In And] The And element is an optional child element of the Query element in Search command requests.
[In And] It [And element] contains elements that specify items on which to perform an AND operation.
[In And] Elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.10] are defined in the Search namespace, except where otherwise indicated by the presence of a namespace prefix (as defined in section 2.2.1).
[In And] Element And in Search command request (section 2.2.2.15), the parent element is Query (section 2.2.3.133).

[In And] Element And in Search command request (section 2.2.2.15), the child elements are FreeText (section 2.2.3.77) , airsync:Class (section 2.2.3.27.4), airsync:CollectionId (section2.2.3.30.4), ConversationId (section 2.2.3.35.2) , GreaterThan (section 2.2.3.82), LessThan (section 2.2.3.91).
[In And] Element And in Search command request (section 2.2.2.15), the data type is container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2).
[In And] Element And in Search command request (section 2.2.2.15), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In And] If multiple And elements are included in the request, the server responds with a Status element (section 2.2.3.167.12) value of 8 (SearchTooComplex).
[In And] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [And] element.
[In And] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [And] element.
[In And] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [And] element.
[In And] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [And] element.
[In And] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [And] element.
[In ApplicationData] The ApplicationData element is a required child element of the Change element and the Add element in Sync command requests.
[In ApplicationData] The ApplicationData element is a required child element of the Change element, the Add element, and the Fetch element in Sync command responses.
[In ApplicationData] It [ApplicationData element] contains data for a particular object, such as a contact, email message, calendar appointment, or task item.
[In ApplicationData] The ApplicationData element can be used to change items, add items, or fetch items on the client device or server.
[In ApplicationData] The format of this data [ApplicationData] is determined by the schema for the object.

[In ApplicationData] Elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.11] are defined in the AirSync namespace, except where otherwise indicated by the presence of a namespace prefix (as defined in section 2.2.1).
[In ApplicationData] Element ApplicationData in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.20), the parent elements are Change (section 2.2.3.24), Add (section 2.2.3.7.2).
[In ApplicationData] Element ApplicationData in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.20), the child elements are Data elements from the content classes.
[In ApplicationData] For details about the content classes, see [MS-ASCAL], [MS-ASCNTC], [MS-ASEMAIL], [MS-ASMS], and [MS-ASTASK].
[In ApplicationData] Element ApplicationData in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.20), the data type is container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2).
[In ApplicationData] Element ApplicationData in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.20), the number allowed is 1…1 (required).
[In ApplicationData] Element ApplicationData in Sync command response, the parent elements are Change (section 2.2.3.24), Add (section 2.2.3.7.2).
[In ApplicationData] Element ApplicationData in Sync command response, the child elements contain Data elements from the content classes.
[In ApplicationData] For details about the content classes, see [MS-ASCAL], [MS-ASCNTC], [MS-ASEMAIL], [MS-ASMS], and [MS-ASTASK].

[In ApplicationData] Element ApplicationData in Sync command response, the child element contains airsyncbase:Body (MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.9), airsyncbase:BodyPart ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.10), airsyncbase:NativeBodyType ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.32), rm:RightsManagementLicense ([MS-ASRM] section 2.2.2.14).
[In ApplicationData] Element ApplicationData in Sync command response, the data type is container.
[In ApplicationData] Element ApplicationData in Sync command response, the number allowed is 1…1 (required).
[In ApplicationData] Element ApplicationData in Sync command response, the parent element is Fetch (section 2.2.3.63.2)

[In ApplicationData] Element ApplicationData in Sync command response, the child elements are airsyncbase:Attachments ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.28), airsyncbase:Body ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.4), airsyncbase:NativeBodyType, rm:RightsManagementLicense.
[In ApplicationData] Element ApplicationData in Sync command response, the child elements contain Data elements from the content classes.
[In ApplicationData] For details about the content classes, see [MS-ASCAL], [MS-ASCNTC], [MS-ASDOC], [MS-ASEMAIL], [MS-ASMS], and [MS-ASTASK].

[In AppliesToExternalKnown] The AppliesToExternalKnown element is an optional child element of the OofMessage element in Settings command requests and responses that indicates that the OOF message applies to known external users.
[In AppliesToExternalKnown] A known external user is a user who is outside the sending user's organization, but is represented in the sending user's contacts.
[In AppliesToExternalKnown] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.12] are defined in the Settings namespace.

[In AppliesToExternalKnown] The AppliesToExternalKnown element is an empty tag element, meaning it [AppliesToExternalKnown element] has no value or data type.
[In AppliesToExternalKnown] It [AppliesToExternalKnown element] is distinguished only by the presence or absence of the <AppliesToExternalKnown/> tag.

[In AppliesToExternalKnown] When the AppliesToExternalKnown element is present, its [AppliesToExternalKnown's] peer elements (that is, the other elements within the OofMessage element) specify the OOF settings with regard to known external users.

[In AppliesToExternalKnown] The following are the peer elements of the AppliesToExternalKnown element: Enabled (section 2.2.3.56)-Specifies whether an OOF message is sent to this audience while the sending user is OOF.
[In AppliesToExternalKnown] [The following are the peer elements of the AppliesToExternalKnown element:] ReplyMessage (section 2.2.3.140)-Specifies the OOF reply message.
[In AppliesToExternalKnown] [The following are the peer elements of the AppliesToExternalKnown element:] BodyType (section 2.2.3.17)-Specifies the format of the OOF message.

[In Availability] The Availability element is an optional child element of the Options element in ResolveRecipients command requests that indicates to the server that free/busy data is being requested by the client and identifies the start time and end time of the free/busy data to retrieve.

[In Availability] The Availability element is an optional child element of the Recipient element in ResolveRecipient command responses that returns the status and free/busy data of the users or distribution lists identified in the request for the time identified by the StartTime and EndTime elements.
[In Availability] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.16] are defined in the ResolveRecipients namespace.
[In Availability] Element Availability in ResolveRecipients command request (section 2.2.2.14), the parent element is Options (section 2.2.3.119.3).
[In Availability] Element Availability in ResolveRecipients command request (section 2.2.2.14), the child elements are StartTime (section 2.2.3.166.1), EndTime (section 2.2.3.58.1).
[In Availability] Element Availability in ResolveRecipients command request (section 2.2.2.14), the data type is container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2).
[In Availability] Element Availability in ResolveRecipients command request (section 2.2.2.14), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In Availability] Element Availability in ResolveRecipients command response, the parent element is Recipient (section 2.2.3.136).
[In Availability] Element Availability in ResolveRecipients command response, the child elements are Status (section 2.2.3.167.11), MergedFreeBusy (section 2.2.3.101).
[In Availability] Element Availability in ResolveRecipients command response, the data type is container.
[In Availability] Element Availability in ResolveRecipients command response, the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).

[In Availability] When the Availability element is included in a ResolveRecipients request, the server retrieves free/busy information for the users identified in the To elements included in the request, and returns the free/busy information in the MergedFreeBusy element in the response.
[In Availability] If the Availability element is included in the ResolveRecipients request, the request MUST also include a valid StartTime element value and EndTime element value.

[In Availability] When the server parses the request, the server first resolves the recipients identified by the To elements, and then determines the users free/busy information for the specified time span, before returning the free/busy data in the MergedFreeBusy element.
[In Availability] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [Availability] element.
[In Availability] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Availability] element.
[In Availability] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Availability] element.
[In Availability] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Availability] element.
[In Availability] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Availability] element.

[In BodyType] In all contexts, it [BodyType element] specifies the format of the OOF message.

[In BodyType] [Element BodyType in Settings command Oof response, the number allowed is 1…1 (required) if a ReplyMessage element is present]; otherwise, [the number allowed is ] 0…1 (optional).
[In BodyType] The following are the permitted values for the BodyType element: Text , HTML.
[In BodyType] If the BodyType element has the value "HTML", all message strings are sent in the HTML format.
[In BodyType] If the BodyType element has the value "Text", the message strings are sent in plain text.
[In BodyType] Because there is no default value, the BodyType element MUST be present (with a non-NULL value) in a Settings command Oof Get operation request.
[In BodyType] [The BodyType element ] MUST be present (with a non-NULL value) in a Settings command Oof Set operation request if the ReplyMessage element (section 2.2.3.140) has been set.
[In BodyType] [The BodyType element ] MUST always be present (with a non-NULL value) in a Settings command Oof Get operation response if the ReplyMessage element is returned.

[In CalendarId] The CalendarId element is an optional child element of the Result element in MeetingResponse command responses that specifies the server ID of the calendar item.
[In CalendarId] The CalendarId element value can be up to 64 characters in length.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Partially verified by derived requirement: MS-ASCMD_R5868.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In CalendarId] The CalendarId element value is not larger than 64 characters in length.
[In CalendarId] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.18] are defined in the MeetingResponse namespace.
[In CalendarId] Element CalendarId in MeetingResponse command response (section 2.2.2.10), the parent element is Result (section 2.2.3.146.1).
[In CalendarId] None [Element CalendarId in MeetingResponse command response (section 2.2.2.10) has no child element.]
[In CalendarId] Element CalendarId in MeetingResponse command response (section 2.2.2.10), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7).
[In CalendarId] Element CalendarId in MeetingResponse command response (section 2.2.2.10), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In CalendarId] The CalendarId element is included in the MeetingResponse command response that is sent to the client if the meeting request was not declined.

[In CalendarId] If the meeting is accepted [or tentatively accepted], the server adds a new item to the calendar, if none is present, and returns the item's server ID in the CalendarId element in the response.

[In CalendarId] If the meeting is [accepted or] tentatively accepted, the server adds a new item to the calendar, if none is present and returns the item's server ID in the CalendarId element in the response.
[In CalendarId] If the client created a tentative meeting calendar item, the client updates that item with the new server ID.
[In CalendarId] The client also changes the busy status from tentative to busy.
[In CalendarId] When a meeting is accepted, the server also creates a new calendar item with the same server ID.

[In CalendarId] This [When a meeting is accepted, the server also creates a new calendar item with the same server ID] means there is a conflict that will be resolved the next time the calendar is synchronized.
[In CalendarId] If the meeting is declined, the response does not contain a CalendarId element.
[In CalendarId] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [CalendarId] element.
[In CalendarId] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [CalendarId] element.
[In CalendarId] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [CalendarId] element.
[In CalendarId] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [CalendarId] element.
[In CalendarId] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [CalendarId] element.

[In Certificate] The Certificate element is used in the following command requests and responses: ResolveRecipients command responses (section 2.2.2.13), ValidateCert command requests and responses (section 2.2.2.20).
[In Certificate] The definition of the Certificate element differs according to the context in which it [Certificate element] is used.
[In Certificate] For more details, see section 2.2.3.19.1 and section 2.2.3.19.2.

[In Certificate(ResolveRecipients)] The Certificate element is an optional child element of the Certificates element in ResolveRecipients command responses that contains the X509 certificate binary large object (BLOB) that is encoded with base64 encoding.
[In Certificate(ResolveRecipients)] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.19.1] are defined in the ResolveRecipients namespace.
[In Certificate(ResolveRecipients)] Element Certificate in ResolveRecipients command response (section 2.2.2.14), the parent element is Certificates (section 2.2.3.23.1).
[In Certificate(ResolveRecipients)] None [Element Certificate in ResolveRecipients command response (section 2.2.2.14) has no child element.]
[In Certificate(ResolveRecipients)] Element Certificate in ResolveRecipients command response (section 2.2.2.14), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7) (encoded with base64 encoding).
[In Certificate(ResolveRecipients)] Element Certificate in ResolveRecipients command response (section 2.2.2.14), the number allowed is 0...N (optional).

[In Certificate(ResolveRecipients)] This element [Certificate] is returned by the server only if the client specifies a value of 2 in the CertificateRetrieval element (section 2.2.3.22) in the ResolveRecipients command request.
[In Certificate(ResolveRecipients)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Certificate(ResolveRecipients)] element.
[In Certificate(ResolveRecipients)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Certificate(ResolveRecipients)] element.
[In Certificate(ResolveRecipients)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Certificate(ResolveRecipients)] element.
[In Certificate(ResolveRecipients)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Certificate(ResolveRecipients)] element.
[In Certificate(ResolveRecipients)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Certificate(ResolveRecipients)] element.

[In Certificate(ValidateCert)] The Certificate element is a required child element of the Certificates element and the CertificateChain element in ValidateCert command requests that contains the X509 certificate BLOB that is encoded with base64 encoding.

[In Certificate(ValidateCert)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Certificate(ValidateCert)] element.

[In CertificateCount] The CertificateCount element is an optional child element of the Certificates element in ResolveRecipients command responses that specifies the number of valid certificates that were found for the recipient.
[In CertificateCount] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.21] are defined in the ResolveRecipients namespace.
[In CertificateCount] Element CertificateCount in ResolveRecipients command response (section 2.2.2.14), the parent element is Certificates (section 2.2.3.23.1).

[In CertificateCount] If a Status element (section 2.2.3.167.11) value of 8 is returned with the Certificates element, the CertificateCount element specifies the number of recipient certificates that were not returned.
[In CertificateCount] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [CertificateCount] element.
[In CertificateCount] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [CertificateCount] element.

[In CertificateRetrieval] The CertificateRetrieval element is an optional child element of the Options element in ResolveRecipients command requests that specifies whether S/MIME certificates are returned by the server for each resolved recipient.
[In CertificateRetrieval] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.22] are defined in the ResolveRecipients namespace.
[In CertificateRetrieval] Element CertificateRetrieval in ResolveRecipients command request (section 2.2.2.14), the parent element is Options (section 2.2.3.119.3).
[In CertificateRetrieval] None [Element CertificateRetrieval in ResolveRecipients command request (section 2.2.2.14) has no child element.]
[In CertificateRetrieval] Element CertificateRetrieval in ResolveRecipients command request (section 2.2.2.14), the data type is integer ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6).
[In CertificateRetrieval] Element CertificateRetrieval in ResolveRecipients command request (section 2.2.2.14), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In CertificateRetrieval] The following table shows valid values [1, 2, 3] for the CertificateRetrieval element.
[In CertificateRetrieval] Value 1 means do not retrieve certificates for the recipient (default).
[In CertificateRetrieval] Value 2 means retrieve the full certificate for each resolved recipient.
[In CertificateRetrieval] Value 3 means retrieve the mini certificate for each resolved recipient.
[In CertificateRetrieval] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [CertificateRetrieval] element.
[In CertificateRetrieval] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [CertificateRetrieval] element.

[In CertificateRetrieval] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [CertificateRetrieval] element.
