[In DeepTraversal] The DeepTraversal element is used in the following command requests: § Find command requests (section 2.2.1.2) § Search command requests (section 2.2.1.16)
[In DeepTraversal] The definition of the DeepTraversal element differs according to the context in which it is used. For more details, see section 2.2.3.41.1 and section 2.2.3.41.2.

[In DeepTraversal (Find)] The DeepTraversal element is an optional child element of the Options element in Find command requests that indicates that the client wants the server to search all subfolders for the folder that is specified in the query.
[In DeepTraversal (Find)] All elements referenced in this section are defined in the Find namespace.
[In DeepTraversal (Find)] Element DeepTraversal in Find command request (section 2.2.1.2), the parent element is Options (section 2.2.3.125.1).
[In DeepTraversal (Find)] None [Element DeepTraversal in has no child element.]
[In DeepTraversal (Find)] None [Element DeepTraversal in Find command request (section 2.2.1.2), has no type.]
[In DeepTraversal (Find)] Element DeepTraversal in Find command request (section 2.2.1.2), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In DeepTraversal (Find)] The DeepTraversal element is not used in the Options element of the GALSearchCriterion element in the Find command request.
[In DeepTraversal (Find)] The DeepTraversal element is an empty tag element, meaning it has no value or data type.
[In DeepTraversal (Find)] It[DeepTraversal] is distinguished only by the presence or absence of the <DeepTraversal/> tag.
[In DeepTraversal (Find)] If the DeepTraversal element and the CollectionId element are not present, all folders returned in FolderSync and their subfolders will be searched.
[In DeepTraversal (Find)] If the DeepTraversal element and the CollectionId element are present, the folder specified by the CollectionId and all its subfolders are searched.
[In DeepTraversal (Find)] Protocol version 12.1 does not supports this [Find] element.
[In DeepTraversal (Find)] Protocol version 14.0 does not supports this [Find] element.
[In DeepTraversal (Find)] Protocol version 14.1 does not supports this [Find] element.
[In DeepTraversal (Find)] Protocol version 16.0 does not supports this [Find] element.
[In DeepTraversal (Find)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Find] element.
[In DeepTraversal (Search)] The DeepTraversal element is an optional child element of the Options element in Search command requests.
[In DeepTraversal (Search)] [The DeepTraversal element] indicates that the client wants the server to search all subfolders for the folders that are specified in the query.
[In DeepTraversal (Search)] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.41] are defined in the Search namespace.
[In DeepTraversal (Search)] Element DeepTraversal in Search command request (section 2.2.2.15), the parent element is Options (section 2.2.3.119.4).
[In DeepTraversal (Search) None [Element DeepTraversal in Search command request (section 2.2.2.15) has no child element.]
[In DeepTraversal (Search)] None [Element DeepTraversal in Search command request (section 2.2.2.15) has no type.]
[In DeepTraversal (Search)] Element DeepTraversal in Search command request (section 2.2.2.15), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In DeepTraversal (Search)] The result of including more than one DeepTraversal element in a Search command request is undefined.
[In DeepTraversal (Search)] The server MAY return a protocol status error in response to such a command request [more than one DeepTraversal element in a Search command request].
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirement: MS-ASCMD_R2143.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In DeepTraversal (Search)] The DeepTraversal element is an empty tag element, meaning it [DeepTraversal element] has no value or data type.
[In DeepTraversal (Search)] It [DeepTraversal element] is distinguished only by the presence or absence of the <DeepTraversal/> tag.
[In DeepTraversal (Search)] If the DeepTraversal element is not present, the subfolders are not searched.
[In DeepTraversal (Search)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [DeepTraversal] element.
[In DeepTraversal (Search)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [DeepTraversal] element.
[In DeepTraversal (Search)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [DeepTraversal] element.
[In DeepTraversal (Search)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [DeepTraversal] element.
[In DeepTraversal (Search)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [DeepTraversal] element.
[In Delete]The Delete element is used in the following command requests and responses: FolderSync command responses (section 2.2.2.4), Sync command requests and responses (section 2.2.2.19).
[In Delete] The definition of the Delete element differs according to the context in which it [Delete element] is used.
[In Delete] For more details, see section 2.2.3.42.1 and section 2.2.3.42.2.
[In Delete(FolderSync)] The Delete element is an optional child element of the Changes element in FolderSync command responses.
[In Delete(FolderSync)] [The Delete element] specifies that a folder on the server was deleted since the last folder synchronization.
[In Delete(FolderSync)] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.42.1] are defined in the FolderHierarchy namespace.
[In Delete(FolderSync)] Element Delete in FolderSync command response (section 2.2.2.4), the parent element is Changes (section 2.2.3.25).
[In Delete(FolderSync)] Element Delete in FolderSync command response (section 2.2.2.4), the child element is ServerId (section 2.2.3.156.3).
[In Delete(FolderSync)] Element Delete in FolderSync command response (section 2.2.2.4), the data type is container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2).
[In Delete(FolderSync)] Element Delete in FolderSync command response (section 2.2.2.4), the number allowed is 0...N (optional).
[In Delete(FolderSync)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Delete(FolderSync)] element.
[In Delete(FolderSync)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Delete(FolderSync)] element.
[In Delete(FolderSync)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Delete(FolderSync)] element.
[In Delete(FolderSync)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Delete(FolderSync)] element.
[In Delete(FolderSync)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Delete(FolderSync)] element.
[In Delete(Sync)] The Delete element is an optional child element of the Commands element in Sync command requests and responses that deletes an object on the client device or the server.
[In Delete(Sync)] The object [Delete] is identified by its ServerId element.
[In Delete(Sync)] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.42.2] are defined in the AirSync namespace.
[In Delete(Sync)] Element Delete in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.20), the parent element is Commands (section 2.2.3.32).
[In Delete(Sync)] Element Delete in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.20), the child element are ServerId (section 2.2.3.156.7), airsyncbase:InstanceId ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.25).
[In Delete(Sync)] Element Delete in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.20), the data type is container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2).
[In Delete(Sync)] Element Delete in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.20), the number allowed is 0...N (optional).
[In Delete(Sync)] Element Delete in Sync command response, the parent element is Commands.
[In Delete(Sync)] Element Delete in Sync command response, the child element is ServerId, Class (section 2.2.3.27.5).
[In Delete(Sync)] Element Delete in Sync command response, the data type is container.
[In Delete(Sync)] Element Delete in Sync command response, the number allowed is 0...N (optional).
[In Delete(Sync)] Element Delete in Sync command response, the parent element is Responses (section 2.2.3.145).
[In Delete(Sync)] Element Delete in Sync command response, the child element is ServerId, Status (section 2.2.3.167.16).
[In Delete(Sync)] Element Delete in Sync command response, the data type is container.
[In Delete(Sync)] Element Delete in Sync command response, the number allowed is 0...N (optional).
[In Delete(Sync)] The server is not required to send an individual response for every operation that is sent by the client.
[In Delete(Sync)] The client only receives responses for successful additions, successful fetches, successful changes that include an attachment being added, and failed changes and deletions.
[In Delete(Sync)] When the client does not receive a response, the client MUST assume that the operation succeeded unless informed otherwise.
[In Delete(Sync)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Delete(Sync)] element.
[In Delete(Sync)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Delete(Sync)] element.
[In Delete(Sync)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Delete(Sync)] element.
[In Delete(Sync)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Delete(Sync)] element.
[In Delete(Sync)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Delete(Sync)] element.
[In Delete(Sync)] The Delete element is not returned in the Sync response for an SMS deletion when protocol version 14.0 is used.

[In Delete(Sync)] When protocol version 16.0 is used and the object is a recurrence instance, the object is identified by both the ServerId element of the master item as well as the airsyncbase:InstanceId element of the specific occurrence.

[In DeletesAsMoves] The DeletesAsMoves element is an optional child element of the Collection element in Sync command requests that indicates that any deleted items SHOULD be moved to the Deleted Items folder.
[In DeletesAsMoves] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.43] are defined in the AirSync namespace.
[In DeletesAsMoves] Element DeletesAsMoves in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.20) , the parent element is Collection (section 2.2.3.29.2).
[In DeletesAsMoves] None [Element DeletesAsMoves in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.20) has no child element .]
[In DeletesAsMoves] Element DeletesAsMoves in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.20) , the data type is boolean ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.1).
[In DeletesAsMoves] Element DeletesAsMoves in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.20) , the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In DeletesAsMoves] The DeletesAsMoves element appears only in requests sent to the server from the client.
[In DeletesAsMoves] If the DeletesAsMoves element is set to false, the deletion is permanent.
[In DeletesAsMoves] If the client wants to permanently delete items, the request MUST include the DeletesAsMoves element with a value of 0 (FALSE).
[In DeletesAsMoves] A value of 1 (TRUE), which is the default, indicates that any deleted items are moved to the Deleted Items folder.
[In DeletesAsMoves] The default is assumed when the DeletesAsMoves element is either empty or not present.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirements: MS-ASCMD_R5874, MS-ASCMD_R5875.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In DeletesAsMoves] If element DeleteAsMoves is empty, the delete items are moved to the Deleted Items folder.
[In DeletesAsMoves] If element DeleteAsMoves is not present, the delete items are moved to the Deleted Items folder.
[In DeletesAsMoves] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [DeletesAsMoves] element.
[In DeletesAsMoves] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [DeletesAsMoves] element.
[In DeletesAsMoves] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [DeletesAsMoves] element.
[In DeletesAsMoves] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [DeletesAsMoves] element.
[In DeletesAsMoves] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [DeletesAsMoves] element.
[In DeleteSubFolders] The DeleteSubFolders element is an optional child element of the Options element in ItemOperations command requests for the EmptyFolderContents (section 2.2.3.55) operation.
[In DeleteSubFolders] It [DeleteSubFolders element] is a flag that indicates whether to delete the subfolders of the specified folder.
[In DeleteSubFolders] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.44] are defined in the ItemOperations namespace.
[In DeleteSubFolders] Element DeleteSubFolders in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.9) EmptyFolderContents operation, the parent element is Options (section 2.2.3.119.2).
[In DeleteSubFolders] None [Element DeleteSubFolders in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.9) EmptyFolderContents operation has no child element.]
[In DeleteSubFolders] None [Element DeleteSubFolders in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.9) EmptyFolderContents operation, the data type is None.]
[In DeleteSubFolders] Element DeleteSubFolders in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.9) EmptyFolderContents operation, the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In DeleteSubFolders] If the DeleteSubFolders element is not present in the request, the default behavior is to not delete subfolders.
[In DeleteSubFolders] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [DeleteSubFolders] element.
[In DeleteSubFolders] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [DeleteSubFolders] element.
[In DeleteSubFolders] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [DeleteSubFolders] element.
[In DeleteSubFolders] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [DeleteSubFolders] element.
[In DeleteSubFolders] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [DeleteSubFolders] element.
[In DeviceInformation] The DeviceInformation element is an optional child element of the Settings element in Settings command requests and responses.
[In DeviceInformation] [The DeviceInformation element is] an optional child element of the Provision element in Provision command requests.
[In DeviceInformation] In Settings and Provision command requests, it [DeviceInformation element] is a container node that is used for sending the client device's properties to the server.
[In DeviceInformation] In Settings command responses, it [DeviceInformation element] is a container node that is used to return the status of the request.
[In DeviceInformation] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.45] are defined in the Settings namespace.
[In DeviceInformation] Element DeviceInformation in Settings command request (section 2.2.2.17), the parent element is Settings (section 2.2.3.158.2).
[In DeviceInformation] Element DeviceInformation in Settings command request (section 2.2.2.17), the child element is Set (section 2.2.3.157).
[In DeviceInformation] Element DeviceInformation in Settings command request (section 2.2.2.17), the data type is container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2).
[In DeviceInformation] Element DeviceInformation in Settings command request (section 2.2.2.17), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In DeviceInformation] Element DeviceInformation in Settings command response, the parent element is Settings.
[In DeviceInformation] Element DeviceInformation in Settings command response, the child element is Status (section 2.2.3.167.14).
[In DeviceInformation] Element DeviceInformation in Settings command response, the data type is container.
[In DeviceInformation] Element DeviceInformation in Settings command response, the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In DeviceInformation] Element DeviceInformation in Provision command request ([MS-ASPROV] section 2.2), the parent element is Provision ([MS-ASPROV] section 2.2.2.43).
[In DeviceInformation] Element DeviceInformation in Provision command request ([MS-ASPROV] section 2.2), the child element is Set.
[In DeviceInformation] Element DeviceInformation in Provision command request ([MS-ASPROV] section 2.2), the data type is container.
[In DeviceInformation] Element DeviceInformation in Provision command request ([MS-ASPROV] section 2.2), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In DeviceInformation] If the protocol version is not 14.1, the client uses the Settings command to send DeviceInformation to the server, as specified in section 3.1.5.2.

[In DeviceInformation] When the Settings command (section 2.2.2.16) is used to send the DeviceInformation element, it sends the following information about a client device to the server: Device model , International Mobile Equipment Identity (IMEI) , Device friendly name , Device operating system , Telephone number , Device operating system language , User Agent , Whether to enable outbound SMS (see [MS-ASMS]) , Mobile operator name
[In DeviceInformation] The device information is represented as a list of settings under the DeviceInformation node in the Settings command.
[In DeviceInformation] The DeviceInformation element has only one child element, Set, which contains the list of device information items in the request and the status in the response.
[In DeviceInformation] The DeviceInformation element supports only the Set element because this information is write-only from the device.
[In DeviceInformation] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [DeviceInformation] command [as a child element of] Settings.
[In DeviceInformation] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [DeviceInformation] command [as a child element of] Settings.
[In DeviceInformation] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [DeviceInformation] element.
[In DeviceInformation] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [DeviceInformation] element.
[In DeviceInformation] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [DeviceInformation] element.
[In ] When protocol version 14.1 or 16.0 is used, the DeviceInformation element MUST be present as a child element of the Provision element in the initial Provision command request.
[In ] When protocol version 14.0, 12.1, or 12.0 is used, the DeviceInformation element MUST NOT be present as a child element of the Provision element in the initial Provision command request.
[In ] In this case, the client uses the Settings command to send the device's properties to the server.
[In DevicePassword] The DevicePassword element is an optional child element of the Settings element in Settings command requests and responses.
[In DevicePassword] In Settings command requests, the DevicePassword element is a container node that is used to send the recovery password of the client device to the server
[In DevicePassword] In Settings command responses, the DevicePassword element is a container node that is used to specify the status of the Settings command DevicePassword Set operation.
[In DevicePassword] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.46] are defined in the Settings namespace.
[In DevicePassword] Element DevicePassword in Settings command request (section 2.2.2.17),the parent element is Settings (section 2.2.3.158.2).
[In DevicePassword] Element DevicePassword in Settings command request (section 2.2.2.17), the child element is Set (section 2.2.3.157).
[In DevicePassword] Element DevicePassword in Settings command request (section 2.2.2.17), the data type is container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2).
[In DevicePassword] Element DevicePassword in Settings command request (section 2.2.2.17), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In DevicePassword] Element DevicePassword in Settings command response, the parent element is Settings.
[In DevicePassword] Element DevicePassword in Settings command response, the child element is Status (section 2.2.3.167.14).
[In DevicePassword] Element DevicePassword in Settings command response, the data type is container.
[In DevicePassword] Element DevicePassword in Settings command response, the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In DevicePassword] Clients use the Set operation within the DevicePassword element to enable the device to send or store a recovery password on the server.
[In DevicePassword] The recovery password is stored in the user's mailbox.
[In DevicePassword] The recovery password can be retrieved by the administrator or the end-user if the user forgets his or her password.
[In DevicePassword] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [DevicePassword] element.
[In DevicePassword] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [DevicePassword] element.
[In DevicePassword] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [DevicePassword] element.
[In DevicePassword] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [DevicePassword] element.
[In DevicePassword] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [DevicePassword] element.

[In DisplayBcc] The DisplayBcc element is an optional child element of the Properties element in Find command responses that specifies the blind carbon copy (Bcc) recipients of an email as displayed to the user.
[In DisplayBcc] The value of this element contains one or more display names.
[In DisplayBcc] If there are multiple display names, they are separated by semi-colons.
[In DisplayBcc] All elements referenced in this section are defined in the Find namespace.

[In DisplayBcc] Protocol version 16.0 does not supports this [DisplayBcc] element.
[In DisplayBcc] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [DisplayBcc] element.

[In DisplayName]The DisplayName element is used in the following command requests and responses: Autodiscover command responses (section 2.2.2.1), FolderCreate command requests (section 2.2.2.2), FolderSync command responses (section 2.2.2.4), FolderUpdate command requests (section 2.2.2.5), ResolveRecipients command responses (section 2.2.2.13), Search command responses (section 2.2.2.14).

[In DisplayName(Autodiscover)] The DisplayName element is an optional child element of the User element in Autodiscover command responses that contains the user's display name in the directory service.

[In DisplayName(Autodiscover)] Element DisplayName in Autodiscover command response (section 2.2.2.1), the parent element is User (section 2.2.3.179).

[In DisplayName(Autodiscover)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [DisplayName(Autodiscover)] element.
[In DisplayName(Autodiscover)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [DisplayName(Autodiscover)] element.

[In DisplayName (Find)] The DisplayName element in the GAL namespace is an optional child element of the find:Properties element in Find command responses.
[In DisplayName (Find)] It[DisplayName] contains the display name of a recipient in the GAL that matched the search criteria from the corresponding Find command request.

[In EMailAddress] The primary email address is the address that appears on the From line when a user sends an email message.
[In EMailAddress] This [the primary email] address can be the same as the email address that was sent in the request.
[In EMailAddress] The client device SHOULD record the address returned by the Autodiscover command response.

[In EmptyFolderContents] The EmptyFolderContents element is an optional child element of the ItemOperations element in ItemOperations command requests and an optional child element of the Response element in ItemOperations responses.
[In EmptyFolderContents] In both contexts, the EmptyFolderContents element identifies the body of the request or response as containing the operation that deletes the contents of a folder.

[In EmptyFolderContents] Elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.55] are defined in the ItemOperations namespace, except where otherwise indicated by the presence of a namespace prefix (as defined in section 2.2.1).
[In EmptyFolderContents] Element EmptyFolderContents in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8), the parent element is ItemOperations (section 2.2.3.85).

[In EmptyFolderContents] Element EmptyFolderContents in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8), the child elements are airsync:CollectionId (section 2.2.3.30.2), Options (section 2.2.3.115.2).
[In EmptyFolderContents] Element EmptyFolderContents in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8), the data type is container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2).
[In EmptyFolderContents] Element EmptyFolderContents in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8), the number allowed is 0...N (optional).
[In EmptyFolderContents] Element EmptyFolderContents in ItemOperations command response, the parent element is Response (section 2.2.3.140.3).
[In EmptyFolderContents] Element EmptyFolderContents in ItemOperations command response, the child elements are airsync:CollectionId (section 2.2.3.30.2) ,Status (section 2.2.3.162.7).
[In EmptyFolderContents] Element EmptyFolderContents in ItemOperations command response, the data type is container.
[In EmptyFolderContents] Element EmptyFolderContents in ItemOperations command response, the number allowed is 0...N (optional).
[In EmptyFolderContents] The EmptyFolderContents element enables the client to empty a folder of all its items.

[In EmptyFolderContents] The element supports a single child element of the Options element, the DeleteSubFolders element (section 2.2.3.44), which determines whether subfolders contained in the folder are deleted.
[In EmptyFolderContents] If the DeleteSubFolders option is not included in the request, the subfolders of the specified airsync:CollectionId are not deleted.
[In EmptyFolderContents] Specifically, clients use EmptyFolderContents to empty the Deleted Items folder.
[In EmptyFolderContents] The client can clear out all items in the Deleted Items folder when the user runs out of storage quota (indicated by the return of an HTTP 507 status code from the server).
[In EmptyFolderContents] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [EmptyFolderContents] element.
[In EmptyFolderContents] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [EmptyFolderContents] element.
[In EmptyFolderContents] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [EmptyFolderContents] element.
[In EmptyFolderContents] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [EmptyFolderContents] element.
[In EmptyFolderContents] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [EmptyFolderContents] element.

[In EndTime]The EndTime element is used in the following command requests and responses: ResolveRecipients command requests (section 2.2.2.13), Settings command requests and responses (section 2.2.2.16).
[In EndTime] The definition of the EndTime element differs according to the context in which it [EndTime element] is used.
[In EndTime] For more details, see section 2.2.3.58.1 and section 2.2.3.58.2.

[In EndTime(ResolveRecipients)] The EndTime element is an optional child element of the Availability element in ResolveRecipients command requests that identifies the end of the span of free/busy time requested by the client.<36>
[In EndTime(ResolveRecipients)] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.58.1] are defined in the ResolveRecipients namespace.
[In EndTime(ResolveRecipients)] Element EndTime in ResolveRecipients command request (section 2.2.2.13), the parent element is Availability (section 2.2.3.16).
[In EndTime(ResolveRecipients)] None [Element EndTime in ResolveRecipients command request (section 2.2.2.13) has no child element.]
[In EndTime(ResolveRecipients)] Element EndTime in ResolveRecipients command request (section 2.2.2.13), the data type is datetime ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.3).
[In EndTime(ResolveRecipients)] Element EndTime in ResolveRecipients command request (section 2.2.2.13), the number allowed is 0…N (optional).
[In EndTime(ResolveRecipients)] If the Availability element is included in the request, the request MUST also include the StartTime (section 2.2.3.161.1) element.

[In EndTime(ResolveRecipients)] If the client sends an invalid EndTime element value, then the server returns a Status element (section 2.2.3.162.11) value of 5 in the ResolveRecipients command response.
[In EndTime(ResolveRecipients)] If no EndTime element is included in an Availablity request, the server uses a default end time value of seven days after the StartTime value.

[In EndTime(ResolveRecipients)] If the EndTime element value specified in the request is smaller than the StartTime element value plus 30 minutes,[ or the duration spanned by the StartTime element value and the EndTime element value is greater than a specific number<37> of days,] then the server returns a Status element value of 5 in the ResolveRecipients command response.

[In EndTime] If [the EndTime element value specified in the request is smaller than the StartTime element value plus 30 minutes, or] the duration spanned by the StartTime element value and the EndTime element value is greater than a specific number<6> of days, then the server returns a Status element value of 5 in the ResolveRecipients command response.

[In Error] Element Error in Autodiscover command response (section 2.2.2.1), the parent element is Action (section 2.2.3.6).

[In Error] Element Error in Autodiscover command response, the parent element is Response (section 2.2.3.140.1).
[In Error] Element Error in Autodiscover command response, the child elements are ErrorCode, Message, DebugData.
[In Error] Element Error in Autodiscover command response, the data type is container.
[In Error] Element Error in Autodiscover command response, the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In Error] When the Error element is a child of the Response element, it has two optional attributes [Time, Id] as specified in the following table.
[In Error] The value of the attribute Time is a string that represents the time of day in that the request that generated the response was submitted.
[In Error] The format of this string [value of attribute Time] follows the Augmented Backus-Naur Form (ABNF) syntax specified below.
[In Error] The value of the attribute Id is an unsigned integer that uniquely identifies the server (within its domain) that generated the response.
[In Error] The value of the Time attribute is specified here using ABNF syntax, as specified in [RFC5234].

[In Error] [The ABNF syntax of the value of the Time attribute is] time_val = hours ":" minutes ":" seconds ["." fractional_seconds]
hours = 2*DIGIT ; 00 - 23, representing a 24-hour clock minutes = 2*DIGIT ; 00 - 59 seconds = 2*DIGIT ; 00 - 59 fractional_seconds = 7*DIGIT ; fractional seconds, always to 7 decimal places
[In Error] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Error] element.
[In Error] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Error] element.
[In Error] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Error] element.

[In Error] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Error] element.

[In ErrorCode] Element ErrorCode in Autodiscover command response (section 2.2.2.1), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In ErrorCode] If the provider cannot be found, [or if the AcceptableResponseSchema element (section 2.2.3.1) value cannot be matched,] then the ErrorCode element is included in the command response.
[In ErrorCode] [If the provider cannot be found, or ]if the AcceptableResponseSchema element (section 2.2.3.1) value cannot be matched, then the ErrorCode element is included in the command response.
[In ErrorCode] A value of 600 means an invalid request was sent to the server.
[In ErrorCode] A value of 601 means that a provider could not be found to handle the AcceptableResponseSchema element value that was specified.

[In Fetch] The Fetch element is used in the following command requests and responses: ItemOperations command requests and responses (section 2.2.2.8) , Sync command requests and responses (section 2.2.2.19).
[In Fetch] The definition of the Fetch element differs according to the context in which it [Fetch element] is used.
[In Fetch] For more details, see section 2.2.3.63.1 and section 2.2.3.63.2.

[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] The Fetch element is an optional child element of the ItemOperations element in ItemOperations command requests and an optional child element of the Response element in ItemOperations responses.
[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] In both contexts, it [Fetch element] retrieves an item from the server.

[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] Elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.63.1] are defined in the ItemOperations namespace, except where otherwise indicated by the presence of a namespace prefix (as defined in section 2.2.1).
[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] Element Fetch in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8), the parent element is ItemOperations (section 2.2.3.85).

[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] Element Fetch in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8), the child elements are Store (section 2.2.3.163.1), documentlibrary:LinkId (section 2.2.3.48) (optional), search:LongId (section 2.2.3.89.1) (optional), airsync:CollectionId (optional) (section 2.2.3.30.2), airsync:ServerId (optional) (section 2.2.3.151.5), Options (optional) (section 2.2.3.115.2), airsyncbase:FileReference (optional) (section 2.2.3.8), rm:RemoveRightsManagementProtection ([MS-ASRM] section 2.2.2.11).
[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] Element Fetch in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8), the data type is container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2).
[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] Element Fetch in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8), the number allowed is 0...N (optional).
[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] Element Fetch in ItemOperations command response, the parent element is Response (section 2.2.3.140.3).

[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] Element Fetch in ItemOperations command response, the child elements are documentlibrary:LinkId (optional), search:LongId (optional), airsync:CollectionId (optional), airsync:ServerId (optional), Status (section 2.2.3.162.7), airsync:Class(optional) (section 2.2.3.27.2), Properties(optional) (section 2.2.3.128.1).
[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] Element Fetch in ItemOperations command response, the data type is container.
[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] Element Fetch in ItemOperations command response, the number allowed is 0...N (optional).
[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] The fetch operation is intended to be used on Windows SharePoint Services technology [or UNC document metadata, search results, and items and attachments].
[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] The Fetch operation is intended to be used on [Windows SharePoint Services technology or] UNC document metadata, search results, and items and attachments.

[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] Because the ItemOperations response potentially contains large amounts of binary data, this protocol [MS-ASCMD] enables the client to choose a delivery method that is most efficient for its implementation by providing the following two methods to deliver content that is requested by the Fetch element: Inline-The binary content is encoded with base64 encoding and is included inside the WBXML.

[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] [Because the ItemOperations response potentially contains large amounts of binary data, this protocol [MS-ASCMD] enables the client to choose a delivery method that is most efficient for its implementation by providing the following two methods to deliver content that is requested by the Fetch element:] Multipart-This method involves a multipart structure in which the WBXML is the first part, and the requested data populates the subsequent parts.
[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] This format [Multipart] enables a client to handle large files without consuming large amounts of memory.
[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] The inline approach generally requires the client to read the WBXML part into memory in order to parse it, thereby consuming a large amount of memory.

[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] The multipart approach enables the client to parse the small WBXML part , obtain references to the binary parts, and handle the binary parts as necessary, without reading the whole response into memory.
[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] In the request, the client specifies the location and a byte range for the item.

[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] The location is indicated by either a link ID (documentlibrary:LinkId element) if the target item is identified by a URI , or a file reference (airsyncbase:FileReference element (section 2.2.3.8)) if the client is retrieving an email attachment.
[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] The location is indicated by a server ID (airsync:ServerId element) if an ActiveSync ID is being used to identify the item.
[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] The Fetch element supports several options, such as byte ranges, body preference, and schema, as specified in section 2.2.3.115.2.
[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] The ItemOperations command response contains either the requested byte range of the item , or an error code that indicates why the fetch failed.
[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] Multiple fetch operations can be included within one ItemOperations request.
[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] In this case [Multiple Fetch operations can be included within one ItemOperations request], the fetch operations are executed in the order that is specified.
[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] For more information about the Fetch element, see section 2.2.2.8.1.
[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Fetch(ItemOperations)] element.
[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Fetch(ItemOperations)] element.
[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Fetch(ItemOperations)] element.
[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Fetch(ItemOperations)] element.
[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Fetch(ItemOperations)] element.
[In Fetch(Sync)] The Fetch element is an optional child element of the Commands element in Sync command requests and an optional child element of the Responses element in Sync command responses.
[In Fetch(Sync)] In a request, the Fetch element is used to request the application data of an item that was truncated in a synchronization response from the server.
[In Fetch(Sync)] The complete item is then returned to the client in a server response.
[In Fetch(Sync)] The ItemOperations command (section 2.2.2.8) is the preferred way to fetch items.
[In Fetch(Sync)] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.63.2] are defined in the AirSync namespace.
[In Fetch(Sync)] Element Fetch in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.19), the parent element is Commands (section 2.2.3.32).
[In Fetch(Sync)] Element Fetch in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.19), the child element is ServerId (section 2.2.3.151.6).
[In Fetch(Sync)] Element Fetch in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.19), the data type is container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2).
[In Fetch(ItemOperations)] Element Fetch in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.19), the number allowed is 0...N (optional).

[In FilterType] The FilterType element is used in the following command requests: GetItemEstimate command requests (section 2.2.2.7), Sync command requests (section 2.2.2.19).
[In FilterType] The definition of the FilterType element differs according to the context in which it [FilterType element] is used.
[In FilterType] For more details, see section 2.2.3.64.1 and section 2.2.3.64.2.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] The airsync:FilterType element is an optional child element of the airsync:Options element and the Collection element in GetItemEstimate command requests.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] In both contexts, it [FilterType element] specifies a time window for the objects sent from the server to the client.

[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.64.1] are defined in the GetItemEstimate namespace, except where otherwise indicated by the presence of a namespace prefix (as defined in section 2.2.1).

[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Element FilterType in GetItemEstimate command request (section 2.2.2.7.1), the parent elements are airsync:Options (section 2.2.3.115.1), Collection (section 2.2.3.29.1)<38>.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] None [Element FilterType in GetItemEstimate command request (section 2.2.2.7) has no child element.]
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Element FilterType in GetItemEstimate command request (section 2.2.2.7), the data type is integer ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.5).
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Element FilterType in GetItemEstimate command request (section 2.2.2.7), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] The airsync:FilterType element applies to email, calendar, and task collections.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] If a filter type is specified, then the server sends an estimate of the items within the filter specifications.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] If the airsync:FilterType element is present in the request, then the server manages objects on the client to maintain the specified time window.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] New objects are added to the client when they are within the time window.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] The start time of the time window is determined by subtracting the period of time represented by the value of the FilterType element from the current time.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Any items that are dated between the start time of the window and the current time are considered within the time window.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] For example, if the value of the FilterType element is 2, then the start time of the time window is three days prior to the current time.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] If the airsync:FilterType element is omitted, then all objects are sent from the server.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Calendar items that are in the future [or that have recurrence, but no end date], are sent to the client regardless of the airsync:FilterType element value.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Calendar items [that are in the future or] that have recurrence, but no end date, are sent to the client regardless of the airsync:FilterType element value.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] The airsync:FilterType element does not support contact collections.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] However, if the airsync:FilterType element is included in a GetItemEstimate request for a contact collection, no error is returned.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] The valid values [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, ] for each collections type are listed in the following table.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Value 0 means No filter
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Yes. [Applies to email, if FilterType is 0, Status element value is 1.]
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Yes. [Applies to calendar, if FilterType is 0, Status element value is 1.]
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Yes. [Applies to tasks, if FilterType is 0, Status element value is 1.]
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Value 1 means 1 day.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Yes. [Applies to email, if FilterType is 1, Status element value is 1.]
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] No, [Applies to calendar, if FilterType is 1,] Status element (section 2.2.3.162.6) value is 110.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] No, [Applies to tasks, if FilterType is 1, ] Status element value is 110.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Value 2 means 3 days.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Yes. [Applies to email, if FilterType is 2, Status element value is 1.]
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] No, [Applies to calendar, if FilterType is 2,] Status element value is 110.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] No, [In FilterType] No, [Applies to tasks, if FilterType is 2, ] Status element value is 110.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Value 3 means 1 week.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Yes. [Applies to email, if FilterType is 3, Status element value is 1.]
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] No, [Applies to calendar, if FilterType is 3,] Status element value is 110.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] No, [In FilterType] No, [Applies to tasks, if FilterType is 3, ] Status element value is 110.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Value 4 means 2 weeks.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Yes. [Applies to email, if FilterType is 4, Status element value is 1.]
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Yes. [Applies to calendar, if FilterType is 4, Status element value 1]
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] No, [Applies to tasks, if FilterType is 4, ] Status element value is 110.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Value 5 means 1 month.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Yes. [Applies to email, if FilterType is 5, Status element value is 1.]
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Yes. [Applies to calendar, if FilterType is 5, Status element value is 1.]
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] No, [Applies to tasks, if FilterType is 5, ]Status element value 110
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Value 6 means 3 months.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] No,[Applies to email, if FilterType is 6,] Status element value 110
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Yes. [Applies to calendar, if FilterType is 6, Status element value 1]
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] No, [Applies to tasks, if FilterType is 6, ] Status element value is 110.
[In FilterType] Value 7 means 6 months.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] No, [Applies to email, if FilterType is 7,] Status element value 110
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Yes. [Applies to calendar, if FilterType is 7, Status element value is 1.]
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] No, [Applies to tasks, if FilterType is 7, ] Status element value is 110.
[In FilterType] Value 8 means Incomplete tasks.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] No, [Applies to email, if FilterType is 8,] Status element value is 110.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] No, [Applies to calendar, if FilterType is 8,] Status element value is 110.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Yes. [Applies to tasks, if FilterType is 8, Status element value is 1.]

[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Specifying a airsync:FilterType of 9 or above for when the CollectionId element (section 2.2.3.30.1) identifies any email, contact, calendar or task collection results in a Status element value of 103.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] element [as] child of Collection.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] element [as] child of airsync:Options.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] element [as] child of airsync:Options.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] element [as] child of airsync:Options.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] element [as] child of airsync:Options.
[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] The FilterType element is a required child element of the Collection element when protocol version 2.5, 12.0, or 12.1 is used;

[In FilterType(GetItemEstimate)] [The FilterType element is a required child element of the Collection element when protocol version 2.5, 12.0, or 12.1 is used; ] the FilterType element is an optional child element of the airsync:Options element when protocol version 14.0, 14.1, 16.0 or 16.1 is used.

[In FilterType(Sync)] The FilterType element is an optional child element of the Options element in Sync command requests that specifies an optional time window for the objects that are sent from the server to the client.
[In FilterType(Sync)] It [FilterType element] applies to email and calendar collections.
[In FilterType(Sync)] If a FilterType element is specified, the server sends only objects that are dated within the specified time window.
[In FilterType(Sync)] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.6.64.2] are defined in the AirSync namespace.
[In FilterType(Sync)] Element FilterType in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.19), the parent element is Options (section 2.2.3.115.5).
[In FilterType(Sync)] None [Element FilterType in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.19) has no child element.]
[In FilterType(Sync)] Element FilterType in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.19), the data type is unsignedByte ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7).
[In FilterType(Sync)]Element FilterType in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.19), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In FilterType(Sync)] The following table lists valid values [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8] for the [FilterType] element.
[In FilterType(Sync)] Value 0 means No filter- synchronize all items.
[In FilterType(Sync)] Yes. [Applies to Email, if FilterType is 0, Status element value is 1.]
[In FilterType(Sync)] Yes. [Applies to calendar, if FilterType is 0, Status element value is 1.]
[In FilterType(Sync)] Yes. [Applies to tasks, if FilterType is 0, Status element value is 1.]
[In FilterType(Sync)] Value 1 means 1 day.
[In FilterType(Sync)] Yes. [Applies to Email, if FilterType is 1, Status element value is 1.]
[In FilterType(Sync)] No, [Applies to calendar, if FilterType is 1, status is not 1.]
[In FilterType(Sync)] No, [Applies to tasks, if FilterType is 1, status is not 1.]
[In FilterType(Sync)] Value 2 means 3 days.
[In FilterType(Sync)] Yes. [Applies to Email, if FilterType is 2, Status element value is 1.]
[In FilterType(Sync)] No, [Applies to calendar, if FilterType is 2, status is not 1.]
[In FilterType(Sync)] No, [Applies to tasks, if FilterType is 2, status is not 1.]
[In FilterType(Sync)] Value 3 means 1 week.
[In FilterType(Sync)] Yes. [Applies to Email, if FilterType is 3, Status element value is 1.]
[In FilterType(Sync)] No, [Applies to calendar, if FilterType is 3, status is not 1.]
[In FilterType(Sync)] No, [Applies to tasks, if FilterType is 3, status is not 1.]
[In FilterType(Sync)] Value 4 means 2 weeks.
[In FilterType(Sync)] Yes. [Applies to Email, if FilterType is 4, Status element value is 1.]
[In FilterType(Sync)] Yes, [Applies to calendar, if FilterType is 4, Status element value is 1.]
[In FilterType(Sync)] No, [Applies to tasks, if FilterType is 4, status is not 1.]
[In FilterType(Sync)] Value 5 means 1 month.
[In FilterType(Sync)] Yes. [Applies to Email, if FilterType is 5, Status element value is 1.]
[In FilterType(Sync)] Yes. [Applies to calendar, if FilterType is 5, Status element value is 1.]
[In FilterType(Sync)] No, [Applies to tasks, if FilterType is 5, status is not 1.]
[In FilterType(Sync)] Value 6 means 3 months.
[In FilterType(Sync)] No, [Applies to email, if FilterType is 6, status is not 1.]
[In FilterType(Sync)] Yes. [Applies to calendar, if FilterType is 6, Status element value is 1.]
[In FilterType(Sync)] No, [Applies to tasks, if FilterType is 6, status is not 1.]
[In FilterType(Sync)] Value 7 means 6 months.
[In FilterType(Sync)] No, [Applies to email, if FilterType is 7, status is not 1.]
[In FilterType(Sync)] Yes. [Applies to calendar, if FilterType is 7, Status element value is 1.]
[In FilterType(Sync)] No, [Applies to tasks, if FilterType is 7, status is not 1.]
[In FilterType(Sync)] Value 8 means Filter by incomplete tasks.
[In FilterType(Sync)] No, [Applies to email, if FilterType is 8, status is not 1.]
[In FilterType(Sync)] No, [The result of including a FilterType element value of 8 for a Calendar item is undefined.]
[In FilterType(Sync)] Yes. [Applies to tasks, if FilterType is 8, Status element value is 1.]
[In FilterType(Sync)] When the FilterType element is specified, the server manages objects on the client to maintain the time window.
[In FilterType(Sync)] New objects are added when they are within the time window.
[In FilterType(Sync)] The server sends SoftDelete (section 2.2.3.157) operations for objects on the client when they become older than the window.
[In FilterType(Sync)] The start time of the time window is determined by subtracting the period of time represented by the value of the FilterType element from the current time.
[In FilterType(Sync)] Any items that are dated between the start time of the window and the current time are considered within the time window.
[In FilterType(Sync)] For example, if the value of the FilterType element is 2, then the start time of the time window is three days prior to the current time.
[In FilterType(Sync)] Calendar items that are in the future [or that have recurrence but no end date] are sent to the client regardless of the FilterType element value.
[In FilterType(Sync)] Calendar items [that are in the future or] that have recurrence but no end date are sent to the client regardless of the FilterType element value.
[In FilterType(Sync)] Calendar items that fall between the FilterType element value and the present time are returned to the client.
[In FilterType(Sync)] For example, an appointment that occurred two weeks ago is returned when the FilterType element value is set to 5 (one month back).
[In FilterType(Sync)] The result of including a FilterType element value of 8 for a Calendar item is undefined.
[In FilterType(Sync)] The server can return a protocol status error in response to such a command request[FilterType element value of 8 for a Calendar item].
[In FilterType(Sync)] The FilterType element is a child of the Options element.
[In FilterType(Sync)] Therefore, it [FilterType element] appears only in requests to the server from the client.
[In FilterType(Sync)] The result of including more than one FilterType element as the child of the Options element is undefined.
[In FilterType(Sync)] The server MAY return a protocol status error in response to such a command request[more than one FilterType element as the child of the Options element ].
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirement: MS-ASCMD_R3075.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In FilterType(Sync)] If the FilterType element is omitted, all objects are sent from the server without regard for their age.
[In FilterType(Sync)] Clients MUST send a maximum of one FilterType element.
[In FilterType(Sync)] The server ignores the FilterType element if it [FilterType element] is included in a contact Sync request, no error is thrown.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Partially verified by derived requirement: MS-ASCMD_R3079.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In FilterType(Sync)] Reply is the same whether FilterType element is or not included in a contact Sync request, and no error is thrown.
[In FilterType(Sync)] The server returns a Status element (section 2.2.3.162.16) value of 4 if a FilterType element value of 8 is included in an email Sync request.

[In FreeText] The FreeText element is used in the following command requests and responses: § Find command requests (section 2.2.1.2) § Search command requests and responses (section 2.2.1.16)
[In FreeText] The definition of the FreeText element differs according to the context in which it is used.
[In FreeText] For more details, see section 2.2.3.80.1 and section 2.2.3.80.2.

[In FreeText (Find)] The FreeText element is an optional child element of the Query element in Find command requests that specifies a Keyword Query Language (KQL) string value that defines the search criteria.
[In FreeText (Find)] All elements referenced in this section are defined in the Find namespace.
[In FreeText (Find)] Element FreeText in Find command request (section 2.2.1.2), the parent element is Query (section 2.2.3.142.1).
[In FreeText (Find)] None [Element FreeText in Find command request (section 2.2.1.2) has no child element.]
[In FreeText (Find)] Element FreeText in Find command request (section 2.2.1.2), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7).
[In FreeText (Find)] Element FreeText in Find command request (section 2.2.1.2), the number allowed is 1...1 (required).
[In FreeText (Find)] Property restrictions are search predicates such as "from:", "to:", "subject:", etc. that can be used to search against specific keywords.
[In FreeText (Find)] For a detailed list of all supported property restrictions, see Advanced Query Search.
[In FreeText (Find)] For details on the syntax to construct the property restriction search, see [MS-KQL].
[In FreeText (Find)] If no property restriction is provided, the basic keyword query is executed against all indexed properties.
[In FreeText (Find)] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [FreeText] element.
[In FreeText (Find)] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [FreeText] element.
[In FreeText (Find)] Protocol version 14.1 does not support this [FreeText] element.
[In FreeText (Find)] Protocol version 16.0 does not support this [FreeText] element.
[In FreeText (Find)] Protocol version 16. 1 supports this [FreeText] element.
[In FreeText (Search)] The FreeText element is an optional child element of the And element in Search command requests that specifies a string value for which to search.
[In FreeText (Search)] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.77] are defined in the Search namespace.
[In FreeText (Search)] Element FreeText in Search command request (section 2.2.2.15), the parent element is And (section 2.2.3.10).
[In FreeText (Search)] None [Element FreeText in Search command request (section 2.2.2.15) has no child element.]
[In FreeText (Search)] Element FreeText in Search command request (section 2.2.2.15), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7).
[In FreeText (Search)] Element FreeText in Search command request (section 2.2.2.15), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).

[In FreeText (Search)] If the FreeText element is included as a child element of any element other than the And element, the server responds with a Status element (section 2.2.3.167.12) value of 8 (SearchTooComplex).
[In FreeText (Search)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [FreeText] element.

[In FriendlyName] The FriendlyName element value can be up to 1024 characters in length.
[In FriendlyName] The friendly name of the device is specified during partnership creation if the user creates a desktop-device partnership with a desktop.

[In Get] The Get element is a required child element of the RightsManagementInformation element in Settings command RightsManagementInformation requests and responses.
[In Get] The Get element is an optional child element of the Oof element in Settings command Oof requests and responses.
[In Get] The Get element is a required child element of the UserInformation element in Settings command UserInformation requests and responses.
[In Get] In requests, the Get element enables the client to retrieve rights management information settings, OOF settings, or user information settings from the server.
[In Get] In responses, the Get element contains rights management information settings, OOF information, or user information settings retrieved from the server.
[In Get] Elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.79] are defined in the Settings namespace, except where otherwise indicated by the presence of a namespace prefix (as defined in section 2.2.1).
[In Get] Element Get in Settings command RightsManagementInformation request (section 2.2.2.17), the parent lement is RightsManagementInformation (section 2.2.3.147).

[In Get] Element Get in Settings command Oof response, the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).

[In Get] Element Get in Settings command UserInformation response, the number allowed is 1…1 (required).
[In Get] In a Settings command Oof request, the client specifies the body type (BodyType element) to be retrieved and the server will return all OOF settings and messages for that body type.
[In Get] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Get] element [as] child of Oof, UserInformation.
[In Get] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Get] element [as] child of Oof, UserInformation.
[In Get] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Get] element.
[In Get] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Get] element.
[In Get] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Get] element.
[In Get] The EmailAddresses element is supported as a child element of the Get element only when the protocol version 12.0, 12.1 or 14.0 is used.
[In Get] The RightsManagementInformation element is supported as a parent element of the Get element only when the protocol version 14.1 or 16.0 is used.

[In GetChanges] The GetChanges element is an optional child element of the Collection element in Sync command requests that requests that the server include in its response any pending changes to the collection that is specified by the ServerId element (section 2.2.3.151.6).
[In GetChanges] If there have been changes since the last synchronization, the server response includes a Commands element (section 2.2.3.32) that contains additions, deletions, and changes.
[In GetChanges] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.80] are defined in the AirSync namespace.
[In GetChanges] Element GetChanges in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.20), the parent element is Collection (section 2.2.3.29.2).
[In GetChanges] None [Element GetChanges in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.20) has no child element.]
[In GetChanges] Element GetChanges in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.20), the data type is boolean ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.1).
[In GetChanges] Element GetChanges in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.20), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In GetChanges] The GetChanges element appears only in requests to the server from the client.
[In GetChanges] If the client does not want the server changes returned, the request MUST include the GetChanges element with a value of 0 (FALSE).
[In GetChanges] A value of 1 (TRUE) indicates that the client wants the server changes to be returned.
[In GetChanges] A value of 1 (TRUE) is assumed when the GetChanges element is empty.
[In GetChanges] When the GetChanges element is not present in the request, the behavior depends on the value of the SyncKey element, as specified in section 2.2.3.166.4.
[In GetChanges] If the SyncKey element has a value of 0, then the request is handled as if the GetChanges element were set to 0 (FALSE).
[In GetChanges] If the SyncKey element has a non-zero value, then the request is handled as if the GetChanges element were set to 1 (TRUE).
[In GetChanges] A Status element (section 2.2.3.167.16) value of 4 is returned if the GetChanges element is present and empty [or set to 1 (TRUE)] when the SyncKey element value is 0 (zero).
[In GetChanges] A Status element (section 2.2.3.167.16) value of 4 is returned if the GetChanges element is [present and empty or] set to 1 (TRUE) when the SyncKey element value is 0 (zero).
[In GetChanges] No error is returned if the GetChanges element is absent [or set to 0 (FALSE)] when the SyncKey value is 0 (zero).
[In GetChanges] No error is returned if the GetChanges element is [absent or] set to 0 (FALSE) when the SyncKey value is 0 (zero).
[In GetChanges] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [GetChanges] element.
[In GetChanges] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [GetChanges] element.
[In GetChanges] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [GetChanges] element.
[In GetChanges] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [GetChanges] element.
[In GetChanges] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [GetChanges] element.

[In GreaterThan] The GreaterThan element is an optional child element of the And element in Search command requests that contains elements that specify a property and a value that are compared for a "greater than" condition during a search.

[In GreaterThan] Elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.78] are defined in the Search namespace, except where otherwise indicated by the presence of a namespace prefix (as defined in section 2.2.1).
[In GreaterThan] Element GreaterThan in Search command request (section 2.2.2.15), the parent element is And (section 2.2.3.10).
[In GreaterThan] Element GreaterThan in Search command request (section 2.2.2.15), the child elements are email:DateReceived (section 2.2.3.51), Value (section 2.2.3.186).
[In GreaterThan] Element GreaterThan in Search command request (section 2.2.2.15), the data type is container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2).
[In GreaterThan] Element GreaterThan in Search command request (section 2.2.2.15), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In GreaterThan] The result of including more than one GreaterThan element in a Search command request is undefined.
[In GreaterThan] The server MAY return a protocol status error in response to such a command request [more than one GreaterThan element in a Search].
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirement: MS-ASCMD_R7568.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In GreaterThan] The GreaterThan element is supported only in mailbox searches.
[In GreaterThan] It [the GreaterThan element ] is not supported for document library searches.
[In GreaterThan] The comparison is made between the value of the Value element and the date that a mailbox item was received.
[In GreaterThan] The email:DateReceived element MUST be present before the Value element.
[In GreaterThan] Typically, this [GreaterThan] element is used to filter results by the date on which they were received so that the date received is greater than the specified value.

[In GreaterThan] If the GreaterThan element is included as a child element of any element other than the And element (section 2.2.3.10), the server responds with a Status element (section 2.2.3.167.12) value of 8 (SearchTooComplex).
[In GreaterThan] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [GreaterThan] element.

[In GreaterThan] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [GreaterThan] element.
[In GreaterThan] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [GreaterThan] element.
[In GreaterThan] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [GreaterThan] element.

[In HeartbeatInterval] The HeartbeatInterval element is used in the following command requests and responses: Ping command requests and responses (section 2.2.2.11), Sync command requests (section 2.2.2.19)
[In HeartbeatInterval] The definition of the HeartbeatInterval element differs according to the context in which it [HeartbeatInterval element] is used.
[In HeartbeatInterval] For more details, section 2.2.3.79.1 and section 2.2.3.79.2.
[In HeartbeatInterval(Ping)] The HeartbeatInterval element is a child element of the Ping element in Ping command requests and responses.

[In HeartbeatInterval(Ping)] In Ping command requests, it specifies the length of time, in seconds, that the server SHOULD wait before sending a response if no new items are added to the specified set of folders, as specified in section 3.1.5.8.

[In HeartbeatInterval(Ping)] The HeartbeatInterval element is also returned by the server with a status code of 5 and specifies [either] the minimum [or maximum] interval that is allowed when the client has requested a heartbeat interval that is outside the acceptable range.

[In HeartbeatInterval(Ping)] The HeartbeatInterval element is also returned by the server with a status code of 5 and specifies [either the minimum or] maximum interval that is allowed when the client has requested a heartbeat interval that is outside the acceptable range.
[In HeartbeatInterval(Ping)] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.79.1] are defined in the Ping namespace.
[In HeartbeatInterval(Ping)] Element HeartbeatInterval in Ping command request (section 2.2.2.12), the parent element is Ping (section 2.2.3.130).

[In HeartbeatInterval(Ping)] Element HeartbeatInterval in Ping command request (section 2.2.2.12), the data type is integer ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6).

[In HeartbeatInterval(Ping)] Valid values for the HeartbeatInterval element are implementation-specific.<7>

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In HeartbeatInterval(Ping)] The HeartbeatInterval element is only required in the first Ping command request from a device by a given user.
[In HeartbeatInterval(Ping)] The server then caches the heartbeat interval value so that in later requests the HeartbeatInterval element is necessary only if the client is changing the interval.

[In HeartbeatInterval(Sync)] The HeartbeatInterval is an optional child element of the Sync element in Sync command requests that specifies the number of seconds that the server SHOULD delay a response if no new items are added to the included folders, as specified in section 3.1.5.4.
[In HeartbeatInterval(Sync)] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.79.2] are defined in the AirSync namespace.
[In HeartbeatInterval(Sync)] Element HeartbeatInterval in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.20), the parent element is Sync (section 2.2.3.170).
[In HeartbeatInterval(Sync)] None [Element HeartbeatInterval in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.20) has no child element.]
[In HeartbeatInterval(Sync)] Element HeartbeatInterval in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.20), the data type is integer ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6).
[In HeartbeatInterval(Sync)] Element HeartbeatInterval in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.20), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In HeartbeatInterval(Sync)] Valid values for the HeartbeatInterval element are implementation-specific.<8>.

[In HeartbeatInterval(Sync)] When the client requests an interval that is outside the acceptable range, the server will send a response that includes a Status element (section 2.2.3.167.16) value of 14 and a Limit element.

[In HeartbeatInterval(Sync)] Either the HeartbeatInterval element or the Wait element (section 2.2.3.182) can be included in a Sync command request, but not both [HeartbeatInterval element and the Wait element].
[In HeartbeatInterval(Sync)] If both [HeartbeatInterval element and the Wait element ] elements are included, the server response will contain a Status element value of 4.

The definition of the HomePhone element differs according to the context in which it is used. For more details, see section 2.2.3.89.1 and section 2.2.3.89.2.
[In HomePhone(Find)] The HomePhone element in the GAL namespace is an optional child element of the find:Properties element in Find command responses.
[In HomePhone(Find)] The HomePhone element is only present in response to Find command requests that contain the GALSearchCriterion element as specified in section 2.2.3.82.
[In HomePhone(Find)] It[HomePhone] contains the home phone number of a recipient in the GAL that matched the search criteria from the corresponding Find command request.

[In Id] The Id element is a required child element of the Folder element in Ping command requests that specifies the server ID of the folder to be monitored.
[In Id] Elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.81] are defined in the Ping namespace, except where otherwise indicated by the presence of a namespace prefix (as defined in section 2.2.1).

[In Id] The server ID of the folder is obtained from the folderhierarchy:ServerId element (section 2.2.3.156) of a previous FolderSync command response (section 2.2.2.4) or FolderCreate command response (section 2.2.2.2).
[In Id] The Id element value can be up to 64 characters in length.
[In Id] The server returns a Status element (section 2.2.3.167.10) value of 4 if the value of the Id element is the same for two or more folders listed in a Ping request.

[In IMEI] The device ID parameter that is currently included in the request URL is not precisely defined.
[In IMEI] Protocol implementers are free to populate the field as they [protocol inplementers] want.
[In IMEI] To enable workable inventory-type report generation, an ID that uniquely identifies a device in the space of all devices is required.

[In InstanceId] The InstanceId element is used in the following command requests: MeetingResponse command requests (section 2.2.2.9), SmartForward command requests (section 2.2.2.17), SmartReply command requests (section 2.2.2.18).
[In InstanceId] The definition of the InstanceId element differs according to the context in which it [InstanceId element] is used.
[In InstanceId] For more details, see section 2.2.3.83.1 and section 2.2.3.83.2.

[In InstanceId(MeetingResponse)] The InstanceId element<40> is an optional child element of the Request element in MeetingResponse command requests that specifies the instance of the recurring meeting to be modified.

[In InstanceId(MeetingResponse)] Elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.83.1] are defined in the MeetingResponse namespace, except where otherwise indicated by the presence of a namespace prefix (as defined in section 2.2.1).
[In InstanceId(MeetingResponse)] Element InstanceId in MeetingResponse command request (section 2.2.2.10), the parent element is Request (section 2.2.3.141.2).
[In InstanceId(MeetingResponse)] None [Element InstanceId in MeetingResponse command request (section 2.2.2.10) has no child element.]
[In InstanceId(MeetingResponse)] Element InstanceId in MeetingResponse command request (section 2.2.2.10), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7).
[In InstanceId(MeetingResponse)] Element InstanceId in MeetingResponse command request (section 2.2.2.10), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In InstanceId(MeetingResponse)] Element InstanceId in MeetingResponse command response, the parent element is Result (section 2.2.3.146.1).
[In InstanceId(MeetingResponse)] None [Element InstanceId in MeetingResponse command response has no child element.]
[In InstanceId(MeetingResponse)] Element InstanceId in MeetingResponse command response, the data type is string.
[In InstanceId(MeetingResponse)] Element InstanceId in MeetingResponse command response, the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In InstanceId(MeetingResponse)] The InstanceId element contains the start time of the appointment or meeting instance to be modified.
[In InstanceId(MeetingResponse)] If the InstanceId element is not included in the MeetingResponse request, then the action is to be taken on every instance of the recurring item.
[In InstanceId(MeetingResponse)] The InstanceId element can specify the start time of an exception to a recurring appointment or meeting.

[In InstanceId(MeetingResponse)] The InstanceId element can be used with the search:LongId element (section 2.2.3.89.2) to identify a calendar item , or it can be used with the CollectionId (section 2.2.3.30.3) and RequestId (section 2.2.3.128) elements to identify a calendar item.
[In InstanceId(MeetingResponse)] The format of the InstanceId value is a string in dateTime ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.3) format with the punctuation separators, for example, 2010-04-08T18:16:00.000Z.

[In InstanceId(MeetingResponse)] If the InstanceId element passes schema validation but the value is not specified in the proper format, the server responds with a Status element (section 2.2.3.167.8) value of 104.
[In InstanceId(MeetingResponse)] If the InstanceId element value specifies a non-recurring meeting, the server responds with a Status element value of 146.
[In InstanceId(MeetingResponse)] A Status element value of 2 [or an HTTP 400 response] is returned if the request includes the InstanceId element when a non-supporting protocol version is used.<9>
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirements: MS-ASCMD_R7497.

[In InstanceId(SmartForward and SmartReply)] The InstanceId element is an optional child element of the Source element in SmartForward command requests and SmartReply command requests that specifies the instance of a recurrence for the source item.
[In InstanceId(SmartForward and SmartReply)] If the InstanceId element is present, both the FolderId (section 2.2.3.69) and ItemId (section 2.2.3.84) elements SHOULD be present.

[In InstanceId(SmartForward and SmartReply)] Element InstanceId in SmartReply command request (section 2.2.2.18), the data type is datetime.
[In InstanceId(SmartForward and SmartReply)] Element InstanceId in SmartReply command request (section 2.2.2.18), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In InstanceId(SmartForward and SmartReply)] The format of the InstanceId element is a dateTime value that includes the punctuation separators.

[In ItemId] The ItemId element is an optional child element of the Source element in SmartForward command requests and SmartReply command requests that specifies the item ID for the source message, which is returned in the Sync command response message (section 2.2.2.19).

[In ItemId] If the ItemId element is present, the FolderId element (section 2.2.3.69) MUST also be present if the message being forwarded or replied to is stored in a folder other than the Inbox folder.
