[LastName (Find)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [LastName] element.
[LastName (Search)] The LastName element in the GAL namespace is an optional child element of the search:Properties element in Search command responses.
[LastName (Search)] The LastName element is only present in response to Search command requests that contain a search:Name element with a value of "GAL", as specified in section 2.2.3.114.2.
[LastName (Search)] It [LastName element] contains the last name of a recipient in the GAL that matched the search criteria from the corresponding Search command request.
[LastName (Search)] Element LastName in Search command response (section 2.2.2.15), the parent element is Properties (section 2.2.3.132.2).
[LastName (Search)] None [Element LastName in Search command response (section 2.2.2.15) has no child element.]
[LastName (Search)] Element LastName in Search command response (section 2.2.2.15), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7).
[LastName (Search)] Element LastName in Search command response (section 2.2.2.15), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[LastName (Search)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [LastName] element.
[LastName (Search)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [LastName] element.
[LastName (Search)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [LastName] element.
[LastName (Search)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [LastName] element.
[LastName (Search)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [LastName] element.

[In LessThan] The LessThan element is an optional child element of the And element in Search command requests that contains elements that specify a property and a value that are compared for a "less than" condition during a search.
[In LessThan] Elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.87] are defined in the Search namespace, except where otherwise indicated by the presence of a namespace prefix (as defined in section 2.2.1).
[In LessThan] Element LessThan in Search command request (section 2.2.2.15), the parent element is And (section 2.2.3.10).
[In LessThan] Element LessThan in Search command request (section 2.2.2.15), the child elements are email:DateReceived (section 2.2.3.51),Value (section 2.2.3.186).
[In LessThan] Element LessThan in Search command request (section 2.2.2.15), the data type is container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2).
[In LessThan] Element LessThan in Search command request (section 2.2.2.15), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In LessThan] The result of including more than one LessThan element in a Search command request is undefined.
[In LessThan] The server MAY return a protocol status error in response to such a command request [more than one LessThan element in a Search command request].
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirement: MS-ASCMD_R7572.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In LessThan] The LessThan element is supported only in mailbox searches.
[In LessThan] It [the LessThan element] is not supported for document library searches.
[In LessThan] The comparison is made between the value of the Value element and the date that a mailbox item was received.
[In LessThan] The email:DateReceived element MUST be present before the Value element.
[In LessThan] Typically, this [LessThan] element is used to filter results by the date on which they were received so that the date received is less than the specified value.

[In LessThan] If the LessThan element is included as a child element of any element other than the And element (section 2.2.3.10), the server responds with a Status element (section 2.2.3.167.12) value of 8 (SearchTooComplex).
[In LessThan] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [LessThan] element.
[In LessThan] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [LessThan] element.
[In LessThan] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [LessThan] element.
[In LessThan] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [LessThan] element.
[In LessThan] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [LessThan] element.

[In Limit] The Limit element is an optional child element of the Sync element in Sync command responses that specifies either the maximum number of collections that can be synchronized or the maximum/minimum value that is allowed for the Wait interval (section 2.2.3.182) or HeartbeatInterval interval (section 2.2.3.79.2).
[In Limit] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.88] are defined in the AirSync namespace.
[In Limit] Element Limit in Sync command response (section 2.2.2.20), the parent element is Sync (section 2.2.3.170).
[In Limit] None [Element Limit in Sync command response (section 2.2.2.20) has no child element.]
[In Limit] Element Limit in Sync command response (section 2.2.2.20), the data type is integer ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6).
[In Limit] Element Limit in Sync command response (section 2.2.2.20), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In Limit] The Limit element is returned in a response with a status code of 14 or 15.
[In Limit] The value of the Status element (section 2.2.3.162.16) indicates whether the limit applies to the Wait interval or HeartbeatInterval interval or the number of collections, as follows:
[In Limit] A status code 14 indicates that the Limit element specifies the minimum or maximum wait-interval that is acceptable.
[In Limit] When the value of the Wait element or HeartbeatInterval element is outside of the acceptable range, the server responds with the closest acceptable value.
[In Limit] If a Wait element value of less than 1 is sent, the server returns a Limit element value of 1, indicating the minimum value of the Wait element is 1.
[In Limit] If a Wait element value greater than 59 is sent, the server returns a Limit element value of 59, indicating the maximum value of the Wait element is 59.
[In Limit] If a HeartbeatInterval element value of less than 60 is sent, the server returns a Limit element value of 60, indicating the minimum value of the HeartbeatInterval element is 60.
[In Limit] If a HeartbeatInterval element value greater than 3540 is sent, the server returns a Limit element value of 3540, indicating the maximum value of HeartbeatInterval element is 3540.
[In Limit] A status code 15 indicates that the Limit element specifies the maximum number of collections that can be synchronized.
[In Limit] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Limit] element.
[In Limit] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Limit] element.
[In Limit] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Limit] element.
[In Limit] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Limit] element.
[In Limit] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Limit] element.

[In LongId]The LongId element is used in the following command requests and responses: ItemOperations command requests (section 2.2.2.8), MeetingResponse command requests (section 2.2.2.9), Search command responses (section 2.2.2.14), SmartForward command requests (section 2.2.2.17), SmartReply command requests (section 2.2.2.18).
[In LongId] The definition of the LongId element differs according to the context in which it [LongId element] is used.
[In LongId] For more details, see section 2.2.3.89.1, section 2.2.3.89.3, and section 2.2.3.89.4.

[In LongId(ItemOperations)] The search:LongId element is an optional child element of the Fetch element in ItemOperations command requests that specifies a unique identifier that was assigned by the server to each result returned by a previous Search response.
[In LongId(ItemOperations)] The search:LongId element value can be up to 256 characters in length.

[In LongId(ItemOperations)] Elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.89.1] are defined in the ItemOperations namespace, except where otherwise indicated by the presence of a namespace prefix (as defined in section 2.2.1).

[In LongId(ItemOperations)] None [Element LongId in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8) fetch operation has no child element.]
[In LongId(ItemOperations)] Element LongId in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8) fetch operation, the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6).
[In LongId(ItemOperations)] Element LongId in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8) fetch operation, the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In LongId(ItemOperations)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [LongId(ItemOperations)] element.
[In LongId(ItemOperations)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [LongId(ItemOperations)] element.
[In LongId(ItemOperations)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [LongId(ItemOperations)] element.
[In LongId(ItemOperations)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [LongId(ItemOperations)] element.
[In LongId(ItemOperations)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [LongId(ItemOperations)] element.
[In LongId (MeetingResponse)] The LongId element is an optional child element of the Source element in MeetingResponse command requests.
[In LongId (MeetingResponse)] This element [LongId element] specifies the long ID for the source meeting request, which is returned in the Search command response message (section 2.2.2.14).
[In LongId (MeetingResponse)] If the LongId element is present, the CollectionId (section 2.2.3.30.3), InstanceId (section 2.2.3.83.1), and RequestId (section 2.2.3.138) elements are not present.
[In LongId (MeetingResponse)] The LongId element value can be up to 256 characters in length.
[In LongId (MeetingResponse)] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.89.2] are defined in the ComposeMail namespace.
[In LongId (MeetingResponse)] Element LongId in MeetingResponse command request (section 2.2.2.9), the parent element is Request (section 2.2.3.137.2).
[In LongId (MeetingResponse)] None [Element LongId in MeetingResponse command request (section 2.2.2.9) has no child element.]
[In LongId (MeetingResponse)] Element LongId in MeetingResponse command request (section 2.2.2.9), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6).
[In LongId (MeetingResponse)] Element LongId in MeetingResponse command request (section 2.2.2.9), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In LongId (MeetingResponse)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [ LongId (MeetingResponse)] element.
[In LongId (MeetingResponse)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [ LongId (MeetingResponse)] element.
[In LongId (MeetingResponse)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [ LongId (MeetingResponse)] element.
[In LongId (MeetingResponse)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [ LongId (MeetingResponse)] element.
[In LongId (MeetingResponse)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [ LongId (MeetingResponse)] element.

[In LongId(Search)] The LongId element is an optional child element of the Result element in Search command responses that specifies a unique identifier that is assigned by the server to each result set that is returned.
[In LongId(Search)] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.89.3] are defined in the Search namespace.
[In LongId(Search)] Element LongId in Search command response (section 2.2.2.15), the parent element is Result (section 2.2.3.146.2).
[In LongId(Search)] None [Element LongId in Search command response (section 2.2.2.15) has no child element.]
[In LongId(Search)] Element LongId in Search command response (section 2.2.2.15), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7).
[In LongId(Search)] Element LongId in Search command response (section 2.2.2.15), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).

[In LongId(Search)] The value of the LongId element can be used as the long ID specified in the ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8), the SmartReply command request (section 2.2.2.18), the SmartForward command request (section 2.2.2.17), or the MeetingResponse command request (section 2.2.2.9) to reference the result set.
[In LongId(Search)] The client MUST store the value of LongId as an opaque string of up to 256 characters.
[In LongId(Search)] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [LongId(Search)] element.
[In LongId(Search)] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [LongId(Search)] element.
[In LongId(Search)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [LongId(Search)] element.
[In LongId(Search)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [LongId(Search)] element.
[In LongId(Search)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [LongId(Search)] element.

[In LongId(SmartForward and SmartReply)] The LongId element is an optional child element of the Source element in SmartForward command requests and SmartReply command requests that specifies the long ID for the source message, which is returned in the Search command response message (section 2.2.2.14).
[In LongId(SmartForward and SmartReply)] If the LongId element is present, the FolderId (section 2.2.3.69), ItemId (section 2.2.3.84), and InstanceId (section 2.2.3.83.2) elements are not present.
[In LongId(SmartForward and SmartReply)] The LongId element value can be up to 256 characters in length.
[In LongId(SmartForward and SmartReply)] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.89.4] are defined in the ComposeMail namespace.

[In LongId(SmartForward and SmartReply)] Element LongId in SmartForward command request (section 2.2.2.17), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6).
[In LongId(SmartForward and SmartReply)] Element LongId in SmartForward command request (section 2.2.2.17), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In LongId(SmartForward and SmartReply)] Element LongId in SmartReply command request (section 2.2.2.18), the parent element is Source.
[In LongId(SmartForward and SmartReply)] None [Element LongId in SmartReply command request (section 2.2.2.18) has no child element.]
[In LongId(SmartForward and SmartReply)] Element LongId in SmartReply command request (section 2.2.2.18), the data type is string.
[In LongId(SmartForward and SmartReply)] Element LongId in SmartReply command request (section 2.2.2.18), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In LongId(SmartForward and SmartReply)] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [LongId] element.
[In LongId(SmartForward and SmartReply)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [LongId] element.
[In LongId(SmartForward and SmartReply)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [LongId] element.
[In LongId(SmartForward and SmartReply)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [LongId] element.
[In LongId(SmartForward and SmartReply)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [LongId] element.
The MailBoxSearchCriterion element is an optional child element of the ExecuteSearch element in Find command requests that contains the criterion for a mailbox search.

[In MaxAmbiguousRecipients] The MaxAmbiguousRecipients element is an optional child element of the Options element in ResolveRecipients command requests that limits the number of suggestions that are returned for each ambiguous recipient node in the response.
[In MaxAmbiguousRecipients] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.90] are defined in the ResolveRecipients namespace.
[In MaxAmbiguousRecipients] Element MaxAmbiguousRecipients in ResolveRecipients command request (section 2.2.2.13), the parent element is Options (section 2.2.3.115.3).
[In MaxAmbiguousRecipients] None [Element MaxAmbiguousRecipients in ResolveRecipients command request (section 2.2.2.13) has no child element.]
[In MaxAmbiguousRecipients] Element MaxAmbiguousRecipients in ResolveRecipients command request (section 2.2.2.13), the data type is integer ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.5).
[In MaxAmbiguousRecipients] Element MaxAmbiguousRecipients in ResolveRecipients command request (section 2.2.2.13), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In MaxAmbiguousRecipients] The value of the MaxAmbiguousRecipients element is limited to a range of 0–9999.
[In MaxAmbiguousRecipients] Each ambiguous recipient node receives only this many suggestions and no more.

[In MaxAmbiguousRecipients] The recipient count, returned in the RecipientCount element (section 2.2.3.133), can be used by the client to determine the total number of suggestions available for that recipient.
[In MaxAmbiguousRecipients] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [MaxAmbiguousRecipients] element.
[In MaxAmbiguousRecipients] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [MaxAmbiguousRecipients] element.
[In MaxAmbiguousRecipients] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [MaxAmbiguousRecipients] element.
[In MaxAmbiguousRecipients] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [MaxAmbiguousRecipients] element.
[In MaxAmbiguousRecipients] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [MaxAmbiguousRecipients] element.

[In MaxCertificates] The MaxCertificates element is an optional child element of the Options element in ResolveRecipients command requests that limits the total number of certificates that are returned by the server.
[In MaxCertificates] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.91] are defined in the ResolveRecipients namespace.
[In MaxCertificates] ElementMaxCertificates in ResolveRecipients command request (section 2.2.2.13),the parent element is Options (section 2.2.3.115.3).
[In MaxCertificates] None [ElementMaxCertificates in ResolveRecipients command request (section 2.2.2.13) has no child element.]
[In MaxCertificates] ElementMaxCertificates in ResolveRecipients command request (section 2.2.2.13), the data type is integer ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.5).
[In MaxCertificates]ElementMaxCertificates in ResolveRecipients command request (section 2.2.2.13), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In MaxCertificates] The value of the MaxCertificates element is limited to a range of 0–9999.
[In MaxCertificates] This limit [the value of the MaxCertificates element is limited to a range of 0–9999] ensures that no individual recipient receives an incomplete set of certificates.

[In MaxCertificates] If the MaxCertificates limit is reached while enumerating certificates for an address list, that address list will not get back any certificates and a Status element (section 2.2.3.167.11) value of 8 is returned.
[In MaxCertificates] The client can then use the certificate count returned to determine the number of certificates that are available for that recipient node.
[In MaxCertificates] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [MaxCertificates] element.
[In MaxCertificates] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [MaxCertificates] element.
[In MaxCertificates] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [MaxCertificates] element.
[In MaxCertificates] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [MaxCertificates] element.
[In MaxCertificates] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [MaxCertificates] element.
[In MaxFolders] The MaxFolders element is an optional child element of the Ping element in Ping command responses that specifies the maximum number of folders that can be monitored.
[In MaxFolders] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.92] are defined in the Ping namespace.
[In MaxFolders] Element MaxFolders in Ping command response (section 2.2.2.12), the parent element is Ping (section 2.2.3.130).
[In MaxFolders] None [Element MaxFolders in Ping command response (section 2.2.2.12) has no child element.]
[In MaxFolders] Element MaxFolders in Ping command response (section 2.2.2.12), the data type is integer ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6).
[In MaxFolders] Element MaxFolders in Ping command response (section 2.2.2.12), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In MaxFolders] The MaxFolders element is returned in a response with a status code of 6.
[In MaxFolders] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [MaxFolders] element.
[In MaxFolders] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [MaxFolders] element.
[In MaxFolders] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [MaxFolders] element.
[In MaxFolders] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [MaxFolders] element.
[In MaxFolders] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [MaxFolders] element.
[In MaxItems]The MaxItems element is used in the following command requests: GetItemEstimate command requests (section 2.2.2.7), Sync command requests (section 2.2.2.19).
[In MaxItems] The definition of the MaxItems element differs according to the context in which it [MaxItems element] is used.
[In MaxItems] For more details, see section 2.2.3.93.1 and section 2.2.3.93.2.

[In MaxItems(GetItemEstimate)] The airsync:MaxItems element<41> is an optional child element of the airsync:Options element in GetItemEstimate command requests that specifies the maximum number of items to include in the response.
[In MaxItems(GetItemEstimate)] This [MaxItems] element can only be included in a request when the CollectionId element (section 2.2.3.30.1) is set to "RI" to specify a recipient information store.
[In MaxItems(GetItemEstimate)] Otherwise [if MaxItems included in a request when the collectionId element is set to anything other than "RI"], the server will respond with a status 2 error.

[In MaxItems(GetItemEstimate)] Elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.93.1] are defined in the GetItemEstimate namespace, except where otherwise indicated by the presence of a namespace prefix (as defined in section 2.2.1).
[In MaxItems(GetItemEstimate)] Element MaxItems in GetItemEstimate command request (section 2.2.2.7), the parent element is airsync:Options (section 2.2.3.115.1).
[In MaxItems(GetItemEstimate)] None [Element MaxItems in GetItemEstimate command request (section 2.2.2.7) has no child element.]
[In MaxItems(GetItemEstimate)] Element MaxItems in GetItemEstimate command request (section 2.2.2.7), the data type is integer ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.5).
[In MaxItems(GetItemEstimate)] Element MaxItems in GetItemEstimate command request (section 2.2.2.7), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).

[In MaxItems(GetItemEstimate)] Including airsync:MaxItems when the CollectionId element is set to anything other than "RI" results in an invalid XML error, Status element (section 2.2.3.167.6) value of 2.
[In MaxItems(GetItemEstimate)] The result of including more than one airsync:MaxItems element as the child of the airsync:Options element is undefined.

[In MaxItems(GetItemEstimate)] The server MAY return a protocol status error in response to such a command request [more than one airsync:MaxItems element as the child of the airsync:Options element is undefined].

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In MaxItems(GetItemEstimate)] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [MaxItems(GetItemEstimate)] element.

[In MaxItems(GetItemEstimate)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [MaxItems(GetItemEstimate)] element.

[In MaxItems(Sync)] The MaxItems element<42> is an optional child element of the Options element in Sync command requests that specifies the maximum number of recipients (that is, the top N most frequently used recipients) to keep synchronized from within the recipient information cache.
[In MaxItems(Sync)] This [MaxItems] element MUST only be included in a request when the value of the CollectionId element (section 2.2.3.30.5) maps to the recipient information cache.

[In MaxItems(Sync)] The value of the MaxItems element does not specify the maximum estimate of additions and deletions to make to the recipient information cache, it only specifies the number of recipients to keep synchronized.
[In MaxItems(Sync)] A complete replacement of each recipient would be double the number of MaxItems or items in the cache, as each recipient update requires a deletion and an addition.
[In MaxItems(Sync)] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.93.2] are defined in the AirSync namespace.
[In MaxItems(Sync)] Element MaxItems in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.19), the parent element is Options (section 2.2.3.115.5).
[In MaxItems(Sync)] None [Element MaxItems in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.19) has no child element.]
[In MaxItems(Sync)] Element MaxItems in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.19), the data type is integer ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.5).
[In MaxItems(Sync)] Element MaxItems in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.19), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In MaxItems(Sync)] The result of including more than one MaxItems element as the child element of the Options element is undefined.
[In MaxItems(Sync)] The server MAY return a protocol status error in response to such a command request [more than one MaxItems element as the child element of the Options element].
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirement: MS-ASCMD_R3280.

[In MaxItems(Sync)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [MaxItems(Sync)] element.
[In MaxItems(Sync)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [MaxItems(Sync)] element.

[In MaxPictures]The MaxPictures element<43> is used in the following command requests: § Find command requests (section 2.2.1.2) § ResolveRecipients command requests (section 2.2.1.15) § Search command requests (section 2.2.1.16)
[In MaxPictures] The definition of the MaxPictures element differs according to the context in which it [MaxPictures element] is used.
[In MaxPictures] For more details, see section 2.2.3.104.1, section 2.2.3.104.2, and section 2.2.3.104.3.
[In MaxPictures (Find)]The MaxPictures element is an optional child element of the Picture element in Find command requests that limits the number of contact photos returned in the server response.
[In MaxPictures (Find)] All elements referenced in this section are defined in the Find namespace.
[In MaxPictures (Find)] Element MaxPictures in Find command request (section 2.2.1.2), the parent element is .
[In MaxPictures (Find)] None [Element MaxPictures in Find command request (section 2.2.1.2) has no child element.]
[In MaxPictures (Find)] Element MaxPictures in Find command request (section 2.2.1.2), the data type is integer ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6).
[In MaxPictures (Find)] Element MaxPictures in Find command request (section 2.2.1.2), the number allowed is 0…..1 (optional).
[In MaxPictures (Find)] The server returns the first N results that have contact photos, where N is the value of the MaxPictures element(N=1).
[In MaxPictures (Find)] After the MaxPictures limit is reached, the server returns Status element (section 2.2.3.177.2) value 173 (NoPicture)
[In MaxPictures (Find)] If the contact has no photo, Status element value 174 (PictureTooLarge) if the contact’s photo is too large.
[In MaxPictures (Find)] If the contact has a photo but the MaxPictures limit was reached, Status element value 175 (PictureLimitReached).
[In MaxPictures (Find)] [MaxPictures (Find)] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [MaxPictures] element.
[In MaxPictures (Find)] [MaxPictures (Find)] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [MaxPictures] element.
[In MaxPictures (Find)] Protocol version 14.1 does not support this [MaxPictures] element.
[In MaxPictures (Find)] Protocol version 16.0 does not support this [MaxPictures] element.
[[In MaxPictures (Find)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [MaxPictures] element.

[In MaxPictures(ResolveRecipients)] The MaxPictures element<44> is an optional child element of the Picture element in ResolveRecipients command requests that limits the number of contact photos returned in the server response.
[In MaxPictures(ResolveRecipients)] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.94.1] are defined in the ResolveRecipients namespace.
[In MaxPictures(ResolveRecipients)] Element MaxPictures in ResolveRecipients command request (section 2.2.2.13), the parent element is Picture (section 2.2.3.125.1).
[In MaxPictures(ResolveRecipients)] None [Element MaxPictures in ResolveRecipients command request (section 2.2.2.13) has no child element.]
[In MaxPictures(ResolveRecipients)] Element MaxPictures in ResolveRecipients command request (section 2.2.2.13), the data type is integer ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.5).
[In MaxPictures(ResolveRecipients)] Element MaxPictures in ResolveRecipients command request (section 2.2.2.13), the number allowed is 0…..1 (optional).
[In MaxPictures(ResolveRecipients)] The server returns the first N results that have contact photos, where N is the value of the MaxPictures element.
[In MaxPictures(ResolveRecipients)] After the MaxPictures limit is reached, the server returns Status element (section 2.2.3.167) value 173 (NoPicture) if the contact has no photo.
[In MaxPictures(ResolveRecipients)] [After the MaxPictures limit is reached, the server returns] Status element value 174 (PictureTooLarge) if the contact’s photo is too large.

[In MaxPictures(ResolveRecipients)] [After the MaxPictures limit is reached, the server returns] Status element value 175 (PictureLimitReached) if the contact has a photo but the MaxPictures limit was reached.
[In MaxPictures(ResolveRecipients)] Note that the MaxPictures element identifies the number of contact photos returned per query.

[In MaxPictures(ResolveRecipients)] Therefore, if the client includes three recipients to resolve and sets the MaxPictures element value to 3 in the ResolveRecipients command request, a maximum of 9 contact photos can be returned.
[In MaxPictures(ResolveRecipients)] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [MaxPictures(ResolveRecipients)] element.
[In MaxPictures(ResolveRecipients)] Protocol version 14.0 does not support this [MaxPictures(ResolveRecipients)] element.
[In MaxPictures(ResolveRecipients)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [MaxPictures(ResolveRecipients)] element.
[In MaxPictures(ResolveRecipients)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [MaxPictures(ResolveRecipients)] element.

[In MeetingResponse] The MeetingResponse element is a required element in MeetingResponse command requests and MeetingResponse command responses that identifies the body of the HTTP POST as containing a MeetingResponse command (section 2.2.2.9).
[In MeetingResponse] It [MeetingResponse element] is the top-level element in the XML stream.
[In MeetingResponse] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.96] are defined in the MeetingResponse namespace.
[In MeetingResponse] None [Element MeetingResponse in MeetingResponse command request has no parent element.]
[In MeetingResponse] Element MeetingResponse in MeetingResponse command request, the child element is Request (section 2.2.3.141.2).

[In MeetingResponse] Element MeetingResponse in MeetingResponse command request, the number allowed is 1…1 (required).

[In MergedFreeBusy] The MergedFreeBusy element<49> is an optional child element of the Availability element in ResolveRecipients command responses that specifies the free/busy information for the users or distribution list identified in the request.
[In MergedFreeBusy] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.97] are defined in the ResolveRecipients namespace.
[In MergedFreeBusy] Element MergedFreeBusy in ResolveRecipients command response (section 2.2.2.14), the parent element is Availability (section 2.2.3.16).
[In MergedFreeBusy] None [Element MergedFreeBusy in ResolveRecipients command response (section 2.2.2.14) has no child element.]
[In MergedFreeBusy] Element MergedFreeBusy in ResolveRecipients command response (section 2.2.2.14), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7).
[In MergedFreeBusy] Element MergedFreeBusy in ResolveRecipients command response (section 2.2.2.14), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In MergedFreeBusy] The MergedFreeBusy element value string has a maximum length of 32 KB.
[In MergedFreeBusy] To retrieve more than 32 KB of availability data, the client MUST issue a new request with the appropriate start time and end time.
[In MergedFreeBusy] Each digit in the MergedFreeBusy element value string indicates the free/busy status for the user or distribution list for every 30 minute interval.
[In MergedFreeBusy] The following table lists the valid values[0, 1, 2, 3, 4]].
[In MergedFreeBusy] Value 0 means Free.
[In MergedFreeBusy] Value 1 means Tentative.
[In MergedFreeBusy] Value 2 means Busy.
[In MergedFreeBusy] Value 3 means Out of Office (OOF).
[In MergedFreeBusy] Value 4 means No data.

[In MergedFreeBusy] A string value of "32201" would represent that this user or group of users is out of the office for the first 30 minutes, busy for the next hour, free for 30 minutes, and then has a tentative meeting for the last 30 minutes.

[In MergedFreeBusy] If the user or group of users has a change in availability that lasts less than the interval value of 30 minutes, the availability value with the higher digit value is assigned to the whole interval period.

[In MergedFreeBusy] For example, if a user has a 25 minutes of free time (value 0) followed by 5 minutes of busy time (value 2), the 30 minute interval is assigned a value of 2 in the server response.

[In MergedFreeBusy] The server determines the number of digits to include in the MergedFreeBusy element by dividing the time interval specified by the StartTime element (section 2.2.3.166.1) value and the EndTime element (section 2.2.3.58.1) value by 30 minutes, and rounding the result up to the next integer.
[In MergedFreeBusy] The MergedFreeBusy element value string is populated from the StartTime element value onwards, therefore the last digit represents between a millisecond and 30 minutes.
[In MergedFreeBusy] A query for data from 13:00:00 to 13:30:00 returns a single digit but a query from 12:59:59 to 13:30:00 or 13:00:00 to 13:30:01 returns two digits.
[In MergedFreeBusy] Any appointment that ends inside a second of the interval requested shall impact the digit representing that timeframe.
[In MergedFreeBusy] For example, given a calendar that contains a 5 minute OOF appointment from 12:00 to 12:05, and is free the rest of the day, queries would result in the following [scenarios].
[In MergedFreeBusy] If a query is made for 12:00:00 to 13:00:00, the result is "30", where each digit represents exactly 30 minutes.
[In MergedFreeBusy] If a query is made for 12:04:59 to 13:00:00, the result is "30", where the "0" maps to 12:34:59 to 13:00:00.
[In MergedFreeBusy] If a query is made for 12:05:00 to 13:00:00, the result is "00" where the second 0 maps the last 25 minutes of the interval.

[In MergedFreeBusy] The client MUST consider daylight saving time transitions and might need to add or remove time intervals from the MergedFreeBusy element value string, as there are days that have more or less than 24 hours.
[In MergedFreeBusy] If the Availability element is included in the response, the response MUST also include the Status element (section 2.2.3.167.11).
[In MergedFreeBusy] The MergedFreeBusy element is also included if the Status element value indicates success.
[In MergedFreeBusy] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [MergedFreeBusy] element.
[In MergedFreeBusy] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [MergedFreeBusy] element.
[In MergedFreeBusy] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [MergedFreeBusy] element.
[In MergedFreeBusy] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [MergedFreeBusy] element.
[In MergedFreeBusy] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [MergedFreeBusy] element.

[In Message] The Message element is an optional child element of the Error element in Autodiscover command responses that contains the error string localized using the Culture (section 2.2.3.36) value specified in the Response element, enabling the client to display error status to the end-user.
[In Message] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.98] are defined in the http://schemas.microsoft.com/exchange/autodiscover/mobilesync/requestschema/2006 namespac
[In Message] Element Message in Autodiscover command response (section 2.2.2.1),the parent element is Error (section 2.2.3.60).
[In Message] None [Element Message in Autodiscover command response (section 2.2.2.1) has no child element.]
[In Message] Element Message in Autodiscover command response (section 2.2.2.1), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7).
[In Message] Element Message in Autodiscover command response (section 2.2.2.1), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In Message] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Message] element.
[In Message] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Message] element.
[In Message] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Message] element.
[In Message] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Message] element.
[In Message] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Message] element.

[In Mime] The Mime element is a required child element of the SendMail element in SendMail command requests, a required child element of the SmartForward element in SmartForward command requests, and a required child element of the SmartReply element in SmartReply command requests.
[In Mime] In all contexts, it [Mime element] contains the MIME-encoded message.
[In Mime] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.99] are defined in the ComposeMail namespace.
[In Mime] Element Mime in SendMail command request (section 2.2.2.15), the parent element is SendMail (section 2.2.3.148).
[In Mime] None [Element Mime in SendMail command request (section 2.2.2.15), has no child element.]
[In Mime] Element Mime in SendMail command request (section 2.2.2.15), the data type ia Byte array.
[In Mime] Element Mime in SendMail command request (section 2.2.2.15), the number allowed is 1...1 (required).
[In Mime] Element Mime in SmartForward command request (section 2.2.2.17), the parent element is SmartForward (section 2.2.3.154).
[In Mime] None [Element Mime in SmartForward command request (section 2.2.2.17) has no child element.]
[In Mime] Element Mime in SmartForward command request (section 2.2.2.17), the data type is Byte array.
[In Mime] Element Mime in SmartForward command request (section 2.2.2.17), the number allowed is 1...1 (required).
[In Mime] Element Mime in SmartReply command request (section 2.2.2.18), the parent element is SmartReply (section 2.2.3.155).
[In Mime] None [Element Mime in SmartReply command request (section 2.2.2.18) has no child element.]
[In Mime] Element Mime in SmartReply command request (section 2.2.2.18), the data type is Byte array.
[In Mime] Element Mime in SmartReply command request (section 2.2.2.18), the number allowed is 1...1 (required).
[In Mime] The Mime element content is transferred as an opaque BLOB within the WBXML tags, as specified in [WBXML1.2].

[In Mime] If the message contains a meeting request, the Mime element contains the details of meeting in iCalendar format [MS-OXCICAL] or Transport Neutral Encapsulation Format (TNEF) format [MS-OXTNEF].
[In Mime] As specified in [RFC2447] section 3.4, iCalendar meeting requests have a content type of "text/calendar" with the method parameter set to "REQUEST".
[In Mime] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [Mime] element.
[In Mime] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Mime] element.
[In Mime] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Mime] element.
[In Mime] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Mime] element.
[In Mime] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Mime] element.

[In MIMESupport]The MIMESupport element is used in the following command requests: ItemOperations command requests (section 2.2.2.8), Search command requests (section 2.2.2.14), Sync command requests (section 2.2.2.19).
[In MIMESupport] The definition of the MIMESupport element differs according to the context in which it [MIMESupport element] is used.
[In MIMESupport] For more details, see section 2.2.3.100.1, section 2.2.3.100.2, and section 2.2.3.100.3.

[In MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] The airsync:MIMESupport element is an optional child element of the the Options element in ItemOperations command requests that enables MIME support for email items that are sent from the server to the client.
[In MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] For an example, see section 4.10.2.

[In MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] Elements referenced in this section are defined in the ItemOperations namespace, except where otherwise indicated by the presence of a namespace prefix (as defined in section 2.2.1).
[In MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] Element MIMESupport in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8) fetch operation, the parent element is Options (section 2.2.3.115.2).
[In MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] None [Element MIMESupport in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8) fetch operation has no child element.]
[In MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] Element MIMESupport in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8) fetch operation, the data type is unsignedByte ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7).
[In MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] Element MIMESupport in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8) fetch operation, the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] The following table lists the valid values [0, 1, 2] for this [MIMESupport] element.
[In MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] If the MIMESupport element is not present, the default value of 0 is used.
[In MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] Value 0 means Never send MIME data.
[In MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] Value 1 means Send MIME data for S/MIME messages only.
[In MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] Value 1 means Send regular body for all other messages.
[In MIMESupport(ItemOperations)]Value 2 means Send MIME data for all messages.
[In MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] This flag[2] could be used by clients to build a more rich and complete Inbox solution.

[In MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] To support fetching of the full S/MIME message, the ItemOperations command request MUST include the following elements [airsync:MIMESupport element, and airsyncbase:BodyPreference element] in the Options element.

[In MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] [To support fetching of the full S/MIME message, the Fetch (section 2.2.3.63.1) request MUST include] The airsync:MIMESupport element (section 2.2.3.104.3) to indicate to the server to return MIME for S/MIME-only messages, all messages, or no messages.

[In MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] [To support fetching of the full S/MIME message, the Fetch (section 2.2.3.63.1) request MUST include] The airsyncbase:BodyPreference element ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.7) with its child element, Type ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.22.4), having a value of 4 to inform the server that the device can read the MIME binary large object (BLOB).

[In MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] The server's response MUST include the airsyncbase:Body element ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.9), which is a child element of the Properties element (section 2.2.3.132.1).
[In MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] The airsyncbase:Body element is a complex element

[In MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] [The airsyncbase:Body element] MUST contain the following child elements in an S/MIME response[the airsyncbase:Type element, the airsyncbase:EstimatedDataSize element, the airsyncbase:Data element]
[In MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] The airsyncbase:Type element ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.41.1) with a value of 4 to inform the device that the data is a MIME BLOB.
[In MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] The airsyncbase:EstimatedDataSize element ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.23.2) to specify the rough total size of the data.
[In MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] The airsyncbase:Data element ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.20.1) that contains the full MIME BLOB.

[In MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] For more details about the airsyncbase:Body element or the airsyncbase:BodyPreference element, see [MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.4 or [MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.7, respectively.
[In MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] element.
[In MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] element.
[In MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] element.
[In MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] element.
[In MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [MIMESupport(ItemOperations)] element.

[In MIMESupport(Search)] The airsync:MIMESupport element is an optional child element of the Options element in Search command requests that enables MIME support for email items that are sent from the server to the client.

[In MIMESupport(Search)] Elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.100.2] are defined in the Search namespace, except where otherwise indicated by the presence of a namespace prefix (as defined in section 2.2.1).
[In MIMESupport(Search)] Element MIMESupport in Search command request (section 2.2.2.14), the parent element is Options (section 2.2.3.115.4).
[In MIMESupport(Search)] None [Element MIMESupport in Search command request (section 2.2.2.14) has no child element.]
[In MIMESupport(Search)] Element MIMESupport in Search command request (section 2.2.2.14), the data type is integer ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.5).
[In MIMESupport(Search)] Element MIMESupport in Search command request (section 2.2.2.14), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In MIMESupport(Search)] The result of including more than one airsync:MIMESupport element in a Search command request is undefined.
[In MIMESupport(Search)] The server MAY return a protocol status error in response to such a command request[more than one airsync:MIMESupport element in a Search command request].
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirement: MS-ASCMD_R3374.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In MIMESupport(Search)] The following table lists the valid values [0, 1, 2] for the [MIMESupport] element.
[In MIMESupport(Search)] If the MIMESupport element is not present, the default value of 0 is used.
[In MIMESupport(Search)] Value 0 means Never send MIME data.
[In MIMESupport(Search)] Value 1 means Send MIME data for S/MIME [RFC5751] messages only.
[In MIMESupport(Search)]Value 1 means Send regular body (non S/MIME) data for all other messages.
[In MIMESupport(Search)]Value 2 means Send MIME data for all messages.
[In MIMESupport(Search)] This flag [MIMESupport value 2] could be used by clients to build a more rich and complete Inbox solution.
[In MIMESupport(Search)] The Search response can include the S/MIME BLOB of a signed/encrypted message.

[In MIMESupport(Search)] If the airsync:MIMESupport element is set to 1 or 2 in the Search request: The child element of the airsyncbase:BodyPreference element ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.7), the Type element ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.22.4), SHOULD be included in the Search request, containing a value of 4 to inform the server that the device can read the MIME BLOB.

[In MIMESupport(Search)] [If the airsync:MIMESupport element is set to 1 in the Search request:] The response from the server MUST include the airsyncbase:Body element ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.9), which is a child element of the Properties element (section 2.2.3.132.2).

[In MIMESupport(Search)] [If the airsync:MIMESupport element is set to 2 in the Search request:] The response from the server MUST include the airsyncbase:Body element ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.9), which is a child element of the Properties element (section 2.2.3.132.2).
[In MIMESupport(Search)] The airsyncbase:Body element is a complex element

[In MIMESupport(Search)] [The airsyncbase:Body element] MUST contain the following child elements [the airsyncbase:Type element, the airsyncbase:EstimatedDataSize element, the airsyncbase:Truncated element, the airsyncbase:Data element] in an S/MIME Search response.
[In MIMESupport(Search)] The airsyncbase:Type element ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.41.1) with a value of 4 to inform the device that the data is a MIME BLOB.
[In MIMESupport(Search)] The airsyncbase:EstimatedDataSize element ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.23.2) to specify the rough total size of the data.
[In MIMESupport(Search)] The airsyncbase:Truncated element ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.20.1) to indicate whether the MIME BLOB is truncated.
[In MIMESupport(Search)] The airsyncbase:Data element ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.10.1) that contains the full MIME BLOB.
[In MIMESupport(Search)] For more details about the airsyncbase:Body element or the airsyncbase:BodyPreference element, see [MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.4 or [MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.7, respectively.
[In MIMESupport(Search)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [MIMESupport(Search)] element.
[In MIMESupport(Search)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [MIMESupport(Search)] element.
[In MIMESupport(Search)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [MIMESupport(Search)] element.
[In MIMESupport(Search)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [MIMESupport(Search)] element.
[In MIMESupport(Search)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [MIMESupport(Search)] element.

[In MIMESupport(Sync)] The MIMESupport element is an optional child element of the Options element in Sync command requests that enables MIME support for email items that are sent from the server to the client.

[In MIMESupport(Sync)] Elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.100.3] are defined in the AirSync namespace, except where otherwise indicated by the presence of a namespace prefix (as defined in section 2.2.1).
[In MIMESupport(Sync)] Element MIMESupport in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.19), the parent element is Options (section 2.2.3.115.5).
[In MIMESupport(Sync)] None [Element MIMESupport in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.19) has no child element.]
[In MIMESupport(Sync)] Element MIMESupport in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.19), the data type is unsignedByte ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7).
[In MIMESupport(Sync)] Element MIMESupport in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.19), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In MIMESupport(Sync)] The following table shows valid values [0, 1, 2] for the [MIMESupport] element.
[In MIMESupport(Sync)] If the MIMESupport element is not present, the default value of 0 is used.
[In MIMESupport(Sync)] Value 0 means Never send MIME data.
[In MIMESupport(Sync)]Value 1 means Send MIME data for S/MIME messages only.
[In MIMESupport(Sync)]Value 1 means Send regular body for all other messages.
[In MIMESupport(Sync)] Value 2 means Send MIME data for all messages.
[In MIMESupport(Sync)] This flag [MIMESupport values 2] could be used by clients to build a more rich and complete Inbox solution.
[In MIMESupport(Sync)] The client MUST send a maximum of one MIMESupport element.
[In MIMESupport(Sync)] The result of including more than one MIMESupport element as the child element of the Options element is undefined.
[In MIMESupport(Sync)] The server MAY return a protocol status error in response to such a command request[more than one MIMESupport element as the child element of the Options element].
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirement: MS-ASCMD_R3404.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In MIMESupport(Sync)] The Sync request MUST include the following elements [the MIMESupport element, the airsyncbase:BodyPreference element] in the Options element when handling S/MIME content.
[In MIMESupport(Sync)] The MIMESupport element to tell the server to return MIME for S/MIME-only/All/None messages.

[In MIMESupport(Sync)] The airsyncbase:BodyPreference element ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.7) with its child element, Type ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.22.4), which contains a value of 4 to inform the server that the device can read the MIME BLOB.

[In MIMESupport(Sync)] When handling S/MIME content in the response, the server MUST include the airsyncbase:Body element ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.9), which is a child of the ApplicationData element (section 2.2.3.11).
[In MIMESupport(Sync)] The airsyncbase:Body element is a complex element.

[In MIMESupport(Sync)] [The airsyncbase:Body element] MUST contain the following child elements [the airsyncbase:Type element, the airsyncbase:EstimatedDataSize element, the airsyncbase:Truncated element, the airsyncbase:Data element] in an S/MIME synchronization response.
[In MIMESupport(Sync)] The airsyncbase:Type element ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.41.1) with a value of 4 to inform the device that the data is a MIME BLOB.
[In MIMESupport(Sync)] The airsyncbase:EstimatedDataSize element ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.12.2) to specify the rough total size of the data.
[In MIMESupport(Sync)] The airsyncbase:Truncated element ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.20.1) to indicate whether the MIME BLOB is truncated.
[In MIMESupport(Sync)] The airsyncbase:Data element ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.10.1) that contains the full MIME BLOB.
[In MIMESupport(Sync)] For more details about the airsyncbase:Body element or the airsyncbase:BodyPreference element, see [MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.4 or [MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.7, respectively.
[In MIMESupport(Sync)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [MIMESupport(Sync)] element.
[In MIMESupport(Sync)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [MIMESupport(Sync)] element.
[In MIMESupport(Sync)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [MIMESupport(Sync)] element.
[In MIMESupport(Sync)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [MIMESupport(Sync)] element.
[In MIMESupport(Sync)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [MIMESupport(Sync)] element.

[In MIMETruncation] The MIMETruncation element is an optional child element of the Options element in Sync command requests that specifies whether the MIME data of the email item SHOULD be truncated when it is sent from the server to the client.
[In MIMETruncation] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.101] are defined in the AirSync namespace.
[In MIMETruncation] Element MIMETruncation in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.19), the parent element is Options (section 2.2.3.115.5).
[In MIMETruncation] None [Element MIMETruncation in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.19), has no child element.]
[In MIMETruncation] Element MIMETruncation in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.19), the data type is unsignedByte ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7).
[In MIMETruncation] Element MIMETruncation in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.19), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In MIMETruncation] The following table lists valid values [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8] for the [MIMETruncation] element.
[In MIMETruncation] Value 0 means Truncate all body text.
[In MIMETruncation] Value 1 means Truncate text over 4,096 characters.
[In MIMETruncation] Value 2 means Truncate text over 5,120 characters.
[In MIMETruncation] Value 3 means Truncate text over 7,168 characters.
[In MIMETruncation] Value 4 means Truncate text over 10,240 characters.
[In MIMETruncation] Value 5 means Truncate text over 20,480 characters.
[In MIMETruncation] Value 6 means Truncate text over 51,200 characters.
[In MIMETruncation] Value 7 means Truncate text over 102,400 characters.
[In MIMETruncation] Value 8 means Do not truncate; send complete MIME data.
[In MIMETruncation] The size of the truncated message returned in the response is not the exact size of the MIMETruncation element value.
[In MIMETruncation] The size specified by the MIMETruncation element is an approximate value.

[In MIMETruncation] This [The size of the truncated message returned in the response is not the exact size of the MIMETruncation element value; the size specified by the MIMETruncation element is an approximate value.] is because line feeds are treated as one character locally, but are counted as two characters during truncation.
[In MIMETruncation] The result of including more than one MIMETruncation element as the child element of the Options element is undefined.
[In MIMETruncation] The server MAY return a protocol status error in response to such a command request[more than one MIMETruncation element as the child element of the Options element].
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirement: MS-ASCMD_R3432.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In MIMETruncation] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [MIMETruncation] element.
[In MIMETruncation] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [MIMETruncation] element.
[In MIMETruncation] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [MIMETruncation] element.
[In MIMETruncation] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [MIMETruncation] element.
[In MIMETruncation] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [MIMETruncation] element.

[In MiniCertificate] The MiniCertificate element is an optional child element of the Certificates element in ResolveRecipients command responses that contains the mini-certificate BLOB that is encoded with base64 encoding.
[In MiniCertificate] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.112] are defined in the ResolveRecipients namespace.
[In MiniCertificate] Element MiniCertificate in ResolveRecipients command response (section 2.2.1.15), the parent element is Certificates (section 2.2.3.23.1).
[In MiniCertificate] None [Element MiniCertificate in ResolveRecipients command response (section 2.2.1.15) has no child element.]
[In MiniCertificate] Element MiniCertificate in ResolveRecipients command response (section 2.2.1.15), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7) (encoded with base64 encoding).
[In MiniCertificate] Element MiniCertificate in ResolveRecipients command response (section 2.2.1.15), the number allowed is 0...1 per Certificates parent element.

[In MiniCertificate] This [MiniCertificate] element is returned only if the client specifies a value of 3 in the CertificateRetrieval element (section 2.2.3.22) in the ResolveRecipients command request and the resolved recipient has a valid S/MIME certificate.
[In MiniCertificate] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [MiniCertificate] element.
[In MiniCertificate] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [MiniCertificate] element.
[In MiniCertificate] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [MiniCertificate] element.
[In MiniCertificate] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [MiniCertificate] element.
[In MiniCertificate] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [MiniCertificate] element.

[In MobileOperator] The MobileOperator element is an optional<50> child element of the Set element in Settings command requests that specifies the name of the mobile operator to which a mobile device is connected.
[In MobileOperator] The MobileOperator element value can be up to 1024 characters in length.
[In MobileOperator] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.103] are defined in the Settings namespace.
[In MobileOperator] Element MobileOperator in Settings command DeviceInformation request (section 2.2.2.16), the parent element is Set (section 2.2.3.152).
[In MobileOperator] None [Element MobileOperator in Settings command DeviceInformation request (section 2.2.2.16) has no child element.]
[In MobileOperator] Element MobileOperator in Settings command DeviceInformation request (section 2.2.2.16), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6).
[In MobileOperator] Element MobileOperator in Settings command DeviceInformation request (section 2.2.2.16), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In MobileOperator] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [MobileOperator] element.
[In MobileOperator] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [MobileOperator] element.
[In MobileOperator] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [MobileOperator] element.
[In MobileOperator] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [MobileOperator] element.
[In MobileOperator] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [MobileOperator] element.
[In MobilePhone] The MobilePhone element is used in the following command responses: § Find command responses (section 2.2.1.2) § Search command responses (section 2.2.1.16)
[In MobilePhone] The definition of the MobilePhone element differs according to the context in which it is used.
[In MobilePhone] For more details, see section 2.2.3.114.1 and section 2.2.3.114.2.
[In MobilePhone (Find)] The MobilePhone element in the GAL namespace is an optional child element of the find:Properties element in Find command responses.
[In MobilePhone (Find)] The MobilePhone element is only present in response to Find command requests that contain a GALSearchCriterion element as specified in section 2.2.3.82.
[In MobilePhone (Find)] It[MobilePhone] contains the mobile phone number of a recipient in the GAL that matched the search criteria from the corresponding Find command request.
[In MobilePhone (Find)] Element MobilePhone in Find command response (section 2.2.1.2), the parent element is Properties (section 2.2.3.139.1) .
[In MobilePhone (Find)] None [Element MobilePhone in Find command response (section 2.2.1.2) has no child element.]
[In MobilePhone (Find)] Element MobilePhone in Find command response (section 2.2.1.2), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7).
[In MobilePhone (Find)] Element MobilePhone in Find command response (section 2.2.1.2), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In MobilePhone (Find)] Protocol version 12.1 does not supports this [MobilePhone] element.
[In MobilePhone (Find)] Protocol version 14.0 does not supports this [MobilePhone] element.
[In MobilePhone (Find)] Protocol version 14.1 does not supports this [MobilePhone] element.
[In MobilePhone (Find)] Protocol version 16.0 does not supports this [MobilePhone] element.
[In MobilePhone (Find)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [MobilePhone] element.
[In MobilePhone (Search)] The MobilePhone element in the GAL namespace is an optional child element of the search:Properties element in Search command responses.
[In MobilePhone (Search)] The MobilePhone element is only present in response to Search command requests that contain a search:Name element with a value of "GAL", as specified in section 2.2.3.120.2.
[In MobilePhone (Search)] It [MobilePhone element] contains the mobile phone number of a recipient in the GAL that matched the search criteria from the corresponding Search command request.
[In MobilePhone (Search)] Element MobilePhone in Search command response (section 2.2.1.16), the parent element is Properties (section 2.2.3.139.3).
[In MobilePhone (Search)] None [Element MobilePhone in Search command response (section 2.2.1.16) has no child element]
[In MobilePhone (Search)] Element MobilePhone in Search command response (section 2.2.1.16), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7).
[In MobilePhone (Search)] Element MobilePhone in Search command response (section 2.2.1.16), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In MobilePhone (Search)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [MobilePhone] element.
[In MobilePhone (Search)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [MobilePhone] element.
[In MobilePhone (Search)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [MobilePhone] element.
[In MobilePhone (Search)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [MobilePhone] element.
[In MobilePhone (Search)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [MobilePhone] element.
[In Model] The Model element is an optional child element of the Set element in Settings command requests that specifies a name that generally describes the device of the client.
[In Model] The Model element value can be up to 1024 characters in length.
[In Model] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.115] are defined in the Settings namespace.
[In Model] Element Model in Settings command DeviceInformation request (section 2.2.1.18), the parent element is Set (section 2.2.3.167).
[In Model] None [Element Model in Settings command DeviceInformation request (section 2.2.1.18) has no child element.]
[In Model] Element Model in Settings command DeviceInformation request (section 2.2.1.18), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6).
[In Model] Element Model in Settings command DeviceInformation request (section 2.2.1.18), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In Model] The descriptive name of the device can be any string that the client chooses, typically a general description of the device.
[In Model] For example, the name of the manufacturer, the model name, or the model number can be used.
[In Model] The server does not perform any validation of this string [the descriptive name of the device], so the client can submit any string.
[In Model] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Model] element.
[In Model] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Model] element.
[In Model] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Model] element.
[In Model] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Model] element.
[In Model] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Model] element.

[In MoreAvailable] The MoreAvailable element is an optional child element of the Collection element in Sync command responses that indicates there are more changes than the number that are requested in the WindowSize element (section 2.2.3.183).
[In MoreAvailable] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.106] are defined in the AirSync namespace.
[In MoreAvailable] Element MoreAvailable in Sync command response (section 2.2.2.20), the parent element is Collection (section 2.2.3.29.2).
[In MoreAvailable] None [Element MoreAvailable in Sync command response (section 2.2.2.20) has no child element.]
[In MoreAvailable] None [Element MoreAvailable in Sync command response (section 2.2.2.20) has no data type.]
[In MoreAvailable] Element MoreAvailable in Sync command response (section 2.2.2.20), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In MoreAvailable] The MoreAvailable element is an empty tag element, meaning it has no value or data type.
[In MoreAvailable] It [MoreAvailable element] is distinguished only by the presence or absence of the <MoreAvailable/> tag.
[In MoreAvailable] The MoreAvailable element appears only in responses that are sent from the server to the client.
[In MoreAvailable] It [MoreAvailable element] appears only if the client request contained a WindowSize element and there are still changes to be returned to the client.
[In MoreAvailable] The server includes the MoreAvailable element in Sync responses that contain no additions, changes, or deletions when the server encounters elements external to the protocol.<10>

[In MoreAvailable] If the client receives multiple Sync responses that contain the MoreAvailable element and fewer changes than requested by the WindowSize element value included in the Sync request the client SHOULD continue to send Sync requests to retrieve additional changes until no additional results are sent by the server

[In MoreAvailable] The client MAY stop sending Sync requests if the Sync request and response loop is affecting network performance and synchronizing the client is of less importance than network performance.
[In MoreAvailable] The MoreAvailable element has no body.
[In MoreAvailable] It [ MoreAvailable element] is omitted if no additional changes are available.
[In MoreAvailable] The maximum value for the WindowSize element is 512.
[In MoreAvailable] The server interprets WindowSize element values above 512 and 0 (zero) as 512.
[In MoreAvailable] If the WindowSize element is omitted, the server behaves as if a WindowSize element with a value of 100 was submitted.
[In MoreAvailable] The MoreAvailable element is returned by the server if there are more than 512 changes, regardless of whether the WindowSize element is included in the request.
[In MoreAvailable] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [MoreAvailable] element.
[In MoreAvailable] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [MoreAvailable] element.
[In MoreAvailable] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [MoreAvailable] element.
[In MoreAvailable] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [MoreAvailable] element.
[In MoreAvailable] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [MoreAvailable] element.
[In Move] The Move element is used in the following command requests and responses: ItemOperations command requests and responses (section 2.2.2.8), MoveItems command request (section 2.2.2.10).
[In Move] The definition of the Move element differs according to the context in which it [Move element] is used.
[In Move] For more details, see section 2.2.3.107.1 and section 2.2.3.107.2.

[In Move(ItemOperations)] The Move element is an optional child element of the ItemOperations element in ItemOperations command requests and an optional child element of the Response element in ItemOperations command responses.
[In Move(ItemOperations)] It [Move element] identifies the body of the request or response as containing the operation that moves a given conversation.
[In Move(ItemOperations)] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.107.1] are defined in the ItemOperations namespace.
[In Move(ItemOperations)] Element Move in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8), the parent element is ItemOperations (section 2.2.3.85).

[In Move(ItemOperations)] Element Move in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8), the child elements are ConversationId (section 2.2.3.35.1), DstFldId (section 2.2.3.49.1), Options (section 2.2.3.115.2).
[In Move(ItemOperations)] Element Move in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8), the data type is container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2).
[In Move(ItemOperations)] Element Move in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8), the number allowed is 0...N (optional).
[In Move(ItemOperations)] Element Move in ItemOperations command response, the parent element is Response (section 2.2.3.144.3).
[In Move(ItemOperations)] Element Move in ItemOperations command response, the child elements are ConversationId,Status (section 2.2.3.167.7).
[In Move(ItemOperations)] Element Move in ItemOperations command response, the data type is container.
[In Move(ItemOperations)] Element Move in ItemOperations command response, the number allowed is 0...N (optional).
[In Move(ItemOperations)] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [Move(ItemOperations)] element.
[In Move(ItemOperations)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Move(ItemOperations)] element.
[In Move(ItemOperations)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Move(ItemOperations)] element.
[In Move(ItemOperations)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Move(ItemOperations)] element.
[In Move(ItemOperations)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Move(ItemOperations)] element.
[In Move(MoveItems)] The Move element is a required child element of the MoveItems element in MoveItems command requests that contains elements that describe details of the items to be moved.
[In Move(MoveItems)] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.107.2] are defined in the Move namespace.
[In Move(MoveItems)] Element Move in MoveItems command request (section 2.2.2.10), the parent element is MoveItems (section 2.2.3.109).
[In Move(MoveItems)] Element Move in MoveItems command request (section 2.2.2.10), the child elements are SrcMsgId (section 2.2.3.160), SrcFldId (section 2.2.3.159), DstFldId (section 2.2.3.49.2).
[In Move(MoveItems)] Element Move in MoveItems command request (section 2.2.2.10), the data type is container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2).
[In Move(MoveItems)] Element Move in MoveItems command request (section 2.2.2.10), the number allowed is 1...N (required).
[In Move(MoveItems)] The Move element's child elements specify the item to be moved, the folder it's currently located in, and the folder it will be moved to.
[In Move(MoveItems)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Move(MoveItems)] element.
[In Move(MoveItems)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Move(MoveItems)] element.
[In Move(MoveItems)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Move(MoveItems)] element.
[In Move(MoveItems)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Move(MoveItems)] element.
[In Move(MoveItems)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Move(MoveItems)] element.

[In MoveAlways] The MoveAlways element is an optional child element of the Options element in ItemOperations command requests that indicates whether to always move the specified conversation, including all future emails in the conversation, to the folder specified by the DstFldId element (section 2.2.3.49.1) value.<53>
[In MoveAlways] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.108] are defined in the ItemOperations namespace.
[In MoveAlways] Element MoveAlways in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8) Move operation, the parent element is Options (section 2.2.3.115.2).
[In MoveAlways] None [Element MoveAlways in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8) Move operation has no child element.]
[In MoveAlways] None [Element MoveAlways in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8) Move operation has no data type.]
[In MoveAlways] Element MoveAlways in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8) Move operation, the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In MoveAlways] The MoveAlways element is an empty tag element, meaning it has no value or data type.
[In MoveAlways] It [MoveAlways element] is distinguished only by the presence or absence of the <MoveAlways/> tag.
[In MoveAlways] The MoveAlways element MUST be included in an ItemOperations request when performing a move operation on a conversation.
[In MoveAlways] A Status element (section 2.2.3.167.7) value of 155 is returned if the MoveAlways element is not included in the ItemOperations request for a move operation.
[In MoveAlways] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [MoveAlways] element.
[In MoveAlways] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [MoveAlways] element.
[In MoveAlways] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [MoveAlways] element.
[In MoveAlways] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [MoveAlways] element.
[In MoveAlways] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [MoveAlways] element.
[In MoveItems] The MoveItems element is a required element in MoveItems command requests and responses that identifies the body of the HTTP POST as containing a MoveItems command (section 2.2.2.11).
[In MoveItems] It [MoveItems element] is the top-level element in the XML stream.
[In MoveItems] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.109] are defined in the Move namespace.
[In MoveItems] None [Element MoveItems in MoveItems command request has no parent element.]
[In MoveItems] Element MoveItems in MoveItems command reques, the child element is Move (section 2.2.3.107.1).
[In MoveItems] Element MoveItems in MoveItems command request, the data type is container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2).
[In MoveItems] Element MoveItems in MoveItems command request, the number allowed is 1…1 (required).
[In MoveItems] None [Element MoveItems in MoveItems command response has no parent element.]
[In MoveItems] Element MoveItems in MoveItems command response, the child element is Response (section 2.2.3.144.4).
[In MoveItems] Element MoveItems in MoveItems command response, the data type is container.
[In MoveItems] Element MoveItems in MoveItems command response, the number allowed is 1…1 (required).
[In MoveItems] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [MoveItems] element.
[In MoveItems] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [MoveItems] element.
[In MoveItems] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [MoveItems] element.
[In MoveItems] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [MoveItems] element.
[In MoveItems] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [MoveItems] element.
[In Name]The Name element is used in the following command requests and responses: Autodiscover command responses (section 2.2.2.1), Search command requests (section 2.2.2.14).
[In Name] The definition of the Name element differs according to the context in which it [Name element] is used.
[In Name] For more details, see section 2.2.3.110.1 and section 2.2.3.110.2.

[In Name(Autodiscover)] The Name element is an optional child element of the Server element in Autodiscover command responses that specifies a URL if the Type element (section 2.2.3.176.1) value is set to "MobileSync".
[In Name(Autodiscover)] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.110.1] are defined in the http://schemas.microsoft.com/exchange/autodiscover/mobilesync/requestschema/2006 namespace.
[In Name(Autodiscover)] Element Name in Autodiscover command response (section 2.2.2.1), the parent element is Server (section 2.2.3.154).
[In Name(Autodiscover)] None [Element Name in Autodiscover command response (section 2.2.2.1) has no child element.]
[In Name(Autodiscover)] Element Name in Autodiscover command response (section 2.2.2.1), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7).
[In Name(Autodiscover)] Element Name in Autodiscover command response (section 2.2.2.1), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In Name(Autodiscover)] If the Type element value is "MobileSync", then the Name element specifies the URL that conveys the protocol.
[In Name(Autodiscover)] If the Type element value is "CertEnroll", then the Name element value is NULL.
[In Name(Autodiscover)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Name(Autodiscover)] element.
[In Name(Autodiscover)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Name(Autodiscover)] element.
[In Name(Autodiscover)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Name(Autodiscover)] element.

[In Name(Search)] The Name element is a required child element of the Store element in Search command requests that specifies the store to search.
[In Name(Search)] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.110.2] are defined in the Search namespace.
[In Name(Search)] Element Name in Search command request (section 2.2.2.14), the parent element is Store (section 2.2.3.163.2).
[In Name(Search)] None [Element Name in Search command request (section 2.2.2.14) has no child element.]
[In Name(Search)] Element Name in Search command request (section 2.2.2.14), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6).
[In Name(Search)] Element Name in Search command request (section 2.2.2.14), the number allowed is 1...1 (required).
[In Name(Search)] The Name element value can be up to 256 characters in length.
[In Name(Search)] The Name element accepts the following values [Mailbox, Document Library, GAL].
[In Name(Search)] Mailbox—The client specifies "Mailbox" when it intends to search the mailbox.
[In Name(Search)] Document Library—The client specifies "DocumentLibrary" when it intends to search a Windows SharePoint Services or UNC library.
[In Name(Search)] GAL—The client specifies "GAL" when it intends to search the Global Address List.
[In Name(Search)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Name(Search)] element.
[In Name(Search)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Name(Search)] element.
[In Name(Search)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Name(Search)] element.
[In Name(Search)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Name(Search)] element.
[In Name(Search)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Name(Search)] element.

[In Name (SmartForward and Sync)] All elements referenced in this section are defined in the ComposeMail namespace.
[In Name (SmartForward and Sync)] Element Name in SmartForward command request (section 2.2.1.19), the parent element is Forwardee (section 2.2.3.78).
[In Name (SmartForward and Sync)] None [Element Name in SmartForward command request (section 2.2.1.19) has no child element.]
[In Name (SmartForward and Sync)] Element Name in SmartForward command request (section 2.2.1.19), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7).
[In Name (SmartForward and Sync)] Element Name in SmartForward command request (section 2.2.1.19), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In Name (SmartForward and Sync)] Element Name in Sync command response (section 2.2.1.21), the parent element is Forwardee (section 2.2.3.78).
[In Name (SmartForward and Sync)] None [Element Name in Sync command response (section 2.2.1.21) has no child element.]
[In Name (SmartForward and Sync)] Element Name in Sync command response (section 2.2.1.21), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7).
[In Name (SmartForward and Sync)] Element Name in Sync command response (section 2.2.1.21), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In Name (SmartForward and Sync)] Protocol version 12.1 does not supports this [Name] element.
[In Name (SmartForward and Sync)] Protocol version 14.0 does not supports this [Name] element.

[In Name (SmartForward and Sync)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Name] element.
