[In Office] The Office element is used in the following command responses: § Find command responses (section 2.2.1.2) § Search command responses (section 2.2.1.16)
[In Office] The definition of the Office element differs according to the context in which it is used.
[In Office] For more details, see section 2.2.3.121.1 and section 2.2.3.121.2.
[In Office (Find)] The Office element in the GAL namespace is an optional child element of the find:Properties element in Find command responses.
[In Office (Find)] The Office element is only present in response to Find command requests that contain the GALSearchCriterion element as specified in section 2.2.3.82.
[In Office (Find)] It[Office] contains the office location or number of a recipient in the GAL that matched the search criteria from the corresponding Find command request.
[In Office (Find)] Element Office in Find command response (section 2.2.1.2), the parent element is Properties (section 2.2.3.139.1).
[In Office (Find)] None [Element in Find command response (section 2.2.1.2) has no child element.]
[In Office (Find)] Element Office in Find command response (section 2.2.1.2), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7).
[In Office (Find)] Element Office in Find command response (section 2.2.1.2), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In Office (Find)] Protocol version 12.1 does not supports this [Office] element.
[In Office (Find)] Protocol version 14.0 does not supports this [Office] element.
[In Office (Find)] Protocol version 14.1 does not supports this [Office] element.
[In Office (Find)] Protocol version 16.0 does not supports this [Office] element.
[In Office (Find)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Office] element.
[In Office] The Office element in the GAL namespace is an optional child element of the search:Properties element in Search command responses.
[In Office (Search)] The Office element is only present in response to Search command requests that contain a search:Name element with a value of "GAL", as specified in section 2.2.3.114.2.
[In Office] It [Office element] contains the office location or number of a recipient in the GAL that matched the search criteria from the corresponding Search command request.
[In Office] Element Office in Search command response (section 2.2.2.15), the parent element is Properties (section 2.2.3.132.2)
[In Office] None [Element Office in Search command response (section 2.2.2.15) has no child element]
[In Office] Element Office in Search command response (section 2.2.2.15), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7)
[In Office] Element Office in Search command response (section 2.2.2.15), number allowed 0...1 (optional)
[In Office] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Office] element.
[In Office] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Office] element.
[In Office] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Office] element.
[In Office] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Office] element.
[In Office] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Office] element.

[In Oof] The Oof element is an optional child element of the Setttings element in Settings command requests and responses that specifies a named property node for retrieving and setting Out of Office (OOF) information.
[In Oof] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.112] are defined in the Settings namespace.
[In Oof] Element Oof in Settings command request (section 2.2.2.16), the parent element is Settings (section 2.2.3.153.2).
[In Oof] Element Oof in Settings command request (section 2.2.2.16), the child elements are Get (section 2.2.3.75), Set (section 2.2.3.152).
[In Oof] Element Oof in Settings command request (section 2.2.2.16), the data type is container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2).
[In Oof] Element Oof in Settings command request (section 2.2.2.16), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In Oof] Element Oof in Settings command response, the parent element is Settings.
[In Oof] Element Oof in Settings command response, the child elements are Get, Status (section 2.2.3.167.14).
[In Oof] Element Oof in Settings command response, the data type is container.
[In Oof] Element Oof in Settings command response, the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In Oof] The Settings command request supports Get and Set operations for the Oof element.
[In Oof] The Oof element enables a user to do the following:
[In Oof] [The Oof element enables a user to do the following:] Specify whether the user is currently out of office.
[In Oof] [The Oof element enables a user to do the following:] Schedule an out of office message to be sent between a particular start date and end date.
[In Oof] [The Oof element enables a user to do the following:] Specify the message that is to be shown to various audiences when the mobile device user is out of office.
[In Oof] Oof Get Request and Response
[In Oof] The Get element within the Oof element of a Settings command request enables the client to retrieve OOF information from the server.
[In Oof] The client specifies the body type (BodyType element (section 2.2.3.17)) to be retrieved and the server will return all OOF information and messages.
[In Oof] In a Settings command Oof Get response, there is one OofMessage node (section 2.2.3.113) per audience.
[In Oof] If the sender group is allowed, but is disabled and has no reply message (specified by the ReplyMessage element (section 2.2.3.140)), an OofMessage node is still reported to the client.
[In Oof] If the client does not receive a group, it is presumably because the client does not have permission to enter settings for that group;
[In Oof] In such a case [client does not have permission to enter settings for that group], any attempt to set those properties results in an Access Denied status code.
[In Oof] Oof Set Request and Response

[In Oof]The Set element within the Oof element of a Settings command request enables the client to set the OOF status, time OOF, and OOF messages for one or more of the following groups: Internal, External Known Senders (such as contacts), External Unknown Senders.
[In Oof] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Oof] element.
[In Oof] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Oof] element.
[In Oof] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Oof] element.
[In Oof] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Oof] element.
[In Oof] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Oof] element.
[In OofMessage] The OofMessage element is an optional child element of the Set element in Settings command requests and an optional child element of the Get element in Settings command responses.
[In OofMessage] It [OofMessage element] specifies the OOF message for a particular audience.
[In OofMessage] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.113] are defined in the Settings namespace.
[In OofMessage] Element OofMessage in Settings command Oof request (section 2.2.2.16), the parent element is Set (section 2.2.3.152).

[In OofMessage] Element OofMessage in Settings command Oof request (section 2.2.2.16), the child elements are AppliesToInternal (section 2.2.3.14), AppliesToExternalKnown (section 2.2.3.12), AppliesToExternalUnknown (section 2.2.3.13), Enabled (section 2.2.3.56), ReplyMessage (section 2.2.3.136), BodyType (section 2.2.3.17).
[In OofMessage] Element OofMessage in Settings command Oof request (section 2.2.2.16), the data type is container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2).
[In OofMessage] Element OofMessage in Settings command Oof request (section 2.2.2.16), the number allowed is 0...3 (optional).
[In OofMessage] Element OofMessage in Settings command Oof response, the parent element is Get (section 2.2.3.79).
[In OofMessage] Element OofMessage in Settings command Oof response, the child elements are AppliesToInternal, AppliesToExternalKnown , AppliesToExternalUnknown, Enabled, ReplyMessage, BodyType.
[In OofMessage] Element OofMessage in Settings command Oof response, the data type is container.
[In OofMessage] Element OofMessage in Settings command Oof response, the number allowed is 0...3 (optional).
[In OofMessage] The Oof property (section 2.2.3.116) supports the following three audiences [Internal, Known external, Unknown external] for an OOF message:<11>
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirement: MS-ASCMD_R5194.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In OofMessage] Internal—A user who is in the same organization as the sending user.
[In OofMessage] Known external—A user who is outside the sending user's organization, but is represented in the sending user's contacts.
[In OofMessage] Unknown external—A user who is outside the sending user's organization and is not represented in the sending user's contacts.

[In OofMessage] The presence of one of the following elements [AppliesToInternal, AppliesToExternalKnown, AppliesToExternalUnknown], which are mutually exclusive, indicates the audience to which an OOF message pertains:
[In OofMessage] AppliesToInternal—The OOF message is relevant to an internal audience.
[In OofMessage] AppliesToExternalKnown—The OOF message is relevant to a known external audience.
[In OofMessage] AppliesToExternalUnknown—The OOF message is relevant to an unknown external audience.
[In OofMessage] There is one OofMessage node per audience in a Settings command Oof Get response.
[In OofMessage] If a sender group is allowed, but is disabled and has no reply message (specified by the ReplyMessage element), an OofMessage node is reported to the client.

[In OofMessage] If [AppliesToExternalKnown or] AppliesToExternalUnknown are not allowed and are disabled by the administrator but are sent by the client in the Settings command Oof Set request, the response returns a successful Status element (section 2.2.3.167.14) value of 1 even though the user does not have access to these settings.

[In OofMessage] If AppliesToExternalKnown [or AppliesToExternalUnknown] are not allowed and are disabled by the administrator but are sent by the client in the Settings command Oof Set request, the response returns a successful Status element (section 2.2.3.162.14) value of 1 even though the user does not have access to these settings.
[In OofMessage] Similarly, the AppliesToExternalKnown element and the AppliesToExternalUnknown element are returned to the client the response even if the sender group is not allowed and is disabled.
[In OofMessage] In a Settings command Oof Set request, the client MUST NOT include the same AppliesTo* element in more than one OofMessage element.
[In OofMessage] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [OofMessage] element.
[In OofMessage] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [OofMessage] element.
[In OofMessage] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [OofMessage] element.
[In OofMessage] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [OofMessage] element.
[In OofMessage] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [OofMessage] element.
[In OofState] The OofState element is an optional child element of the Set element in Settings command requests and an optional child element of the Get element in Settings command responses.
[In OofState] It [OofState] specifies the availability of the Oof property (section 2.2.3.112).
[In OofState] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.114] are defined in the Settings namespace.
[In OofState] Element OofState in Settings command Oof request (section 2.2.2.16), the parent element is Set (section 2.2.3.152).
[In OofState] None [Element OofState in Settings command Oof request (section 2.2.2.16) has no child element .]
[In OofState] Element OofState in Settings command Oof request (section 2.2.2.16), the data type is integer ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.5).
[In OofState] Element OofState in Settings command Oof request (section 2.2.2.16), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In OofState] Element OofState in Settings command Oof response, the parent element is Get (section 2.2.3.79).
[In OofState] None [Element OofState in Settings command Oof response has no child element.]
[In OofState] Element OofState in Settings command Oof response, the data type is integer.
[In OofState] Element OofState in Settings command Oof response, the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In OofState] The following table lists the valid values [0, 1, 2] for OofState.
[In OofState] Value 0 means The Oof property is disabled.
[In OofState] Value 1 means The Oof property is global.
[In OofState] Value 2 means The Oof property is time-based.
[In OofState] The OofState element value MUST be set to 2 if the StartTime (section 2.2.3.166.1) and EndTime (section 2.2.3.58.2) elements are present.
[In OofState] If the OofState element value is not set to 2 and the StartTime and EndTime elements are submitted in the request, the client does receive a successful response message.
[In OofState] If the OofState element value is not set to 2 and the StartTime and EndTime elements are submitted in the request, the server does not store the StartTime and EndTime element values.
[In OofState] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [OofState] element.
[In OofState] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [OofState] element.
[In OofState] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [OofState] element.
[In OofState] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [OofState] element.
[In OofState] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [OofState] element.

[In Options] The Options element is used in the following command requests: § Find command requests (section 2.2.1.2) § GetItemEstimate command requests (section 2.2.1.9) § ItemOperations command requests (section 2.2.1.10) § ResolveRecipients command requests (section 2.2.1.15) § Search command requests (section 2.2.1.16) § Sync command requests (section 2.2.1.21)
[In Options] The definition of the Options element differs according to the context in which it [Options element] is used.

[In Options (Find)] The Options element is an optional child element of the MailBoxSearchCriterion element in Find command requests that contains the search options.
[In Options (Find)] Elements referenced in this section are defined in the Find namespace.
[In Options (Find)] Element Options in Find command request (section 2.2.1.2), the parent element is MailBoxSearchCriterion (section 2.2.3.99) or GALSearchCriterion (section 2.2.3.82).
[In Options (Find)] Element Options in Find command request (section 2.2.1.2), the child elements are Range (section 2.2.3.143.1) DeepTraversal (section 2.2.3.41.1) Picture (section 2.2.3.135.1)
[In Options (Find)] Element Options in Find command request (section 2.2.1.2), the data type is container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2) .
[In Options (Find)] Element Options in Find command request (section 2.2.1.2), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In Options (Find)] Protocol version 12.1 does not supports this [Options] element.
[In Options (Find)] Protocol version 14.0 does not supports this [Options] element.
[In Options (Find)] Protocol version 14.1 does not supports this [Options] element.
[In Options (Find)] Protocol version 16.0 does not supports this [Options] element.
[In Options (Find)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Options] element.

[In Options(GetItemEstimate)] The airsync:Options element<55> is an optional child element of the Collection element in GetItemEstimate command requests that contains elements that filter the results of the GetItemEstimate command.

[In Options(GetItemEstimate)] Elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.115.1] are defined in the GetItemEstimate namespace, except where otherwise indicated by the presence of a namespace prefix (as defined in section 2.2.1).
[In Options(GetItemEstimate)] Element Options in GetItemEstimate command request (section 2.2.2.7), the parent element is Collection (section 2.2.3.29.1).

[In Options(GetItemEstimate)] Element Options in GetItemEstimate command request (section 2.2.2.7), the child elements are airsync:Class (section 2.2.3.27.1), airsync:FilterType (section 2.2.3.64.1), airsync:MaxItems (section 2.2.3.93.1).
[In Options(GetItemEstimate)] Element Options in GetItemEstimate command request (section 2.2.2.7), the data type is container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2).
[In Options(GetItemEstimate)] Element Options in GetItemEstimate command request (section 2.2.2.7), the number allowed is 0...2 (optional).
[In Options(GetItemEstimate)] This [Options] element is optional.
[In Options(GetItemEstimate)] However, when it [Options element] is present, it [Options element] MUST include at least one child element.
[In Options(GetItemEstimate)] The airsync:Options element appears only in requests to the server from the client.

[In Options(GetItemEstimate)] If the airsync:Options element is not included in a request, then the GetItemEstimate command (section 2.2.2.8) will enumerate all of the items within the collection, without any filter (up to a maximum of 512 items).
[In Options(GetItemEstimate)] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [Options(GetItemEstimate)] element.
[In Options(GetItemEstimate)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Options(GetItemEstimate)] element.
[In Options(GetItemEstimate)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Options(GetItemEstimate)] element.
[In Options(GetItemEstimate)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Options(GetItemEstimate)] element.
[In Options(ItemOperations)] The Options element is an optional child element of the EmptyFolderContents element, the Fetch element, and the Move element in ItemOperations command requests.
[In Options(ItemOperations)] It [Options element] contains the options for the EmptyFolderContents operation, the fetch operation, or the move operation.

[In Options(ItemOperations)] Elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.115.2] are defined in the ItemOperations namespace, except where otherwise indicated by the presence of a namespace prefix (as defined in section 2.2.1).
[In Options(ItemOperations)] Element Options in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8) EmptyFolderContents operation, the parent element is EmptyFolderContents (section 2.2.3.55).
[In Options(ItemOperations)] Element Options in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8) EmptyFolderContents operation, the child element is DeleteSubFolders (section 2.2.3.44).
[In Options(ItemOperations)] Element Options in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8) EmptyFolderContents operation, the data type is container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2).
[In Options(ItemOperations)] Element Options in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8) EmptyFolderContents operation, the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In Options(ItemOperations)] Element Options in ItemOperations command request fetch operation, the parent element is Fetch (section 2.2.3.63.1).

[In Options(ItemOperations)] Element Options in ItemOperations command request fetch operation, the child elements are Schema (section 2.2.3.145), Range (section 2.2.3.130.1), UserName (section 2.2.3.177.1), Password (section 2.2.3.122.1), airsync:MIMESupport (section 2.2.3.94.1), airsyncbase:BodyPreference ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.7), airsyncbase:BodyPartPreference ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.6), rm:RightsManagementSupport<56> ([MS-ASRM] section 2.2.2.15).
[In Options(ItemOperations)] Element Options in ItemOperations command request fetch operation, the data type is container.
[In Options(ItemOperations)] Element Options in ItemOperations command request fetch operation, the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In Options(ItemOperations)] Element Options in ItemOperations command request Move operation, the parent element is Move (section 2.2.3.107.1).
[In Options(ItemOperations)] Element Options in ItemOperations command request Move operation, the child element is MoveAlways (section 2.2.3.108).
[In Options(ItemOperations)] Element Options in ItemOperations command request Move operation, the data type is container.
[In Options(ItemOperations)] Element Options in ItemOperations command request Move operation, the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In Options(ItemOperations)] If the client specifies an option that is invalid for the parent element, the server returns a Status element (section 2.2.3.167.7) value of 2.

[In Options(ItemOperations)] The following options [Schema, Range, UserName , Password, airsync:MIMESupport, airsyncbase:BodyPreference, airsyncbase:BodyPartPreference, airsyncbase:FileReference] are supported for the fetch operation.
[In Options(ItemOperations)] Schema: Per-class settings on format for fetch results.
[In Options(ItemOperations)] Schema: This protocol [MS-ASCMD] supports schemas for Personal Information Manager (PIM) items only;
[In Options(ItemOperations)] Schema: it [this protocol] does not support schemas for document library items or attachments.
[In Options(ItemOperations)] Schema: Supports all top-level property nodes.
[In Options(ItemOperations)] For more information about the Schema element, section 2.2.3.145.
[In Options(ItemOperations)] Byte ranges: Facilitates a checkpoint to improve the reliability of large data downloads.
[In Options(ItemOperations)] Byte ranges: This protocol [MS-ASCMD] supports ranges for document library items and attachments;
[In Options(ItemOperations)] Byte ranges: it [this protocol] does not support ranges for other item types—that is, PIM items, such as email, contact, calendar, or task items.
[In Options(ItemOperations)] Schema: For attachments, the range applies to the file content.
[In Options(ItemOperations)] Schema: For document library items, this applies to the file content.
[In Options(ItemOperations)] For more information about the Range element, section 2.2.3.130.1.
[In Options(ItemOperations)] User name and password: Identifies the username and password required to fetch the desired item.
[In Options(ItemOperations)] For more information about UserName and Password elements, see section 2.2.3.177.1 and section 2.2.3.122.1 respectively.
[In Options(ItemOperations)] MIME support: Indicates whether the server returns MIME content for S/MIME-only messages, all messages, or no messages
[In Options(ItemOperations)] For more information about the airsync:MIMESupport element, section 2.2.3.100.1.
[In Options(ItemOperations)] Body format preference: Per-class settings on preferred body format.
[In Options(ItemOperations)] Body format preference: This protocol [MS-ASCMD] supports body preferences for PIM items only;
[In Options(ItemOperations)] Body format preference: it [this protocol] does not support body format preferences for document library items or attachments.
[In Options(ItemOperations)] For more information about the airsyncbase:BodyPreference element, see [MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.7.
[In Options(ItemOperations)] Body part preference: Per email settings on preferred body part format.

[In Options(ItemOperations)] Body part preference: When the airsyncbase:BodyPartPreference element is specified, the server returns the unique parts of the email message body (2) with reference to the parent item across all collections.
[In Options(ItemOperations)] For more information about the airsyncbase:BodyPartPreference element, see [MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.6.
[In Options(ItemOperations)] Rights management support: Indicates whether the device has information rights management enabled.

[In Options(ItemOperations)] Rights management support: If information rights management is enabled, the client requests that the information rights management content be returned in its schematized form in the response.
[In Options(ItemOperations)] If the airsyncbase:FileReference element (section 2.2.3.8) is present, then the Range element is the only valid child element of the Options element.
[In Options(ItemOperations)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Options(ItemOperations)] element.
[In Options(ItemOperations)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Options(ItemOperations)] element.
[In Options(ItemOperations)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Options(ItemOperations)] element.
[In Options(ItemOperations)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Options(ItemOperations)] element.
[In Options(ItemOperations)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Options(ItemOperations)] element.

[In Options(ResolveRecipients)] Element Options in ResolveRecipients command request (section 2.2.2.13), the data type is container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2).
[In Options(ResolveRecipients)] Element Options in ResolveRecipients command request (section 2.2.2.13), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).

[In Options(ResolveRecipients)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Options(ResolveRecipients)] element.
[In Options(ResolveRecipients)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Options(ResolveRecipients)] element.
[In Options(ResolveRecipients)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Options(ResolveRecipients)] element.
[In Options(Search)] The Options element is an optional child element of the Store element in Search command requests that contains the search options.

[In Options(Search)] Elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.115.4] are defined in the Search namespace, except where otherwise indicated by the presence of a namespace prefix (as defined in section 2.2.1).
[In Options(Search)] Element Options in Search command request (section 2.2.2.14), the parent element is Store (section 2.2.3.163.2).

[In Options(Search)] Element Options in Search command request (section 2.2.2.14), the child elements are airsync:MIMESupport (section 2.2.3.100.2), airsyncbase:BodyPreference ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.7), airsyncbase:BodyPartPreference ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.6), rm:RightsManagementSupport<58> ([MS-ASRM] section 2.2.2.15), Range (section 2.2.3.130.2), UserName (section 2.2.3.177.2), Password (section 2.2.3.122.2), DeepTraversal (section 2.2.3.41), RebuildResults (section 2.2.3.131),Picture (section 2.2.3.125.2).

[In Options(Search)] Element Options in Search command request (section 2.2.2.14), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).

[In Options(Search)] The UserName element and Password element can only be sent in the request after receiving a Status element (section 2.2.3.162.12) value of 14 (see section 2.2.3.162.12 for more details).
[In Options(Search)] The server requires these credentials [The UserName element and Password element] to access the requested resources.
[In Options(Search)] The client MUST only send these [requested resources] over a secure or trusted connection, and only in response to a Status value of 14.
[In Options(Search)] The UserName and Password element values are defined as strings consisting of at most 100 characters.
[In Options(Search)] The supported options vary according to the message store that is being searched.
[In Options(Search)] The following table lists the valid options for each store.
[In Options(Search)] Options: Range, UserName, Password, Picture for store GAL.
[In Options(Search)] Options: Range, Deep,Traversal, RebuildResults, airsyncbase:BodyPreference, airsyncbase:BodyPartPreference, rm:RightsManagementSupport<59> for store Mailbox.
[In Options(Search)] Options: Range, UserName, Password for store Document Library.
[In Options(Search)] The airsyncbase:BodyPartPreference element is only valid in Search command requests that include a ConversationId element, as specified in section 2.2.3.35.2.

[In Options(Search)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Options(Search)] element.

[In Options(Search)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Options(Search)] element.
[In Options(Search)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Options(Search)] element.

[In Options(Sync)] The Options element is an optional child element of the Collection element in Sync command requests that contains elements that control certain aspects of how the synchronization is performed.

[In Options(Sync)] Elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.115.5] are defined in the AirSync namespace, except where otherwise indicated by the presence of a namespace prefix (as defined in section 2.2.1).
[In Options(Sync)] Element Options in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.19), the parent element is Collection (section 2.2.3.29.2).

[In Options(Sync)] Element Options in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.19), the child elements are FilterType (section 2.2.3.64.2), Conflict (section2.2.3.34), MIMETruncation (section2.2.3.101), MIMESupport (section 2.2.3.100.3), Class (section 2.2.3.27.5), MaxItems (section2.2.3.93.2), airsyncbase:BodyPreference ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.7) airsyncbase:BodyPartPreference ([MS-ASAIRS] section2.2.2.6), rm:RightsManagementSupport<60> ([MS-ASRM] section 2.2.2.15).
[In Options(Sync)] Element Options in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.19), the data type is container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2).
[In Options(Sync)] Element Options in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.19), the number allowed is 0...2 (optional).
[In Options(Sync)] This [Options] element is optional.
[In Options(Sync)] if it [Options element] is present, it [Options element] SHOULD include at least one child element.
[In Options(Sync)] The Options element appears only in requests to the server from the client.
[In Options(Sync)] Synchronization options enable the client to specify truncation and content settings.

[In Options(Sync)] These settings [Synchronization options enable the client to specify truncation and content settings] are encapsulated within a airsyncbase:BodyPreference child element, as specified in [MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.7.

[In Options(Sync)] Because synchronization options are specified on a collection, the client can specify a unique airsyncbase:BodyPreference element value for each collection that it is being synchronized.
[In Options(Sync)] For more details about the airsyncbase:BodyPreference element, see [MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.7.
[In Options(Sync)] The server preserves the Options block across requests, using a concept referred to as "sticky options".
[In Options(Sync)] If the Options block is not included in a request, the previous Options block is used.
[In Options(Sync)] Whenever the client specifies new options by including an Options block in the request, the server MUST replace the original Options block with the new Options block.

[In Options(Sync)] If two Options elements are included in a single Sync command request, one of the Options elements MUST specify the synchronization options for the SMS class, while the other Options element specifies the options for the default class of the given folder.
[In Options(Sync)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Options(Sync)] element.
[In Options(Sync)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Options(Sync)] element.
[In Options(Sync)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Options(Sync)] element.
[In Options(Sync)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Options(Sync)] element.
[In Options(Sync)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Options(Sync)] element.

[In OS] The OS element is an optional child element of the Set element in Settings command requests that specifies the operating system of the client device.
[In OS] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.117] are defined in the Settings namespace.
[In OS] Element OS in Settings command DeviceInformation request (section 2.2.2.16), the parent element is Set (section 2.2.3.152).
[In OS] None [Element OS in Settings command DeviceInformation request (section 2.2.2.16) has no child element.]
[In OS] Element OS in Settings command DeviceInformation request (section 2.2.2.16), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6).
[In OS] Element OS in Settings command DeviceInformation request (section 2.2.2.16), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In OS] Some information about the operating system of the device can be collected from the user agent string that is associated with requests from that client.
[In OS] The mapping from user agent to operating system is not one to one, however, and therefore does not provide sufficient information to troubleshoot and establish an inventory.
[In OS] The OS element is a string value (up to 1024 characters in length) that enables the client to precisely specify the operating system of the device.
[In OS] The server does not perform any validation of this value [the string value of OS element].
[In OS] But clients SHOULD <12> use the following convention: <Operating System Product Name> <Operating System Major Version> <Operating System Minor Version>.
[In OS] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [OS] element.
[In OS] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [OS] element.
[In OS] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [OS] element.
[In OS] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [OS] element.
[In OS] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [OS] element.

[In OSLanguage] Element OSLanguage in Settings command DeviceInformation request (section 2.2.2.16), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In OSLanguage] Knowledge of the user's language facilitates localization if the server is required to send localizable content to the client device.
[In OSLanguage] The OS element value can be up to 1024 characters in length.
[In OSLanguage] The server does not validate the value of the OSLanguage element.

[In ParentId] The ParentId element is used in the following command requests and responses: FolderCreate command requests (section 2.2.2.2), FolderSync command responses (section 2.2.2.4), FolderUpdate command requests (section 2.2.2.5).

[In ParentId(FolderCreate)] The server ID of the parent folder is obtained from the ServerId element (section 2.2.3.151.3) of a previous FolderSync command (section 2.2.2.4).

[In ParentId(FolderCreate)] The ParentId element value can be up to 64 characters in length.

[In ParentId(FolderCreate)] Element ParentId in FolderCreate command request (section 2.2.2.2), the number allowed is 1…1 (required).

[In Part] The Part element is an optional child element of the Properties element or the airsyncbase:Body element in ItemOperations command responses that specifies an integer index into the metadata of the multipart response.
[In Part] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.120] are defined in the ItemOperations namespace.
[In Part] Element Part in ItemOperations command response (section 2.2.2.9) fetch operation, the parent elements are Properties (section 2.2.3.132.1) , airsyncbase:Body ([MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.9).
[In Part] None [Element Part in ItemOperations command response (section 2.2.2.9) fetch operation has no child element.]
[In Part] Element Part in ItemOperations command response (section 2.2.2.9) fetch operation, the data type is integer ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6).
[In Part] Element Part in ItemOperations command response (section 2.2.2.9) fetch operation, the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In Part] The Part element is present only in a multipart ItemOperations response.
[In Part] When the item being fetched is located in a document library, the Part element is a child of the Properties element.

[In Part] When the item being fetched is an attachment located in a mailbox, the Part element is a child of the Properties element if the item's data is not requested[, and is a child of the airsyncbase:Body element if the item's data is requested].

[In Part] When the item being fetched is an attachment located in a mailbox, the Part element [is a child of the Properties element if the item's data is not requested, and] is a child of the airsyncbase:Body element if the item's data is requested.
[In Part] The Part element can be used to locate the [start, end] tuple that specifies the starting byte and ending byte for this item's binary content in the command response.
[In Part] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Part] element.
[In Part] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Part] element.
[In Part] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Part] element.
[In Part] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Part] element.
[In Part] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Part] element.

[In Partial] The Partial element is an optional child element of the Sync element in Sync command requests that indicates to the server that the client sent a partial list of collections, in which case the server obtains the rest of the collections from its cache.
[In Partial] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.121] are defined in the AirSync namespace.
[In Partial] Element Partial in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.19), the parent element is Sync (section 2.2.3.165).
[In Partial] None [Element Partial in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.19) has no child element.]
[In Partial] None [Element Partial in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.19) has no data type.]
[In Partial] Element Partial in Sync command request (section 2.2.2.19), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In Partial] The Partial element is an empty tag element, meaning it has no value or data type.
[In Partial] It [Partial element] is distinguished only by the presence or absence of the <Partial/> tag.
[In Partial] The client MUST NOT send a Partial element without any other elements in the Sync request.

[In Partial] A Sync command request is valid with only a Partial element and either a Wait element (section 2.2.3.182) or HeartbeatInterval element (section 2.2.3.79.2), a WindowSize element (section 2.2.3.183), a Collections element (section 2.2.3.31.2), or any combination of the three. A Sync command request requires, at least, either a Partial element or a Collections element.

[In Partial] When a Sync command request includes a Partial element but does not specify some collections, the settings and synchronization key for each of those unspecified collections specified in the previous Sync request remain the same as specified in the previous request.

[In Partial] Such a request [When a Sync command request includes a Partial element but does not specify some collections, the settings and synchronization key for each of those unspecified collections specified in the previous Sync request remain the same as specified in the previous request.] is equivalent to a request that specifies each of these collections with the same settings and synchronization key as in the previous request.

[In Partial] This [When a Sync command request includes a Partial element but does not specify some collections, the settings and synchronization key for each of those unspecified collections specified in the previous Sync request remain the same as specified in the previous request is equivalent to a request that specifies each of these collections with the same settings and synchronization key as in the previous request] enables the client to modify some aspect of the previous request (one of the collections, the wait time, the global window size, and so on) without sending up every unchanged collection.
[In Partial] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Partial] element.
[In Partial] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Partial] element.
[In Partial] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Partial] element.
[In Partial] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Partial] element.
[In Partial] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Partial] element.

[In Properties(Search)] The Search command response Properties element is a container for properties that apply to an individual entry that matches the Query element (section 2.2.3.129) search string.
[In Properties(Search)] For example, the Properties element contains an element for each nonempty, text-valued GAL property that is attached to the matching GAL entry.
[In Properties(Search)] Only those properties that are attached to the specific GAL entry are returned.
[In Properties(Search)] Therefore different sets of properties can be returned in the response XML for different matching GAL entries.
[In Properties(Search)] Each element in the Properties container is scoped to the appropriate namespace that is specified in the top-level Search element (section 2.2.3.146).
[In Properties(Search)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Properties(Search)] element.

[In Query (Find)] Protocol version 16.0 does not supports this [Query] element.
[In Query (Find)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Query] element.

[In Query (Search)] The Query element is a required child element of the Store element in Search command requests that specifies the keywords to use for matching the entries in the store that is being searched.
[In Query (Search)] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.129] are defined in the Search namespace.
[In Query (Search)] Element Query in Search command request (section 2.2.2.14), the parent element is Store (section 2.2.3.163.2).
[In Query (Search)] Element Query in Search command request (section 2.2.2.14), the child elements are And (section 2.2.3.10), EqualTo (section 2.2.3.59).
[In Query (Search)] Element Query in Search command request (section 2.2.2.14), the data type is container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2).
[In Query (Search)] Element Query in Search command request (section 2.2.2.14), the number allowed is 1...1 (required).
[In Query (Search)] The value of the Query element is used as a prefix-string matching pattern.
[In Query (Search)] The value of the Query element returns entries that match the beginning of the string.
[In Query (Search)] For example, searching for "John" would match "John Frum" or "Barry Johnson", but would not match "James Littlejohn".
[In Query (Search)] All nonempty text properties in the GAL that are indexed by using ANR are compared with the Query element value.
[In Query (Search)] Search comparisons are performed by using case-insensitive matching.

[In Query (Search)] For a Windows SharePoint Services document library search, this protocol [MS-ASCMD] supports queries of the following form: LinkId == value, where value specifies the URL of the item or folder and LinkId indicates that the value is to be compared to the link ID property.

[In Query (Search)] For mailbox search, the query syntax is as follows: Folders can be specified in the following ways: Specified ID, Specified folder and subfolders, All email folders, including Draft, Inbox and subfolders, Outbox, and Sent Items.

[In Query (Search)] [For mailbox search, the query syntax is as follows:] The basic keyword query can be composed of the following: The basic operator: And (section 2.2.3.10), A dateTime filter specified by using the GreaterThan (section 2.2.3.78) and LessThan elements (section 2.2.3.87), FreeText elements (section 2.2.3.73) that contain keywords.
[In Query (Search)] The basic keyword query is executed against all indexed properties.
[In Query (Search)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Query] element.
[In Query (Search)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Query] element.
[In Query (Search)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Query] element.
[In Query (Search)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Query] element.
[In Query (Search)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Query] element.

[In Range] The Range element is used in the following command requests and responses:§ Find command requests and responses (section 2.2.1.2) § ItemOperations command requests and responses (section 2.2.1.10) § Search command requests and responses (section 2.2.1.16)
[In Range] The definition of the Range element differs according to the context in which it [Range element] is used.
[In Range] For more details, see section 2.2.3.143.1, section 2.2.3.143.2 and section 2.2.3.143.3.
[In Range (Find)] The Range element is an optional child element of the Options element in Find command requests that specifies the maximum number of matching entries to return.
[In Range (Find)] The Range element is an optional child element of the Response element in Find command responses that specifies the number of matching entries that are being returned.
[In Range (Find)] All elements referenced in this section are defined in the Find namespace.
[In Range (Find)] Element Range in Find command request (section 2.2.1.2), the parent element is Options (section 2.2.3.125.1).
[In Range (Find)] None [Element Range in Find command request (section 2.2.1.2), has no child element.]
[In Range (Find)] Element Range in Find command request (section 2.2.1.2), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7).
[In Range (Find)] Element Range in Find command request (section 2.2.1.2), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In Range (Find)] Element Range in Find command response, the parent element is Response (section 2.2.3.153.2).
[In Range (Find)] None [Element Range in Find command response, has no child element.]
[In Range (Find)] Element Range in Find command response, the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7).
[In Range (Find)] Element Range in Find command response, the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).

[In Range (Find)] The format of the Range element value is in the form of a zero-based index specifier, formed with a nonnegative integer, a hyphen, and another nonnegative integer of higher value than the first.

[In Range (Find)] The m indicates the lowest index of a zero-based array that would hold the items. The n indicates the highest index of a zero-based array that would hold the items. The Range element has possible values for m and n of 0 ≤ m ≤ n ≤ 999.
[In Range (Find)] For example, a Range element value of 0–9 indicates 10 items, and 0–10 indicates 11 items. A Range element value of 0–0 indicates 1 item.
[In Range (Find)] If the client is making its first Find command request for a given search, it MUST start with a Range element value of "0-n".
[In Range (Find)] If the Find request does not include a Range element, the default range value for Mailbox searches is used.
[In Range (Find)] If the Find request includes a Range element, the server can return fewer results than requested.
[In Range (Find)] The Total element SHOULD be used by the client to increment the Range element in subsequent Find requests.
[In Range (Find)] Protocol version 12.1 does not supports this [Range] element.
[In Range (Find)] Protocol version 14.0 does not supports this [Range] element.
[In Range (Find)] Protocol version 14.1 does not supports this [Range] element.
[In Range (Find)] Protocol version 16.0 does not supports this [Range] element.
[In Range (Find)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Range] element.

[In Range(ItemOperations)] The Range element is an optional child element of the Options element in ItemOperations command requests that specifies the range of bytes that the client can receive in response to the fetch operation for a document library item.

[In Range(ItemOperations)] The Range element is an optional child element of the Properties element in ItemOperations command responses that specifies the actual range of bytes for an item that is contained in a given fetch operation.

[In Range(ItemOperations)] Elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.130.1] are defined in the ItemOperations namespace, except where otherwise indicated by the presence of a namespace prefix (as defined in section 2.2.1).
[In Range(ItemOperations)] Element Range in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8) fetch operation, the parent element is Options (section 2.2.3.115.2).
[In Range(ItemOperations)] None [Element Range in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8) fetch operation has no child element.]
[In Range(ItemOperations)] Element Range in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8) fetch operation, the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6).
[In Range(ItemOperations)] Element Range in ItemOperations command request (section 2.2.2.8) fetch operation, the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In Range(ItemOperations)] Element Range in ItemOperations command response fetch operation, the parent element is Properties (section 2.2.3.132.1).
[In Range(ItemOperations)] None [Element Range in ItemOperations command response fetch operation has no child element.]
[In Range(ItemOperations)] Element Range in ItemOperations command response fetch operation, the data type is string.
[In Range(ItemOperations)] Element Range in ItemOperations command response fetch operation, the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In Range(ItemOperations)] The Range element contains a string value in the format "m-n", where m is less or equal to n, and m is the minimum value and n is the maximum value.
[In Range] The byte range is zero-indexed.
[In Range] The first byte is indicated by a 0 (zero).
[In Range(ItemOperations)] The server provides a best effort at fulfilling the request.
[In Range(ItemOperations)] Therefore, the client cannot assume that the byte-range that is specified in the request exactly matches the byte-range that is returned in the response.
[In Range(ItemOperations)] The byte-range that is specified by the server in the response is the authoritative value.
[In Range(ItemOperations)] If the Range element is omitted in the fetch request, the whole item is fetched.
[In Range(ItemOperations)] If the airsyncbase:FileReference element (section 2.2.3.8) is present in the request, then the Range element is the only valid child element of the Options element.
[In Range(ItemOperations)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Range(ItemOperations)] element.
[In Range(ItemOperations)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Range(ItemOperations)] element.
[In Range(ItemOperations)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Range(ItemOperations)] element.
[In Range(ItemOperations)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Range(ItemOperations)] element.
[In Range(ItemOperations)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Range(ItemOperations)] element.
[In Range(Search)] The Range element is an optional child element of the Options element in Search command requests that specifies the maximum number of matching entries to return.
[In Range(Search)] The Range element is an optional child element of the Store element in Search command responses that specifies the number of matching entries that are being returned.
[In Range(Search)] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.130.2] are defined in the Search namespace.
[In Range(Search)] Element Range in Search command request (section 2.2.2.14), the parent element is Options (section 2.2.3.115.4).
[In Range(Search)] None [Element Range in Search command request (section 2.2.2.14) has no child element.]
[In Range(Search)] Element Range in Search command request (section 2.2.2.14), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6).
[In Range(Search)] Element Range in Search command request (section 2.2.2.14), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In Range(Search)] Element Range in Search command response, the parent element is Store (section 2.2.3.168.2).
[In Range(Search)] None [Element Range in Search command response has no child element.]
[In Range(Search)] Element Range in Search command response, the data type is string.
[In Range(Search)] Element Range in Search command response, the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In Range(Search)] The result of including more than one Range element in a Search command request is undefined.
[In Range(Search)] The server MAY return a protocol status error in response to such a command request[more than one Range element in a Search command request].
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirement: MS-ASCMD_R3723.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Range(Search)] The Range element value specifies a number of entries, but indicates different things depending on whether the element is in the request or the response XML.
[In Range(Search)] The format of the Range element value is in the form of a zero-based index specifier, formed with a zero, a hyphen, and another numeric value: "m-n."
[In Range(Search)] The m indicates the lowest index of a zero-based array that would hold the items.
[In Range(Search)] The n indicates the highest index of a zero-based array that would hold the items.
[In Range(Search)] For example, a Range element value of 0–9 indicates 10 items, and 0–10 indicates 11 items.
[In Range(Search)] A Range element value of 0-0 indicates 1 item.
[In Range(Search)] If the request does not include a Range element, the default Range value for each Store type is used.
[In Range(Search)] The following table identifies the default Range values [Mailbox, DocumentLibrary, GAL] and maximum results returned for each Store type.
[In Range(Search)] Store value Mailbox, default range value 0-99, maximun result returned 100.
[In Range(Search)]Store value DocumentLibrary, default range value 0-999, maximum results returned 1000.
[In Range(Search)]Store value GAL, default range value 0-99, maximum results returned 100.

[In Range(Search)] If the Range element value specified in the request exceeds the default range value, a Status element (section 2.2.3.167.12) value of 12 is returned to indicate that the maximum range has been exceeded, as specified in section 2.2.3.167.12.

[In Range(Search)] In the Search command response, the Total element (section 2.2.3.169.2) indicates an estimate of the total number of entries that matched the Query element (section 2.2.3.129) value.
[In Range(Search)] Search results are stored in a search folder (2) on the server.

[In Range(Search)] This way [Search results are stored in a search folder (2) on the server], when a client comes back with the same query but a new row range, rows are pulled from the result set that is currently stored in the search folder.
[In Range(Search)] The entire result set does not have to be rebuilt.
[In Range(Search)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Range(Search)] element.
[In Range(Search)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Range(Search)] element.
[In Range(Search)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Range(Search)] element.
[In Range(Search)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Range(Search)] element.
[In Range(Search)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Range(Search)] element.

[In RebuildResults] The RebuildResults element is an optional child element of the Options element in Search command requests that forces the server to rebuild the search folder (2) that corresponds to a given query.
[In RebuildResults] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.131] are defined in the Search namespace.
[In RebuildResults] Element RebuildResults in Search command request (section 2.2.2.14), the parent element is Options (section 2.2.3.115.4).
[In RebuildResults] None [Element RebuildResults in Search command request (section 2.2.2.14) has no child element.]
[In RebuildResults] None [Element RebuildResults in Search command request (section 2.2.2.14) has no data type.]
[In RebuildResults] Element RebuildResults in Search command request (section 2.2.2.14), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In RebuildResults] The RebuildResults element is an empty tag element, meaning it has no value or data type.
[In RebuildResults] It [RebuildResults element] is distinguished only by the presence or absence of the <RebuildResults/> tag.
[In RebuildResults] The result of including more than one RebuildResults element in a Search command request is undefined.
[In RebuildResults] The server MAY return a protocol status error in response to such a command request [more than one RebuildResults element in a Search command request].
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirement: MS-ASCMD_R3747.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In RebuildResults] The search results (that is, the result set) are stored in a search folder on the server.

[In RebuildResults] This way [The search results (that is, the result set) are stored in a search folder on the server], when a client comes back with the same query but a new row range, rows are pulled from the result set that is currently stored in the search folder.
[In RebuildResults] The entire result set does not have to be rebuilt.
[In RebuildResults] The search folder remains unchanged until the client does one of the following to update the result set: Sends a Search request, specifying a new query.
[In RebuildResults] In this case [Sends a Search request, specifying a new query], the search folder is automatically rebuilt.
[In RebuildResults] The RebuildResults node does not have to be included.
[In RebuildResults] [The search folder remains unchanged until the client does one of the following to update the result set:] Sends a Search request that includes the RebuildResults node.
[In RebuildResults] In this case [Sends a Search request that includes the RebuildResults node], the server is forced to rebuild the search folder.
[In RebuildResults] If a new item is added, the item does not appear in the result set until the result set is updated.
[In RebuildResults] If an item is deleted, the server will filter the deleted item out of the result set.
[In RebuildResults] The client SHOULD send a new Search request with the given query and include the RebuildResults option every few days to ensure accurate results for that query.
[In RebuildResults] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [RebuildResults] element.
[In RebuildResults] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [RebuildResults] element.
[In RebuildResults] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [RebuildResults] element.
[In RebuildResults] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [RebuildResults] element.
[In RebuildResults] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [RebuildResults] element.
[In Recipient] The Recipient element is an optional child element of the Response element in ResolveRecipients command responses that represents a single recipient that has been resolved.
[In Recipient] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.132] are defined in the ResolveRecipients namespace.
[In Recipient] Element Recipient in ResolveRecipients command response (section 2.2.2.14), the parent element is Response (section 2.2.3.144.5).

[In Recipient] Element Recipient in ResolveRecipients command response (section 2.2.2.14), the child elements are Type (section 2.2.3.176.4), DisplayName (section 2.2.3.47.5), EmailAddress (section 2.2.3.53.2), Availability (section 2.2.3.16), Certificates (section 2.2.3.23.1), Picture (section 2.2.3.129.1).
[In Recipient] Element Recipient in ResolveRecipients command response (section 2.2.2.14), the data type is container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2).
[In Recipient] Element Recipient in ResolveRecipients command response (section 2.2.2.14), the number allowed is 0...N (optional).

[In Recipient] One or more Recipient elements are returned to the client in a Response element by the server if the To element specified in the request was either resolved to a distribution list or found to be ambiguous.
[In Recipient] The status code returned in the Response element can be used to determine if the recipient was found to be ambiguous.
[In Recipient] The recipient would be a suggested match if the recipient specified in the request was found to be ambiguous.
[In Recipient] A Certificates element is returned as a child element of the Recipient element if the client requested certificates to be returned in the response.
[In Recipient] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Recipient] element.
[In Recipient] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Recipient] element.
[In Recipient] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Recipient] element.
[In Recipient] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Recipient] element.
[In Recipient] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Recipient] element.
[In RecipientCount] The RecipientCount element is a required child element of the Response element and the Certificates element in ResolveRecipients command responses (section 2.2.2.14).
[In RecipientCount] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.133] are defined in the ResolveRecipients namespace.
[In RecipientCount] Element RecipientCount in ResolveRecipients command response, the parent elements are Response (section 2.2.3.144.5), Certificates (section 2.2.3.23.1).
[In RecipientCount] None [Element RecipientCount in ResolveRecipients command response has no child element.]
[In RecipientCount] Element RecipientCount in ResolveRecipients command response, the data type is integer ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6).
[In RecipientCount] Element RecipientCount in ResolveRecipients command response, the number allowed is 0…1 (optional).
[In RecipientCount] As a child element of the Response element, the RecipientCount element specifies the number of recipients that are returned in the ResolveRecipients command response.
[In RecipientCount] As a child element of the Certificates element, the RecipientCount element specifies the number of members belonging to a distribution list.

[In RecipientCount] It [RecipientCount element] can be used to determine whether all recipients belonging to a distribution list have valid certificates by comparing values of the CertificateCount (section 2.2.3.21) and RecipientCount elements.
[In RecipientCount] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [RecipientCount] element.
[In RecipientCount] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [RecipientCount] element.
[In RecipientCount] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [RecipientCount] element.
[In RecipientCount] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [RecipientCount] element.
[In RecipientCount] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [RecipientCount] element.
[In Redirect] The Redirect element is an optional child element of the Action element in Autodiscover command responses that specifies the SMTP address of the requested user.
[In Redirect] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.134] are defined in the http://schemas.microsoft.com/exchange/autodiscover/mobilesync/requestschema/2006 namespace.
[In Redirect] Element Redirect in Autodiscover command response (section 2.2.2.1), the parent element is Action (section 2.2.3.6).
[In Redirect] None [Element Redirect in Autodiscover command response (section 2.2.2.1) has no child element.]
[In Redirect] Element Redirect in Autodiscover command response (section 2.2.2.1), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7).
[In Redirect] Element Redirect in Autodiscover command response (section 2.2.2.1), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In Redirect] The client device uses the domain part of the address to send a new Autodiscover command request.
[In Redirect] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Redirect] element.
[In Redirect] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Redirect] element.
[In Redirect] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Redirect] element.
[In Redirect] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Redirect] element.
[In Redirect] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Redirect] element.

[In ReplaceMime] The ReplaceMime element is an optional child element of the SmartForward element in SmartForward command requests and an optional child element of the SmartReply element in SmartReply command requests.
[In ReplaceMime] In both contexts, it [ReplaceMime element] specifies whether the client is sending the entire message.
[In ReplaceMime] When the ReplaceMime element is present, the server MUST not include the body or attachments of the original message being forwarded.
[In ReplaceMime] When [ReplaceMime element is] not included, the client MUST append the body of the original message as attachments to the outgoing message.
[In ReplaceMime] The client can use this tag [ReplaceMime element] to indicate whether the message was edited inline, or whether the message had reply/forward text prepended to the source message.
[In ReplaceMime] If the ReplaceMime element is present, the message was edited.
[In ReplaceMime] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.135] are defined in the ComposeMail namespace.
[In ReplaceMime] Element ReplaceMime in SmartForward command request (section 2.2.2.17), the parent element is SmartForward (section 2.2.3.154).
[In ReplaceMime] None [Element ReplaceMime in SmartForward command request (section 2.2.2.17) has no child element.]
[In ReplaceMime] None [Element ReplaceMime in SmartForward command request (section 2.2.2.17) has no data type.]
[In ReplaceMime] Element ReplaceMime in SmartForward command request (section 2.2.2.17), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In ReplaceMime] Element ReplaceMime in SmartReply command request (section 2.2.2.18), the parent element is SmartReply (section 2.2.3.155).
[In ReplaceMime] None [Element ReplaceMime in SmartReply command request (section 2.2.2.18) has no child element.]
[In ReplaceMime] None [Element ReplaceMime in SmartReply command request (section 2.2.2.18) has no data type.]
[In ReplaceMime] Element ReplaceMime in SmartReply command request (section 2.2.2.18), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).
[In ReplaceMime] The ReplaceMime element is an empty tag element, meaning it has no value or data type.
[In ReplaceMime] It [ReplaceMime element] is distinguished only by the presence or absence of the <ReplaceMime/> tag.
[In ReplaceMime] Protocol version 12.1 does not support this [ReplaceMime] element.
[In ReplaceMime] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [ReplaceMime] element.
[In ReplaceMime] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [ReplaceMime] element.
[In ReplaceMime] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [ReplaceMime] element.
[In ReplaceMime] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [ReplaceMime] element.

[In ReplyMessage] The ReplyMessage element is an optional child element of the OofMessage element in Settings command requests and responses that specifies the message to be shown to a particular audience when the user is OOF.
[In ReplyMessage] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.136] are defined in the Settings namespace.
[In ReplyMessage] Element ReplyMessage in Settings command Oof request and response (section 2.2.2.17), the parent element is OofMessage (section 2.2.3.117).
[In ReplyMessage] None [ Element ReplyMessage in Settings command Oof request and response (section 2.2.2.17) has no child element.]
[In ReplyMessage] Element ReplyMessage in Settings command Oof request and response (section 2.2.2.17), the data type is string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7).
[In ReplyMessage] Element ReplyMessage in Settings command Oof request and response (section 2.2.2.17), the number allowed is 0...1 (optional).

[In ReplyMessage] The ReplyMessage element can be used in a Settings command Oof Get (section 2.2.3.75) response to convey the requested OOF message, or in a Settings command Oof Set request to set the message that the client wants to send to a particular audience.
[In ReplyMessage] If a ReplyMessage element is included in an Oof Set request, a BodyType element (section 2.2.3.17) MUST also be included.
[In ReplyMessage] The Oof property (section 2.2.3.112) supports the following three audiences for an OOF message [Internal, Known external, Unknown external].
[In ReplyMessage] Internal—A user who is in the same organization as the sending user.
[In ReplyMessage] Known external—A user who is outside the sending user's organization, but is represented in the sending user's contacts.
[In ReplyMessage] Unknown external—A user who is outside the sending user's organization and is not represented in the sending user's contacts.

[In ReplyMessage] The presence of one of the following elements [AppliesToInternal, AppliesToExternalKnown, AppliesToExternalUnknown], which are mutually exclusive, indicates the audience to which an OOF message pertains.
[In ReplyMessage] AppliesToInternal—The OOF message is relevant to an internal audience.
[In ReplyMessage] AppliesToExternalKnown—The OOF message is relevant to a known external audience.
[In ReplyMessage] AppliesToExternalUnknown—The OOF message is relevant to an unknown external audience.
[In ReplyMessage] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [ReplyMessage] element.
[In ReplyMessage] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [ReplyMessage] element.
[In ReplyMessage] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [ReplyMessage] element.
[In ReplyMessage] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [ReplyMessage] element.
[In ReplyMessage] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [ReplyMessage] element.
[In Request] The Request element is used in the following command requests: Autodiscover command requests (section 2.2.2.1), MeetingResponse command requests (section 2.2.2.9).
[In Request] The definition of the Request element differs according to the context in which it [Request element] is used.
[In Request] For more details, see section 2.2.3.137.1 and section 2.2.3.137.2.
[In Request(Autodiscover)] The Request element is a required child element of the Autodiscover element in Autodiscover command requests that contains the Autodiscover command request parameters.
[In Request(Autodiscover)] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.137.1] are defined in the http://schemas.microsoft.com/exchange/autodiscover/mobilesync/requestschema/2006 namespace.
[In Request(Autodiscover)] Element Request in Autodiscover command request (section 2.2.2.1), the parent element is Autodiscover (section 2.2.3.15).
[In Request(Autodiscover)] Element Request in Autodiscover command request (section 2.2.2.1), the child elements are EMailAddress (section 2.2.3.52.1), AcceptableResponseSchema (section 2.2.3.1).
[In Request(Autodiscover)] Element Request in Autodiscover command request (section 2.2.2.1), the data type is container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2).
[In Request(Autodiscover)] Element Request in Autodiscover command request (section 2.2.2.1), the number allowed is 1...1 (required).
[In Request(Autodiscover)] When more than one Request elements are present in an Autodiscover command request, the server returns an ErrorCode (section 2.2.3.61) value of 600.
[In Request(Autodiscover)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Request(Autodiscover)] element.
[In Request(Autodiscover)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Request(Autodiscover)] element.
[In Request(Autodiscover)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Request(Autodiscover)] element.
[In Request(Autodiscover)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Request(Autodiscover)] element.
[In Request(Autodiscover)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Request(Autodiscover)] element.
[In Request(MeetingResponse)] The Request element is a required child element of the MeetingResponse element in MeetingResponse command requests.
[In Request(MeetingResponse)] Its [Request's] child elements specify the meeting request that is being responded to.
[In Request(MeetingResponse)] Its [Request's] child elements specify the response to that meeting request.
[In Request(MeetingResponse)] Its [Request's] child elements specify the folder on the server that the meeting request is located in.

[In Request(MeetingResponse)] Elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.137.2] are defined in the MeetingResponse namespace, except where otherwise indicated by the presence of a namespace prefix (as defined in section 2.2.1).
[In Request(MeetingResponse)] Element Request in MeetingResponse command request (section 2.2.2.9), the parent element is MeetingResponse (section 2.2.3.96).

[In RequestId] The RequestId element is a child element of the Request element in MeetingResponse command requests and a child element of the Result element in MeetingResponse command responses.
[In RequestId] In both contexts, it [RequestId element] specifies the server ID of the meeting request message item.

[In RequestId] Elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.138] are defined in the MeetingResponse namespace, except where otherwise indicated by the presence of a namespace prefix (as defined in section 2.2.1).

[In RequestId] Element RequestId in MeetingResponse command response, the number allowed is 0…1 (optional).
[In RequestId] When the client sends a MeetingResponse command request, the client includes a RequestId element to identify which meeting request is being responded to.
[In RequestId] The RequestId element is also returned in the response to the client along with the status of the user's response to the meeting request.
[In RequestId] The RequestId element value can be up to 64 characters in length.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Partially verified by derived requirement: MS-ASCMD_R5871.

[In Response(Autodiscover)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Response(Autodiscover)] element.
[In Response(Autodiscover)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Response(Autodiscover)] element.

[In Response(ResolveRecipients)] The Response element is an optional child element of the ResolveRecipients element in ResolveRecipients command responses that contains information as to whether the recipient was resolved.

[In Response(ResolveRecipients)] If the recipient was resolved, the element also contains the type of recipient, the email address that the recipient resolved to, and, optionally, the S/MIME certificate for the recipient.
[In Response(ResolveRecipients)] All elements referenced in this section [2.2.3.140.5] are defined in the ResolveRecipients namespace.
[In Response(ResolveRecipients)] Element Response in ResolveRecipients command response (section 2.2.2.14), the parent element is ResolveRecipients (section 2.2.3.143)

[In Response(Search)] Element Response in Search command response (section 2.2.2.15), the parent element is Search (section 2.2.3.150).
[In Response(Search)] Element Response in Search command response (section 2.2.2.15), the child element is Store (section 2.2.3.168.2).
[In Response(Search)] Element Response in Search command response (section 2.2.2.15), the data type is container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section .
